name: Katarina BARLEY
text: I shall begin by announcing the results of yesterday's vote. The results of the round of voting on Monday 5 October are as follows: votes on requests for urgent procedure (Article 163 CRP): – Rail safety and interoperability in rail transport in the Channel Tunnel: adopted; - Authorisation by France to conclude an international agreement on the Channel Tunnel: adopted; - Organic production: start of application and certain other data: adopted; Final votes: - Commission proposal: amendment to Regulation (EU) No 514/2014: adopted; - Commission proposal: Guadeloupe, French Guiana, Martinique and Réunion: indirect taxes on 'traditional' rum: adopted; - Commission proposal: AIEM taxes in the Canary Islands: adopted; - Commission proposal: extension of the period of application of the special tax "octroi de mer" in the French outermost regions: adopted; - Draft amending budget No 7/2020: Updating revenue (own resources): adopted. I shall now give the floor to Mr Jörgen Warborn, who has requested that he be allowed to speak before today's first round of voting on his report on the implementation of the common commercial policy – annual report 2018. Mr Warborn has the floor for two minutes.

name: Jörgen WARBORN
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, so this is the yearly report on the implementation of the common commercial policy. The European Parliament wrote the latest report of this kind in 2018 but it did not write one last year because of the European elections. I therefore focus on the recent developments in the two last years and I look to the future, because this is also the input to the Commission’s trade policy review and to the incoming Trade Commissioner.  The report covers ongoing negotiations, implementation of free trade agreements, WTO issues, relations with the US, China, the UK and other important partners, as well as SMEs, trade and sustainable developments and digital trade and services. This report is also our response to the COVID-19 crisis. My main message here is that of European competitiveness, that this is not the time for protectionism. The response to a decline in trade due to the crisis shouldn’t be political control of companies’ value chains. Instead, rules-based free trade is even more important now and we must diversify our value chains, not shorten them.  This is the way forward to secure our resilience, supply and growth, and trade agreements play an important role in this. And we need to remove trade barriers. Export restrictions on the internal market are unacceptable; so are those to third countries.  In the last few years, we have closed trade deals with Canada, Japan, Singapore and Vietnam. We need to finish deals with Mercosur, Mexico, Australia, New Zealand and Taiwan, to mention a few. We must resolve trade disputes with the US, no matter who sits in the White House and we need the US by our side, not least to handle unfair competition from China, and we need close ties to the UK.  With this report we, the European Parliament, take our position for the future. We push back protectionism and pave the way for a competitive Europe. I would like to thank the shadows and all the advisers that have worked on this report.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the joint debate on the extraordinary European Council meetings of 1 and 2 October 2020 and 15 and 16 October 2020 (2020/2787(RSP) (2020/2788(SDR)).

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: President of the European Council. Mr President, we want a stronger Europe to shape a better world. Less dependence, more influence. That's why our last European Council focused on strengthening Europe, both within our borders and beyond our borders. We discussed how to reinforce our common house. Strategic autonomy and open economies are the centrepiece. We also addressed measures for the first issues and took key decisions. We had a comprehensive debate on the situation in the Eastern Mediterranean and our relationship with Turkey. A more stable and predictable Eastern Mediterranean region is in our strategic interest and we are united towards Turkey. We have agreed on a two—track approach: firmness and readiness to engage. EU solidarity with Cyprus and Greece is unwavering. Sovereignty and sovereign rights must be respected. We welcomed the start of a confidence-building dialogue between Greece and Turkey and we strongly condemned violations of the sovereign rights of the people of Cyprus. More steps are needed in that direction.  We call on Turkey to accept the invitation by Cyprus to engage in dialogue to settle all maritime—related disputes and we support the speedy resumption of UN—led negotiations and we remain fully committed to a comprehensive settlement of the Cyprus problem within the UN framework. Many issues need to be discussed, like the sharing of revenue from hydrocarbons. In case of renewed unilateral actions or provocations in breach of international law, we'll use all the instruments at our disposal to defend our interests and those of our Member States. But, of course, our preference is to engage in a positive EU—Turkey agenda with a focus on, for instance, the modernization of the customs union and trade facilitation, people—to—people contact, high—level dialogues and continued cooperation on migration issues.  It's not just about Turkey. There are conflicts, disputes and many overlapping challenges across the Eastern Mediterranean, and that's why I have proposed a multilateral conference on the Eastern Mediterranean. We call for a multilateral conference on the Eastern Mediterranean and we invite the High Representative to engage in talks about its organisation. This conference could address issues that need multilateral solutions, including maritime delimitations, security, energy, migration and economic cooperation.  On Belarus, our goals are clear: first, to end the repression and the violence against the opposition and the population; second, to allow the people of Belarus to decide on their future without interference. This means an inclusive national dialogue, which could be facilitated by the Organisation for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE), and those responsible for the violence must be held to account. We, therefore, took the decision on sanctions, which was immediately implemented.  We condemn the assassination attempt on Alexei Navalny with a military chemical nerve agent and we call on the Russian authorities to fully cooperate with the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW) to ensure an impartial international investigation to bring those responsible to justice. We will revert to this issue in two weeks. Concerning Nagorno-Karabakh, we call for a cessation of hostilities and the resumption of peaceful negotiations. External interference, military in particular, is unacceptable.  We now have a clear strategy towards China. We want to remain engaged with China. China is a major partner in addressing global challenges like climate change or COVID—19. We welcome China's recent commitment to carbon neutrality by 2060. We have encouraged China to take this path. China is also a key trading partner, but we want a more balanced relationship, with a level playing field and greater reciprocity. We expect our negotiations on the investment agreement to conclude successfully by the end of this year. On human rights, we will not paper over our differences, especially the rights of minorities and the rule of law like in Hong Kong. Ladies and gentlemen, this European Council was also an opportunity to look at the strategic autonomy of the European Union, in relation to an open economy. This has enabled us to affirm our ambition to work together, not only to repair the internal market, damaged by the Covid-19 crisis, but above all to improve the functioning of this internal market, which is a central value at the heart of the European project.  This was an opportunity to assert strong and ambitious directions in the digital field, after the climate field. These two major transitions are fundamental levers for successful transformation of the economic and social project at the European level.  We want to be a digital leader, we want to accelerate the necessary transformations, which means investing and equipping ourselves, especially through the regulatory capacity inspired by our values Fundamental. The heart of the matter is not only the economy, it is also the values and the type of digital model that we want. That is why we are totally convinced of the way forward: we must be more resilient, better able to guide our destiny by enshrining it in our commitment to multilateralism and the open economy, and maintain the ambition of a stronger Europe for a fairer world and a more committed world. With regard to Covid-19, there is a need to improve cooperation between Member States because, both in terms of testing, international travel and quarantine rules, cooperation and coordination between Member States are very perfect. There are plans to come back very regularly on this subject and to ask both the Commission and the Member States, through the Council, to be extremely committed. The issue of vaccines was also discussed. This was an opportunity for the Commission to present a precise picture of the progress of the decisions that were taken. This is to ensure that, when available, vaccines can be made available fairly and equitably in Europe. So that the issue of distribution and priorities can be clarified between us and that we can also fully assume our responsibility at the international level, because this vaccine is a common good, that this challenge is a global challenge and it is not just a matter of getting by on its own. As the European Union, we must also support our partners in making progress on this issue. In conclusion, I would say that, in the political, democratic and institutional process and with the forthrly multi-year budget and this exceptional stimulus fund, we must give the European Union the resources to act and implement what we believe in in in the years to come.  We will continue in good faith, in dialogue and with mutual respect, to work and negotiate with you, Parliament, so that we can come up with decisions and solutions as quickly as possible, move forward, assume our responsibilities and meet the expectations of the 450 million European citizens as well as those around the world who are convinced that this European project is a necessary added value.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, let me address this House today on behalf of the Commission’s President, Ursula von der Leyen.  As you are well aware, she is still in self-isolation today after participating in a meeting attended by a person who tested positive for coronavirus, and as the President has said, we have to be careful and do our utmost to reduce the spread of the virus.  Now, if you will allow me, turning to the topic at hand – the European Council – President Michel has debriefed you on the very substantial discussion on foreign affairs. I would sum it up very simply: we at the Commission are very glad that the European Council has finally found unity after a very long debate, because when we are united we have the power to address the many challenges that surround our European Union. Today, I would like to focus on two issues from the European Council where our unity will be needed and will be tested again: our climate and digital goals, and Brexit.  First, on our climate goals, which will be at the core of the next European Council. This Parliament and Europe’s heads of state and government have agreed on making Europe the first climate neutral continent by 2050.  For that, we need to speed up. If we continued with business-as-usual, we would only cut our emissions by 60% by 2050, and that’s too little to contain global warming and its devastating impact. That is why the Commission proposes to increase our climate ambition for 2030. We propose a reduction of at least 55% by 2030 compared to 1990. It is an ambitious goal, but it is within our reach.  There is an economic rationale for 55%. Our cost—benefit analyses tell us that the benefits are bigger than the costs. Science tells us that we have no choice. The Paris Agreement requires it. And the public consultation we have conducted shows that a very large majority of Europeans expect this from us, including in the business sector. They all observe the increase in extreme weather conditions.  Businesses want to invest in green innovation, but they also want certainty and predictability. Do we have a plan to realise the increased ambition? Yes, we do. We have policies and rules in place that have delivered CO2 reductions in the past while growing our economy. The emissions trading system coupled with other rules and mechanisms is proving its effectiveness.  We can and will propose by June 2021 an upgrade for our policy toolbox to become ‘fit for 55’ in the most cost—efficient and innovation—enhancing manner. This will be underpinned again by impact assessments for Member States and economic sectors.  The second question is: do we have the resources to finance the higher climate ambitions? Yes, we do.  The next EU budget and Next Generation EU will make available more than EUR 600 billion for climate and green investment. This investment from the EU level should leverage a multiple of this in further private and public investment that will support the transition, and this includes investment for a fair transition.  Then we have to ask: do we have allies in this task? Yes, we do.  President Michel just made reference to the fact that, at the UN General Assembly two weeks ago, President Xi announced that China aims to achieve carbon neutrality before 2060, and that it will peak its CO2 emissions before 2030. The same with the President of South Africa, Cyril Ramaphosa, who declared that his country will aim at carbon neutrality by 2050. These are messages we want to hear and we need more of them. Europe will not solve climate change alone. We represent less than 10% of global CO2 emissions, but we are not alone and this is good news for the world. But it also means that we must preserve our ‘first—mover’ advantage. We must step up our climate ambition if we want the best green technologies to be European technologies.  So the question that remains is: do we have the resolve?  If you look around us, we are heading from the wildfire season straight into the flood season, and I want to appreciate President Sassoli’s remarks and expression of solidarity with the floods which took place just this weekend in Italy and France. Is this the world we want to live in? A world of never—ending natural disasters? A constant increase in desertification? Now it is the question for you, for the European Parliament, to unite around an ambitious climate objective of at least 55% by 2030. And we will push for Europe’s heads of state and government to unite behind the same ambition before the end of the year. The Commission wants it to be our common goal to deliver the European Union’s nationally determined contribution by the end of 2020, a date that marks the fifth anniversary of the Paris Agreement.  The green transition goes hand in hand with the digital one. Like for the green transition we need clear objectives for the next decade. Just like with our 2030 climate goals, Europe needs to up its game. This is how the 2020s can become Europe’s digital decade. Last week’s European Council recognised that need, calling for a digital compass to navigate this transformational period and has concluded to invest 20% of the Recovery and Resilience Facility in digital projects.  That investment will support and profit from our actions in three fields: First, we must establish a true digital single market through firm enforcement of the rules we already have, and we must deepen it in fields such as digital services.  Second, fair competition. We need new tools to address the power of global tech platforms over small European companies and to respond to global subsidy races. That’s why we will propose a digital service act in December of this year, and a foreign subsidies instrument in early 2021. Third, we must build up the digital capacity of our industries, and for this we need European flagships and alliances, for instance on secure 5G networks, low energy data processing and quantum computing.  In parallel to this, we must also better serve citizens and businesses through digital public services and common European digital identity.  All this requires major investment which Next Generation EU can drive. Next Generation EU is our opportunity to deliver. Let’s use it! Finally, we will need all our energy in this final stage of negotiations with the United Kingdom. We are less than 100 days away from the end of the transition period. There are two tracks to which we should devote our full attention and energy. The ongoing negotiations on our future partnership, which are tough, and the full and timely implementation of the Withdrawal Agreement, which I have the honour to oversee.  This Agreement guarantees our citizens’ rights, our financial interests, the integrity of the single market – and crucially – the Good Friday Agreement. The fact that our British friends now, all of a sudden, propose the draft bill that, by its very nature, is a breach of this Withdrawal Agreement is a heavy blow to the British signature and reliability.  Respecting agreements is first a matter of law, but also of trust and of good faith, and this is why last week the Commission started an infringement procedure by sending a letter of formal notice to the UK Government. We invited them to submit their observations by the beginning of November. The full and timely implementation of the Withdrawal Agreement is simply not debatable.  Concerning the negotiations on our future partnership, Prime Minister Johnson and President von der Leyen took stock of the negotiations last Saturday. They both agreed that some progress had been made but that a lot remains to be done.  We all know where the difficulties are. We all know our mandate, our red lines, our objectives. Our negotiators were instructed to work as hard as they can to try to finalise an agreement. Michel Barnier and his team have, as always, our full trust. But time is short.  In case we reach an agreement, which is our objective, both parties will have to ensure ratification in time for an entry into force by 1 January 2021, and this will need some time, including time for this House.  If this is not the case, we will be in the ‘no-deal’ territory. Given that we are less than 100 days away from this date, we cannot exclude this scenario. This is why we will continue to work with you and the Member States to ensure that we are ready for every scenario.  This is a delicate moment for Europe. The Brexit deadline looms. The pandemic is still with us. It is a moment of uncertainty, so it must be the moment of unity. The moment of courage.  Long live Europe.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, let me start with a brief remark on the Commission. Tomorrow, after a successful hearing in the committees, we will vote on one new commissioner and one commissioner who is changing portfolio. I remind us of this because it's a historic moment: it's the first time we have the chance to achieve a really gender-balanced Commission, and I think that is a good thing. I promised citizens this during the campaign, as did a lot of other politicians; we are making it now and that is good for Europe. Now for the daily assessment of last week's Council. Again, the glass is half-full and half-empty; that's the principle of the Council. Half-full, because we have concrete sanctions against those who are responsible for violence and torture in Belarus. That's good, but, on the other hand, Lukashenko is not on the list. Please explain to us why the brain of the whole system is not on the list. Second, we have Greece, Cyprus and Turkey. Greek and Cypriot interests are European interests. There's no doubt about this. We use strong words and have a clear strategy, but still, the glass is half-empty. I think we cannot explain to citizens all over Europe that we are still negotiating with Turkey about enlargement, about Turkey's full membership of the European Union. So, once again, small steps, right direction, but no clear signal. Good compromise but no leadership. Once again, that's the outcome of the Council. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The biggest concern that concerns me at the moment is what is going on in our economy.  It is a question of substance: 15 million unemployed on this continent. In Spain, 40% of the young generation that has no jobs. France - Renault, 15 000 jobs, Air France, 7 500. In Germany, all DAX companies will cut 80,000 jobs over the next two years – Mercedes 4,000, VW 27,000 – and in Italy, the number has risen by 290,000 in six months. Studies show that the Corona crisis now affects one in five jobs on this continent. We do not currently have any answers to these tasks. People are afraid of their standard of living, of their future, of their social standard, and we currently have no answers. I would also like to point out that I do not believe that this is just a dent, a short-term development that we have. If you look at the figures from China, for example, you have to see, unfortunately, that China has only had a few months this year where there has been economic decline; China is already growing again. Next year, more than 8% plus in china's economic figures are forecast. Economic power in this world is currently being redistributed. This can be compared to a post-war situation where the weights shift massively. China is currently the winner, and Europe is currently the loser. That is the reality when we look at the world map. That is why we must now put jobs and jobs at the heart of the political debate. As the Recovery Fund, Vice-President Sefsovic mentioned, a prioritisation for the agenda for the future must be created. With regard to the internal market, we need a renewed basis for prosperity. We need an end to isolation and selfishness. We need to look again at common rules at European level. We finally need proposals from the Commission and not just statements from the Commission. Thirdly, we must tackle bureaucracy. 60, 70 years of ever new regulation on top leads to paralysis and not to the freedom of our businesses. We must finally face up to this question. Fourthly, we must take care of exports. Our prosperity is based on the fact that we export to neighbouring countries, and I am already concerned about this when I consider, for example, the discussion about Mercosur. Europe must have the strength to conclude trade agreements in the future, otherwise we will not be able to secure our prosperity in the long term. Innovation: Financing innovation is important. A reform agenda at national level, and Vice-President Efsovic, has mentioned it: we must put an end to hard Brexit, this madness. We must reach a reasonable compromise with our British friends. We in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats want the continent's main issue to finally be discussed in the coming weeks, and that is the economic question of whether we will be able to secure prosperity. It is the basis of our social model, and that is why we need jobs, jobs and jobs.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, events in the European Union neighborhood do not stop, and last summer he has demonstrated this with a series of crises in Lebanon, Belarus, Mali and the eastern Mediterranean. The unity reached at the European Council to sanction those responsible for violent repression in Belarus is good news. So is the message of firmness to Turkey to respect international law. There is scope to reduce tensions in the Mediterranean and holding a multilateral conference is the ideal space for this. The pandemic has highlighted both our strengths and weaknesses. Faced with the strategic rivalry between the United States and China, the European Union cannot be a mere arbiter. He has to become a global actor with his own voice. That is why we support strategic autonomy that allows us to rebuild our industrial and digital independence in the face of future crises. But let us be frank, the strategic autonomy of the European Union will only be a reality if we are able to guarantee social cohesion, a single market that meets the objectives of the European Green Pact and a competitive digital transition that leaves no one behind. The first wave of the pandemic attacked everyone equally, but on the second wave not everyone can defend themselves in the same way. Cuts in health, science and education resulting from the 2008 crisis have left a wide swath of the population unsused. Faced with the layers of population that can cope with the pandemic with telework and educational and technological support for their children, the most disadvantaged classes coexist in small flats, in high-density neighborhoods, with face-to-face work, without resources to complement their children's education and with health centers that are overwhelmed. This time we cannot afford a two-speed recovery of the European economy, and to avoid this we need the European Union budget for the next seven years and the recovery plan to be available as soon as possible. We are prepared to reach an agreement through fair and sincere negotiation. But the Council must park its game of accusations. We have been waiting two years for ministers to negotiate, so we cannot now give in as Parliament to sacrifice the priorities already agreed in this House. If we want to end the technology gap, we need a recovery plan that invests 20% in the digital transition. If we are to guarantee the human capital of the European Union, programmes such as Erasmus or as Horizon Europe must be respected in the next budget. And if we aspire to definitively defeat the pandemic, development cooperation and humanitarian aid must be sufficiently funded, because we will only defeat the virus within and outside our borders. We are in time to avoid a social fracture if we can make sure that the sacrifice of recovery does not go to the most vulnerable. Let us do so with a clear and ambitious timetable on new own resources. Because the adoption of new taxes, such as financial transitions or greenhouse gas emissions, will allow us to guarantee the public accounts of the Member States and the purchasing power of taxpayers. Don't let it fall on taxpayers' backs to be able to deal with this recovery plan. We are aware of the difficulty of the negotiations, but with the Council and Parliament on an equal footing we have an obligation to reach an agreement that meets the greatest challenge of our generations. Citizenship is waiting for us.

name: Dacian CIOLOŞ
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, Mr President, dear Charles, thank you again for being here. Speaking of international relations, this debate that took place in the Council was more than necessary. Some powers have decided to complicate the situation, as if the health crisis, the economic crisis and the climate crisis were not enough. At a time when the world has to stick together, some have decided to play it. We must therefore ensure that the Union becomes a geopolitical, economic and democratic power. There is an urgent need for a common strategic vision to become a truly geopolitical Europe, to act rather than react, and this with speed when necessary. But this implies that the Member States understand the value of a truly collective action. This is not always the case in international relations, because everyone defends their interests.  And in the face of China, Turkey or Russia, we now need a strategic vision, but also unity and firmness in action. How could we define ourselves as a real geopolitical actor if we need two months to sanction the Lukashenko regime and, two months later, it has still not been placed on this list.  We simply lose credibility when we meet the Council just to discuss. Our power must be based on new tools of action and decision-making. Passing foreign policy by qualified majority and putting in place a regime of human rights sanctions are among the emergencies now. This would allow us to react quickly, for example in situations such as the poisoning of Alexei Navalny.  The Council also spoke of Europe's economic power. Our influence depends on our economic influence and this economic influence depends on our climate ambition and our mastery of digital technology. Parliament has recently set up a special committee on artificial intelligence in the digital age, we intend to make proposals in this area. Our internal market, our social and democratic organisation and the strategic autonomy of our economy require a real ambition to invest in digital. Democratic power, at last. We can only be credible at the international level if we are blameless ourselves. All strategic development must be based on strong values: freedom, democracy and the rule of law. What credibility would we have, beyond our borders, if every European could not count on an independent judiciary, free from political pressure and clientelism. If every European could not count on an independent press, and on journalists free from any influence exerted by oligarchs close to power. If public funds, instead of fuelling innovation and healthy investment, sometimes end up in the pockets of the corrupt and obscure networks of interests. We must therefore be clear:without democratic values, the injection of financial liquidity will not be sufficient. We need both. If we lack a common foundation of values, we will not be able to solve concrete problems, such as health coordination to deal with coronavirus. And this coordination, Parliament has been asking for and demanding for months, and we can see that there are still Member States that do not respond to it. If it is still not in place, it is because some want to feed a health nationalism, a clash of values on our continent, more than a shock of solidarity. We must not accept it, because we will all pay the price. The Union must therefore be this force capable of protecting the health, employment and rights of all European citizens.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Michel, I increasingly have the impression that whenever important European institutions, especially at a time of crisis, come together to decide something, they only show how torn this continent is and how much this continent is now adrift, a secondary continent, a victim of the wrong political choices made, especially over the last twenty years. You began your speech by talking about foreign policy, talking about what you decided about the various geopolitical hotbeds around Europe – and my fellow Members have mentioned this: foreign dictators make a mockery of us when you see these decisions. You have sanctioned Belarus, but you have forgotten to sanction the leader of that country, who is responsible for what is happening. As usual, you praised the attitude towards Turkey, which nevertheless remains a lascivious attitude, an attitude that allows Erdoğan, the Turkish dictator, to make a mockery of the European institutions, to make a mockery of the European Member States and to continue to challenge and provoke the European Union and the Member States by doing what it wants, without us being able to take decisive action. It is once again a totally inconsistent approach, where we are lascivious to foreign dictators while we allow ourselves to debate the rule of law, the behaviour of certain Member States, forgetting, once again, that it is not the European Union that legitimises the Member States, but the States that legitimise the Union: this is a concept that we should all have more respect for. The second point, with which I am going to close, is the most important point in my opinion: there was talk of recovery fund, in July a great deal was touted but in the end what remains on the table? There remains an agreement that has not yet been drawn up; we do not know when and how the money will come and the impact, seeing the numbers published by the Commission, is absolutely minimal. Next year, in 2021, 6 % of the amount will be paid if there is an agreement. In the face of a double-digit fall in GDP for my country, we will receive support of 0.16 % of GDP. But we're sure there will be taxes, what you call own resources. A plastic tax will arrive on 1 January. You will say: "very well", it helps because it allows us to attract resources and also allows us to reduce the use of un recycled plastic. But again, two one. Either we will have a source of funding, through a European tax, or we will have a reduction in plastics: it is not possible to achieve both objectives at the same time. I will close with a comment, which I would like to see at the next European Council. We are in the greatest moment of crisis in the European Union and the Member States, an exogenous crisis that does not depend on us. We have made a Stability and Growth Pact, precisely because in times of difficulty we must have stability and growth and what happens? At a time when we are facing the greatest crisis, when we need stability and growth, we must suspend this pact! This is a reflection that I would like to see in the next Council.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, what strikes me in the conclusions of the European Council is the asymmetry in the handling of Belarusian, Chinese, Russian and Turkish cases. The authorities of these four states daily and brutally flout the very principles of democracy and, at the international level, systematically oppose the strength of the fait accompli with the law. But now only Lukashenko's regime is being subjected to sanctions that ensure, understand who can, to spare the autocrat when two days ago, his riot police arrested eleven reporters and even a 13-year-old girl. Big threat. Faced with China, the heads of state and government still refuse to even name the Uighur minority, of which one million citizens are prisoners of re-education camps. Faced with Russia, we will simply ask for an investigation into the poisoning of Vladimir Putin's opponent, Alexei Navalny. As for Turkey, it is once again invited to dialogue as Erdogan continues to vindicate, the political opposition, journalists, academics, human rights activists and multiplies military adventures abroad. Like you, Mr Michel, I believe in the virtues of dialogue, but I also believe that we must be able to resist if we want to be respected. However, the European Union's willingness to resist is inversely proportional to its dependence on its neighbours: commercial dependence on China, energy dependence on Russia, dependence on asylum and migration on Turkey.  We must therefore find the means of greater autonomy. The relocation of our economy, as well as the energy transition, go in this direction. Similarly, a Union capable of taking its fair share in the reception of refugees and migrants would be less vulnerable to the blackmail of the potentates to whom we have very recklessly entrusted the keys to our borders. And it is not the Commission's recent proposals, Mr Vice-President, that will bring Europe out of this unworthy myth of the fortress.  More than all this, ladies and gentlemen, what devalues the word of the European Union is its inability to uphold even the rule of law which it would like to be the herald of outside. And make no mistake, violations of freedoms are not the preserve of the two usual suspects.  The repression of the right to protest in France, the Chovanec case in Belgium, the discriminatory treatment of Catalan prisoners in Spain or the way we treat refugees at our borders, remind us that no Member State should enjoy a presumption of exemplarity and that our vigilance must be permanent. This is the meaning of the European Parliament's resolute commitment to the current negotiations on the Union's budget and its recovery plan.  Finally, we want the European Union to have an effective instrument that will enable us to uphold a simple principle: the benefits of membership of the Union require respect for the foundations of democracy and our values, starting with respect for human dignity, that of all human beings present and to come, here and elsewhere.  A more balanced interdependence, an ability to take responsibility and a stronger coherence with the values it proclaims, Mr President, are the conditions for a more geopolitical European Union.  But to do that, we still have to give us the means to do so. The means of effective joint action in external affairs, such as budgetary or fiscal matters, the unanimity rule puts the Union at the mercy of the most extreme points of view. It is time to abolish it.

name: Derk Jan EPPINK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, I will try to stay within the speaking time, as usual. One of the last points in the Council's conclusions is Armenia. That is, of course, a pity, because we see that it is actually the weakest part of these conclusions at the same time.  In 2012, the European Union was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize, and I sometimes wonder why. If I look at the United States, I have the impression that Mr Trump has achieved more successes in four years than the European Union has achieved in 20 years. If I can take the list – and now, of course, you should not get angry –: Kosovo, Serbia, at the front door, economic normalisation thanks to the United States; Israel, diplomatic relations with the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain; in Afghanistan peace negotiations after 20 years of war; North Korea, the fat man kept in check through negotiations; united states, canada and mexico.  Yes, that's not nothing. And, Mr Michel, you are no further than calling. I would say a bit more energy, a bit more Trumpism, maybe.  Because now, after ten years of European common foreign policy, we are only seeing weak porridge, when there are means of pressure to put pressure on Azerbaijan and Turkey, but they are afraid to use it. So I propose a coalition of the willing states, both in Europe and hopefully with the United States, to put pressure on these countries. For, Mr President, it is macabre that 100 years after the genocide in Armenia we do not go beyond moral appeals. We have to do something. And if the EU cannot do that, then European states must do so themselves in cooperation with the United States, because at least it can show power. We only have on offer: weak porridge.

name: Giorgos GEORGIOU
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Mr Michel, for the past two years Turkey has been continuing its illegal activity in the Cypriot EEZ. For the past two years, unfortunately, we have witnessed a bad theatre. To tell you the truth, of course, I did not expect the European Council to impose sanctions on Turkey, and I am sure that it will not impose sanctions on Turkey either in December, for reasons we all know very well. Of course sanctions are not an end in itself, Mr Michel, but Turkey will be given a positive political agenda. However, Turkey must change course, stop violating the sovereign rights of the Republic of Cyprus, enter the negotiations in a positive mood for a solution to the Cyprus problem on the basis of the bi-social federation, stop threatening and ordering the illegal settlement of Famagusta. Because Yavuz has left the Cypriot seas and that is a good thing, but the ghost town, the city of Famagusta, is threatened again and in danger.  450 years after its siege for a year and its capture by Lala Mustafa, despite the heroic resistance of a Venetian, Mr President, Mr Sassoli, of Marcantonios Bragadinos, Famagusta is again threatened with illegal colonization. Famagusta is a European affair. History must not repeat itself, the European Union must act immediately to prevent this possibility, because if Famagusta is colonized, this will be a tombstone for the solution of the Cyprus problem. But if the Cyprus issue is not resolved, you can be sure, Mr President, that tensions in the Mediterranean will continue and no dialogue will progress. Europe must act now, literally now, because tomorrow will be too late.

name: Mario FURORE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe certainly takes the lead in the world on one thing: the time spent by leaders in debating. Well, in the end decisions must be taken, because the citizens expect decisions and unfortunately we, once again, are forced here to comment on the Council's too many indecision. I am thinking, for example, of the European response to the health and economic crisis. The threats by selfish countries to slow down Next Generation EU are unacceptable, all the more so since the European Parliament, this House – the only institution democratically elected by the citizens – has repeatedly shown the way. If the Council listens a little more to this Parliament and a little less to the either/or who are now coming from Budapest, now from The Hague, we will certainly make progress. The same applies to foreign policy: it is all very well to discuss, but in the end Belarus and Turkey must respect fundamental human rights.  If we are weak with dictators outside the European area, we encourage the 'dictators' in our own homes to do the same, and that would be the end. Europe, on the other hand, needs courage and determination to be, as the citizens demand, a beacon of freedom and social justice in the world.

name: Mario FURORE
text: President of the Council. Mr President, thank you for giving me the opportunity to reply after this first round of speech, it is proof of the interactivity between the democratic European institutions.  Mr. Weber, you said, ''It is a good compromise, but there is no leadership.'' And that is the real issue for the future of the European Union, and that is why I started my message by declaring that our aim should be 'less dependency and more influence'. And for the first time in the Council, I have chosen to bring the debate on strategic autonomy to open economies by supporting the multilateral model.  The debate is not over, but it is a starting point on which to start the debate, because Europe is an economic power: the first trading power, the second largest economy in the world. It is also a democratic power: we guarantee a world order based on values, on the rule of law, on the rule of law, values that inspire every action we take. And the question is how the Europe of tomorrow can be more of a political power, with a positive effect inspired by our values, considering that the pillar of climate change coupled with the pillar of digital change are spaces within which we will exercise our strategic influence, as we have once done, for example , in the chemical field, or in the processing of private data, for example, that is the issue. And you will observe that since this new institutional cycle, only a few months ago, a few clear choices have been made. China, for example. I remember that for a long time Europe was totally divided. How to approach the relationship with China? In a few months, through political work, through dialogue between us, we have aligned a clear, strategic position and we are expressing the message clearly. When I speak to President Xi about fundamental values, human rights, I am not looking down, I am talking about Uighurs. We do not have the same political model or the same economic model. There are three points: we want to be engaged with China, we believe in the virtues of dialogue, we think that China is a partner to manage the issue like COVID and the climate issue. You will also observe that China, like South Africa, is committed to the issue of climate neutrality. It is certainly not enough, we must remain vigilant, but it is an approach that shows that we have an influence, it goes in the right direction. And finally, I would also like to highlight another point that I like to highlight so as not to be like I have not heard. The question of sanctions: Belarus, Turkey, differences of opinion expressed on the issue of sanctions. From my point of view, as with the European Council, sanctions are not a goal in themselves. Sanctions are an instrument. They are an element, along with many others at the international level, that could perhaps be more coherent, not just for a geopolitical Commission, but for a geopolitical European Union. In my view, that is the sense of the process that must be pursued. Once the sanctions are activated, we can actually decide to lighten them, to remove them, to extend them, to make them worse, and it is in this spirit that, in full consciousness, a choice has been made. We are advocating for an inclusive dialogue, dear Mr Weber, within the framework of Belarus, we are advocating for CSOs to play a role and we will come back regularly to the issue of Belarus to see how we should act and perhaps make decisions based on the positive or negative developments that will take place. Turkey now. Clear and clear solidarity with Greece and Cyprus. We defend sovereignty. We defend sovereign rights. A first impact, albeit slight, certainly timid, intervened since even before the European Council, the prospect of a resumption of dialogue, after weeks of tension throughout the summer, between Greece and Turkey, opened up. It's not enough, it's fragile, it's not naivety, but it's a first effect, it's a first impact, it seems to me.  In Cyprus a few hours ago, the ship Yavuz left the waters. This is not enough, we will remain attentive, vigilant, and I will be in contact on behalf of the European Union with President Erdogan to see how I can, on behalf of the Union, act on the ground, both with firmness (in terms of principles and international law) but also in opening up to engage in more positive discussions if there is a common will. I also fully support the process of United Nations, I hope that after the elections in the northern part of the island, which are due to take place in October, there will be the capacity for the United Nations to relaunch this dialogue and that is why I have indicated that in this dialogue several central and difficult issues will have to be discussed through dialogue and I hope progress can be made, such as the issue of the sharing of hydrocarbon revenues which is a subject with others. be debated. And finally, Europe is at the rendezvous when, for example, we take the initiative of this multilateral conference on this part of the Mediterranean to put around the table, to engage together those who sometimes have common points of view but also sometimes different points of view on maritime disputes, on energy issues, on security issues, on security issues. , on economic development issues. This, ladies and gentlemen, is how I see the role of the European Union and therefore I react, Mr Weber, a good compromise, no leadership, I roll up my sleeves for a European leadership less dependence, more influence.

name: Daniel CASPARY
text: Mr President, Mr President Michel, I would like to thank mr Michel for his work on What you have just formulated is very exciting. The only impression i have is that it is not the European Council that meets most of the time, but the Council of European States usually meets. What do I mean by that? I have the impression that in the body you chair, the Member States very, very often do not care about the common European interest, they do not have in mind that if we come together, if we make compromises, if we try to find a common European solution, that this could help everyone together in case of doubt, but I have the impression that we will have the impression that we will be able to reach a compromise. , that you chair a body that includes many people who think that if they put their national interest forward, then they achieve more. That is why we are not making progress on many issues. What is the situation in the internal market? You said in the last Council that we want to develop and strengthen the internal market. But in many areas we are seeing national markets closing off. You raised the issue of climate policy. As the European Union, we are happy to set ourselves ambitious objectives. However, I see that many Member States are still refusing to make the contribution that each country must make. You are talking about the common foreign and security policy. However, we also saw at the weekend how the focus was not on a common European foreign and security policy, but on how the Member States have once again put their national interests forward. In this sense, I would like you to have the strength to create a mood in your body and to create a mood that the Member States and their Heads of State or Government really see the European interest and that we will hopefully return these national things, which we have seen more and more in recent months, together... (Microphone off)

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: Madam President, Vice-President, Mr. Efsovic, representatives of the Council, I would like to thank the Commissionerfor the Council. Many important points have been raised today. However, I would like to mention an important issue, namely the future of our digital development in the European Union. I believe that it is undisputed that the Green Deal will only succeed if we, as the European Union, also understand new technologies. Now my primary concern is how we deal with the 5G developments. 5G is crucial for the future of the European Union, and we see that we are also lagging behind here – lagging behind China, the United States, South Korea and also Japan.  What we are talking about here is how the European Union can support the fact that we have good examples here, for example in the form of the Important Projects of Common European Interest, the so-called IPCEI, which, thanks to your efforts, Mr. Efovic, we also have in the area of the battery industry. We should also use them in the field of 5G technology, because without them we will fall further behind in international comparison.

name: Luis GARICANO
text: – Madam President, President Sánchez, at the European summit, asked this Parliament to work quickly to ensure that the money from European plans is available from 1 January, and So did Mr Michel tell us today. We share, I believe, everyone in this room the urgency and guarantee the Council that we will do our part; negotiating teams are working non-stop to achieve this.  But the Council and the States must also do their own. The Council must stop blocking the rule of law mechanism, which is so important to prevent money from being used to infringe citizens' rights. And the Council must also work with us to develop transparent and demanding rules, which ensure that European money is spent to transform our economies, for the benefit of all.  Each country must also do its part. There are nine short days left before the end of the deadline to deliver recovery plans, and they must be coherent, transformative, ambitious plans to rebuild our economies for the benefit of all. Mr Michel is right when he tells us that the citizens expect us to act, but they also expect us to invest their money well, and we must work together for it.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: Madam President, between 3,000 and 4,000 jihadists have been transferred from Syria to Armenia by Turkey, which Emmanuel Macron himself has admitted. Thousands of Islamist mercenaries guilty of war crimes by Daesh, sent by Erdogan to commit others and continue the Armenian genocide perpetrated 80 years ago by the Ottoman Empire. Between 1.2 and 1.5 million victims, a genocide that the Turkish authorities have never acknowledged, whose recognition by other states has been described by Erdogan as the greatest insult possible. But history is not an insult! A history that Erdogan would like to rewrite, however, since all his manoeuvres converge towards a single goal: to reconstitute the Ottoman Empire, to regain the role of leader of the Sunni Islamic world, which Turkey had at the time of the caliphate. A project he assumes, including in his official propaganda videos: military actions in Syria and Libya, the barely concealed proximity with the Islamic State, the orchestration of a real migratory invasion in Greece, the destruction of churches in Anatolia, piracy of Cypriot resources in the Mediterranean, the transformation of St. Sophia Basilica into a mosque and now the incursion into Armenian territory , the oldest Christian country in the world. All of Erdogan's actions sign up for this neo-Ottoman inspiration and during this time the Council has a strong taste for litote. In its conclusions of 2 October, it strongly condemns the violations of the sovereign rights of the Republic of Cyprus, which must cease. But it has been 50 years, 50 years since Turkey occupied half the territory of a Member State, and you continue to want, I quote, a dialogue in good faith. Retaliation could have been taken on the money from the accession process, on EIB funding, on securing the borders of Greece and Bulgaria, on the suspension of the customs union, which allows Turkey to make 40% of its foreign trade with the European Union. But nothing. Nothing! Europe is afraid of Turkey and the response is tragic, the Council has once again given in to this constant racket, he reminds us Balzac, saying that resignation is a daily suicide. If the nations of Europe are unable to put up with him in response, Erdogan could succeed tomorrow in fulfilling his imperialist and Islamist dream, while once again here in Brussels, we discuss the sex of angels.

name: Diana RIBA I GINER
text: – Madam President, beyond the economic volume or the percentages of financial attribution to sectoral policies, I would like to stress the importance of the participation of European regions in the management of the future Recovery and Resilience Mechanism. Since the onset of the COVID crisis, most local regions and authorities have been at the forefront of the needs of the population, some of them even managing key competencies such as health, education or the social sphere. It is therefore the regional administrations that know their communities best and also have experience in managing European funds. The inclusion of regions in fund management would allow us to streamline and carry out more projects, thus gaining more credibility from the European Union. Ladies and gentlemen, crisis management has made clear the need for greater coordination, but at the same time greater multi-level governance. Only in this way will we be able to address the many consequences of the crisis, which has impacted our regions differently. Some of the amendments to the Commission text, now in negotiation in the European Parliament, already contain this proposal. Let us hope that they will be adopted and that the Council will then also take them into consideration. Thinking globally to act locally is more necessary than ever.

name: Johan VAN OVERTVELDT
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is quite clear that we are in a difficult situation as a result of an ongoing health crisis with far-reaching socio-economic consequences. There is considerable uncertainty around what can happen to vaccines, around the effectiveness of a number of anticorona measures, around the short- and medium-term economic outlook and so on.  This uncertainty is causing the downward spiral to be reversed rather than reversed, and it is imperative that strong action is taken at all levels of public policy to reverse that negative spiral. In this respect, the EU is falling short today.  I refer here, for example, to the negotiations on the new multiannual budget and the recovery and resilience facility. Clear, clear and forward-looking measures on these issues could already make a big difference and remove a great deal of uncertainty. But that signal stays out. The effective launch of this much-needed recovery fund is a long way off. That has absolutely nothing to do with Parliament's attitude. This has everything to do with the fact that there are no or hardly meaningful proposals from the Council on suggestions made by Parliament to improve the measures that are currently before us.  I can only express the hope that this situation will turn quickly and that we will quickly get meaningful answers to extremely sensible proposals.

name: Idoia VILLANUEVA RUIZ
text: – Madam President, Europe today has the opportunity and responsibility to decide who it is and how it contributes to the world; he's into life on it. Reconstruction plans: from the determination to deal with the pandemic in a united way, the facts must be passed, and for that it is necessary to take forward the reconstruction plans immediately.  We cannot allow us to emerge from this new crisis with a new inequality gap, and for that it is necessary to guarantee public services, to revive the care economy; that the energy transition and digitization do not become the business of a few and that they serve to strengthen the industry, that they also look at the primary sector, to fix population in the territory, to young employment and to achieve the objectives against climate change.  We need a clear look with autonomy in foreign policy. But first of all, we need to end the shame of this Europe: to comply with human rights in our territory, so that we can call ourselves as such, human; immediate relocation of all refugee camps; legal and safe avenues. No more Morias, no more deaths, no more shame.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, the European Council has once again stroked Turkey's bourgeoisie, rushing to sanctions on Belarus. European Union-Turkey relations are chained to strong economic, political and military interests, with miserable refugee agreements. This is dictated by the communiqué legitimising all flagrant Turkish violations that have taken place so far in the Aegean and Cypriot EEZs, with hypocritical concerns for the future. That is also why no word has been said about Turkey's interventions in Syria, Libya, Iraq, Cyprus or its special role in The North Karabakh.  A common goal of the European Union, the US, NATO, their civil divisions, Greece and Turkey, but also governments and civil parties, is to set the table for negotiations on co-exploitation, sacrificing sovereign rights in the Aegean and the South-East Mediterranean, with the aim of a dichotomy solution to the Cyprus issue under Euro-Atlantic supervision, with NATO as a gendarme, and that is why Mr Stoltenberg is also in Athens. The only way out for the people is to fight for disengagement from imperialist plans, with disengagement from the European Union and NATO and with the people in charge of the wealth of their country.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: – Madam President, it is not only a single, common market for the European Union, but also a community of values, we can hear it day after day. Let us leave this consideration for a moment. The question of whether the value community is not an ideological identity, and let us leave the question of how the value community is being destroyed by a left-wing, liberal, federalist approach that engages in a combative, aggressive, partisan political, ideological struggle. Let's not talk about that right now. It is not only a common market, but also a community of values, but it cannot follow that we forget about the common market, the single market. Today, here in the European Parliament, no one in the world but the People's Party is talking about job creation. Today, no one in the European Parliament, other than the People's Party, talks about how the Common Economic Problems of the European Union can be solved. Or if a left-wing, liberal, green or communist MEP were to talk about economic issues, he would not, because, led by their own ideological biases, they come up with ideas that will destroy the competitiveness of the European Union's economy. They are doing so in a situation where the European Union gave 24-25% of the world's total economic output 20 years ago, and today that performance has fallen to 15%. So let's not be delirious, let's talk about the economy: job creation, job creation, job creation.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: "Madam President, the climate emergency is a race we are losing," said UN Secretary-General Guterres last weekend. This is something that more and more of us are sharing. This new European mandate and the Green Pact for Europe therefore sound like those of the last chance. But I cannot help but note that, behind the shocking sentences of the Commission or the Council and the fine declarations of intent, there is still no real act and, even worse, there is still no agreement on how to get these questions asked. I see that we are moving in a disorderly way and that we lack consistency. I would not want the stimulus package to hide the weakness of the multi-year fiscal framework at this stage. Yes, we need real means to put our public policies in place. Yes, the coronavirus crisis has shown how necessary it is to implement public policies. We need real resources of our own, now and in the future, to address our major political challenges. The planet is dying, biodiversity is dying, humanity is dying, we no longer have time for another failure.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: Before we proceed with the debates, I will open the first round of voting today. The dossiers on which we are now voting can be found on the agenda. The voting round is open from 10.30 a.m. with a little delay to 11.45 a.m. I declare the first round of voting open. You can vote until 11.45 a.m. The results of the first round of voting will be announced at 2.15 p.m.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: We are now continuing our joint debate on the statements of the European Council and the Commission on the conclusions of the special European Council of 1 and 2 October 2020 (2020/2787(RSP)) and - the statements by the Council and the Commission on the preparation of the European Council of 15 and 16 October 2020 (2020/2788(RSP)).

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: – Madam President, the images we have seen from Belarus were both horrific and inspiring. We have seen brutal repression but we’ve seen also Belarusian society that stood up for their rights. The struggle in Belarus is not over and Belarusians need our support now more than ever. The decision last week to impose sanctions was the correct one, but waiting 55 days was far too long and, of course, the main question is why the elephant in the room, Mr Lukashenko, is not on the list this time?  These actions are important, but the European Union must find additional ways how to support Belarusians in their day-to-day struggle towards freedom.

name: Jörg MEUTHEN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. In view of the results presented here today at last week's EU summit, we really need to talk about a summit, a summit of perplexity and denial of reality – so no surprise at all. Merkel, Macron and co. are already swearing about the distribution of a Corona vaccine, which does not yet exist. And the downturn in the single market is supposed to get their green all-purpose pill back on its feet – really? Do you seriously believe in this quackery yourself? Indeed, they seem willing to administer not only a very bitter medicine to the European patient, but above all one with absolutely fatal side effects for our economy. But anyone who now assumes that, if you clearly do not understand anything about the economy, you would at least use the summit to resolutely rein in the choleric would-be Sultan Erdogan, is wrong. Abolition of the Customs Union - nothing! Finally, mr Weber has already mentioned it – misrepresentation! Since you are so happy to use the word of solidarity, where is your real support for Greece and Cyprus, whose territorial integrity – and not least our EU external border – is threatened by the Turks? You wanted them, too. After all, your hands are tied after you have systematically become dependent on Ankara. You will now see, inaction, how, 100 years after the Armenian genocide, 30 years after the pogrom in Baku, today the Azerbaijani army, together with the Syrian jihadists, will once again kill Armenian Christians at the behest of the Turkish Government. It is simply shameful to make a fine appeal to both sides to stop the hostilities. A very clear positioning would be indicated. Unfortunately, the EU is and remains a toothless tiger in foreign policy, which no one takes seriously. You just can't, and that's sad.

name: Alexandra GEESE
text: – Madam President, I’m very happy that the Council also focused on the digital sector, which is absolutely crucial if we want to live in freedom and democracy in the future, because today, this way of living is involuntarily threatened by the business model of a few global tech companies. And what is that business model? It’s collecting huge amounts of data on citizens, creating detailed profiles and selling them to advertisers, and this has side effects. It promotes disinformation. It promotes hate in our society. It distorts competition and it reduces the revenue of our press. These enormous amounts of data, as well as the staggering profits, don’t allow for a level playing field for our European industry and threaten democracies globally. But the good news is that we now have the chance to change this with the new competition framework, with the digital services act. We can have a new start in Europe because, in Europe, what we want are digital technologies to implement the European green deals and make the lives of European citizens better.

name: Eugen JURZYCA
text: – Madam President, the recovery of the European Union after the pandemic should be all about using the reserves we already have in the European Union today, and we do not have to take out credit for them. Such a reserve is mainly the European market without unnecessary barriers. Already in 2017, a European Parliament study estimated that completing the single market would increase the annual performance of the European economy by more than €600 billion. That's almost the whole extra recovery plan every single year. For example, Member States have hundreds of regulated professions that create barriers to cross-border provision of services. I therefore consider it crucial that we fulfil our homework by further removing obstacles to cross-border entrepreneurship and the provision of services, which today limit the potential for our recovery and growth.

name: Chris MACMANUS
text: – Mr President, two weeks ago the British Parliament voted for a government bill giving British soldiers immunity for war crimes, including unlawful killing and torture. The British Government wear their contempt for what they would refer to as ‘foreign laws’, just as they wear their hostility to the EU, as a badge of honour. The evidence is in their flagrant violation of the Withdrawal Agreement and our Good Friday Agreement.  The European Council would do well to face up to the reality that Britain is not interested in being a friendly neighbour. They will seek to destroy jobs across the European Union, to drive down pay and conditions and environmental standards, both in Britain and in the EU. I urge the European Council to hold firm in rejecting British provocations, in asserting international law, and in defending the interests of Ireland and the EU.

name: Carles PUIGDEMONT I CASAMAJÓ
text: Madam President, the European Council has spoken of Turkey, China, Belarus and Nagorno-Karabakh. It was necessary, and it's really good. The world had to hear Europe's voice, even if it is a little timid, but we Europeans also want to hear Europe's voice when there are abuses and violations of fundamental rights within our borders. Is there nothing to say about a state that impeachs two consecutive presidents of a national minority for exclusively political reasons? Is there nothing to say about a prosecutor's office proposing a constitutional rehabilitation programme for political prisoners? Is there nothing to say about a state that condemns the country's largest university for demanding the release of political prisoners and defending freedom of expression? To be credible, to be influential elsewhere, the Council should also talk about all of this.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: – Madam President, the Council should take the European Union's own resources decision as soon as possible. Without that, Parliament cannot approve the financial framework. The recovery plan is not pooled debt, because no Member State puts its own money: it is European debt. But it's also not free money that comes in without states having to raise taxes or issue debt, even if many are going to find it free money. So, without knowing where the money to pay will come from, we cannot approve the financial framework. If we do not rather understand what we are doing, we can end up dismantling the European project so that the Member States are handing out the pieces. It is unacceptable that this Parliament does not control the expenditure of the recovery plan. It is unacceptable for European policies to be cut in the budget. It is unacceptable for the Commission to issue debt without us knowing when and how it will be paid. It is unacceptable that respect for the rule of law is not considered as a condition. It would be unacceptable for the European Union to make a Brexit itself. This Parliament must be prepared to oppose the next financial framework from construction to European deconstruction. It is unacceptable that we are having a debate with the Council here and the Council does not have any members present. It is a demonstration of what the Council thinks of this Parliament. It is completely unacceptable for the Council to consider us an irrelevant institution. And I demand that the Presidency either send a note of protest to the Council or immediately suspend this debate until the Council sits in place again.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: – Madam President, Maroš Šefčovič has brought the subject of Brexit to this debate and has done very well to stress here the importance of maintaining the unity of the European Union, the Council and Parliament at this crucial stage. I want to support the timely and firm initiative of the President of the Commission and Vice-President Šefčovič and to open infringement proceedings against the United Kingdom for failure to fulfil the duties of good faith in the implementation of the Withdrawal Agreement.  The Commission did the only thing it could and should do. On behalf of the socialist group I would also like to support the efforts of Mr Barnier's team to reach an agreement on the future relationship by the end of October. We want an agreement, but we demand a good agreement and there is an essential principle that we should remember: any agreement that gives the UK access to the European market with 0 tariffs and 0 quotas must also ensure 0 dumping, which means not allowing any setback in our environmental, social and labour protection standards. The end of October is even the deadline because this Parliament does not give up democratic scrutiny of any agreement.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I think we have just heard a passionate Charles Michel say here: 'we are going for a stronger Europe, less dependent, more influence'. I'll share that, of course. I am also pleased that he was able to reach an agreement in difficult circumstances. But let us be honest, ladies and gentlemen – and we have heard it here several times – we should actually say: too slow, too soft and not united enough.  Too slow. Two months after the uprisings in Belarus. And actually, about Hong Kong, how long have we been talking about that? But when will actions come? Too soft. Yes, sanctions, but without – a colleague called him the elephant in the room – Lukashenko on that list.  And not united enough, when you see that one country can block a lot. It's really clear to me, ladies and gentlemen. We need to make a fist. We must be able to play geopolitically, and then we must reform the Union. We need to get rid of that unanimity rule. I therefore call on the Council and the Commission to do so.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: Mr President, I would like to hold the European Council to account today. The European Commission has already proposed to the press a so-called migration pact from the European Union on 23 September. But the European Council, which represents the Member States, has accepted that Charles Michel and the German Presidency have kept this away from the agenda of the European summit on both 2 October and 15 October. The migration pact is nowhere to be seen. Moreover, in the European Parliament, too, the majority has rejected the migration pact from the plenary agenda. The fact that you all want to keep this pact out of your eye is absolutely not normal and is absolutely unacceptable. After all, migration is the top theme of choice for the citizens of the Member States you have to represent. Ladies and gentlemen, last Saturday, at a meeting of the Belgian Parliament, the new Belgian Government was installed in this Chamber, after the previous one had fallen at the end of October 2018 – almost two years ago – on the United Nations migration pact, which, by the way, was signed by Charles Michel on behalf of Belgium against the wishes of his own government. That was why the government fell. What the population thinks about this migration pact is now known. The Flemish Interest, my party, which opposed it, came back here in the European Parliament with three times as many seats as before.  Your migration pact is along the same globalist line: verbally embracing the so-called return of foreigners, but in practice juggling the concept of 'solidarity' until the flow of migrants to our Member States becomes a real distribution of migrants with a compulsion on the Member States to take in your migrants – if necessary against their will – on the basis of an asylum concept that is completely outdated and abused.  I therefore call on the Council to put the opposition to this Migration Pact of the European Union immediately on the agenda. Enough is enough. The people of the EU want more but less immigration, no more but less open borders. Stop, in the word of Viktor Orbán, this globalist madness.

name: Tineke STRIK
text: – Madam President, it was a good step of the European Council to finally break its deadlock and agree on sanctions for 40 individuals of the Lukashenko regime, responsible for manipulating the elections and oppressing its citizens. But why not include the person most responsible, Mr Lukashenko himself? This cannot be explained to the Belarusian people. How long do we accept his regime violently cracking down on peaceful protests, and him flirting with Putin, before the Council realises that we are long past a political solution with Mr Lukashenko?  And this is why calling for an inclusive national dialogue is important, but not enough. If we want to ensure new and fair elections, much more pressure from the EU is necessary, and freedom of speech, association and media is vital to preserve democratic rights in Belarus. Apart from an economic plan, we call for substantial support of civil society and the independent media. This is the time for the EU to show some of the courage that the people in Belarus show us every day.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Decisions on sanctions against representatives of the Belarusian regime are good news from the Council summit. The Union must have a firm and coherent position on this issue. It is only through political and economic pressure that we can effectively stop the violence, which for Lukashenko is the only means of maintaining his power today. The conclusions of the Council concluded that, in addition to declarations and gestures of solidarity, concrete support is needed for democratic processes of change in Belarus.  Poland has since the beginning of this crisis called for the establishment of an economic plan for a democratic Belarus, which will include financial support, scholarship programmes and facilitation of border crossings. I congratulate Prime Minister Morawiecki on his effectiveness in pushing this idea, and I hope that the Commission will effectively implement this plan.  The last few months should also convince many Member States to revise their relations with Russia, which is the main source of instability and conflict in our immediate neighbourhood. More than ever, abandoning the Nord Stream 2 project seems to be a necessary step today.

name: Özlem DEMIREL
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The mountain cracked and bore a mouse. This is how the Council meeting can be summarised with regard to Turkey. The EU's relations with Turkey are being redefined, it said. But then: Germany prevailed. Sanctions for Belarus - Friendship for Erdogan. This is in a week when dozens of opposition activists and HDP members have been arrested. In a letter, Erdogan has written to the Council listing his demands.  He has offered to move moria de facto to Turkey. The Council has gratefully accepted. The EU buys time – but gives Erdogan carte blanche to do so. He has used Islamists not only in Syria against the Kurds, but also, presumably, in Libya and currently in Nagorno-Karabakh. The truth is that you always like to talk about the EU's union of values. But who is to believe you at the moment? Has the EU really deserved the Nobel Peace Prize in this way, ladies and gentlemen?

name: François-Xavier BELLAMY
text: Madam President, the Council has finally finally spoken of Turkey, but once again what a disarming passivity! It is time to act now, to act urgently because Turkey is now posing a threat to its neighbours, but also to Europe as a whole and to the world around us. In fact, last February, Mr Erdogan organised a migration crisis on the border of the European Union, it violates the sovereignty of Cyprus, it threatens the territorial waters, the airspace of our Greek friends systematically, he invades territories in Syria to oppress the Kurds, he finances and recruits jihadists dreaming of the new leader of an International Islamist and , today, it is with Azerbaijan, Armenia that he is attacking. To Armenia already martyr of a genocide, because Armenia is Christian, today still denied by all Turkish propaganda. It's time to finally react. What do we do? The Council has still not put an end to Turkey's accession to the European Union, which was an aberration and is now an absolute moral scandal. It puts the aggressors and the assaulted on the same level by simply calling for an end to hostilities. How do we think we are going to set Mr Erdogan back with such a vocabulary? Finally, there is no mention of sanctions against Turkey at any one point. Dear friends, we talk a lot about the rule of law here. Turkey is trying to show that violence can prevail over international law, will we still agree to this collective cowardice for a long time? That is the question that is being asked of all of us today.

name: Tonino PICULA
