text: – Dear Chairman, the conclusions call for lowering tensions and supporting dialogue in the case of the Eastern Mediterranean where the European Union must defend its sovereignty and the intensified conflicts in Nagorno Karabakh.  I welcome the agreement on measures for 40 Belarusian officials. However, this list is not complete without self-styled President Lukashnek. We owe it to citizens who suffer regime repression and are persistent in protests. This proves that qualified sanctions decision-making is necessary in increasingly tense foreign policy opportunities in the neighbourhood and globally.  China's announcement of reaching carbon neutrality by 2060 is encouraging, with a clear reminder of the unacceptable human rights situation and the need to level the rules of competition. The Council's political agreement is not the final of the multiannual financial framework. The European Parliament has clearly communicated its mandate as regards amounts and priorities. Parliament must be respected as a co-legislature, the rule of law as a precondition for withdrawing funds with their own means of recovery is in the interest of citizens who have given us direct legitimacy.

name: Nathalie LOISEAU
text: Madam President, strategic autonomy, European sovereignty, how many times has a France allegedly been criticised alone. Only to attach itself to concepts that it alone would defend in Europe. Well, Madam President, I am pleased to see, on reading the council's conclusions on 1 and 2 October, that these ideas of strategic autonomy and European sovereignty are now part of the vocabulary of the European Union.  Whether it is thinking about our digital future, our industrial policy or facing the geopolitical crises of today's world, we can no longer simply remain a market open to all winds, nor refuse to weigh as a peaceful but determined power. We can protect ourselves without becoming protectionists, we must defend ourselves without becoming aggressive. Faced with China's systematic rivalry, in the face of Turkey's systematic military adventurism, in view of Russia's imperialist nostalgia and the indifferent passivity of the United States, we must assert ourselves, defend our interests, be proud of our values not only in words, but also in deeds.

name: Jaak MADISON
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Van Rompuy, for his excellent work I have listened carefully to the debate and it has been really interesting. I would like to mention the issues concerning the economy, unemployment and green turnaround. Isn't it funny that we are constantly talking about rising unemployment, economic problems and an unprecedented crisis, but we are solving the economic problems with frantic borrowing money, EUR 750 billion, which we know nothing about? We are planning new pan-European taxes to finance a loan that no one can do anything about, and we are not really fixing the fundamental problems in the economy. We are talking about a global decline in competitiveness against China, Russia and the United States, and at the same time we think that we are solving our economic problems globally with a frantic loan package in order to finance the green revolution. The green turn to supposedly save the world by going along with the climate policy craze that is pure fanaticism. And at the same time, to cover energy shortages, we are importing cheap gas, for example, from Russia to Germany through Nord Stream 2, which is very green and globally life-saving for the world. It's called ambivalence and hypocrisy! We have destroyed our economic competitiveness through over-regulation, bureaucracy and centralisation, and now we are trying to solve the main problems with the long-term emergence of new problems. No new Pan-European tax solves economic problems, it is basic basic knowledge that you may not understand, unfortunately, because what is wrong with sitting on a good enough salary with taxpayers' money?

name: Jorge BUXADÉ VILLALBA
text: – Madam President, in this Parliament we are fed up with seeing the consensus progre treating full-minded partners of the European Union worse than openly hostile nations, such as Turkey or China.  Here are the worst accusations against our Polish, Hungarian, Greek or Bulgarian friends, while the Chinese communist regime is applauded or, on the contrary, it is intended to make peace with Turkey, surrendering every day.  Turkey's attacks on our sovereignty, our borders, our culture, are not mere provocations, as has been said this weekend, are genuine hostile acts of a regime that despises us, as we continue to negotiate its entry into the European Union and bags of money continue to be sent from Brussels; money that our entrepreneurs and workers now need.  Ladies and gentlemen of the Commission and of the Council, there are no more threats to those who do not submit to their ideological agenda, to the point of saying that there are countries that will be left out of the recovery fund because they do not meet their demands, while billions are launched to third countries where human rights are systematically violated. I think the time has come: Europeans are demanding that we put our feet on the ground and come down from their lay paradise.

name: Sira REGO
text: – Madam President, have you ever had that dream in which you have to run, but is there something that slows you down and you cannot move forward? Well, honestly, I am the feeling I have with certain debates in the European Parliament, for example the climate targets, which will be discussed next week in the Council. On the one hand, we are pushing for a reasonable climate law, but on the other hand we are in favour of a Fair Transition Fund, which is fair and has little transition to a low-emission energy model, because it continues to dopando gas. Or we continue to sign free trade agreements that make the oranges we eat, which are from South Africa, more than exceed that of the total production of my homeland, Valencia. That's not to mention the shattering of farmers' rights or abuses by arbitration courts. I have a very specific doubt that I would have loved to be able to formulate to the Council directly, but, as my colleague said, they are not here. But well, still, I'm going to formulate it. It's simple: what glue are you going to use to make climate targets compatible with the unfair transition fund or with the escalation of free trade agreements? And, above all, how are they going to make what they tell us no longer look like an advertising brochure?

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: Madam President, the Summit has given time, space and direction to deal with Greek-Turkish disputes with specific positions. It called for the resumption of negotiations under the auspices of the UN, with the sole purpose of demarcating maritime zones. It strongly condemned the violations of Cyprus' sovereign rights and explicitly stated that in any unilateral actions and challenges of Turkey the European Union will use all the tools given to it by the Treaties. But, ladies and gentlemen, let us be realistic. Even before the exploratory contacts begin, Turkey is already torpedoing the dialogue. He is trying to change the agenda of the talks, adding to the demilitarisation of the islands, while again talking about grey areas. Only yesterday, in the presence of NATO Secretary General Stoltenberg, Foreign Minister Mevlüt Çavuşoğlu called Cyprus, Israel and Syria criminal states, and said that tension in the Eastern Mediterranean was caused, if possible, by Greece sending warships to the Turkish continental shelf. No one can separate us, President von der Leyen said. But if we are to be united and strong, colleagues, we must have a voice and a policy against our neighbor when she threatens our Union. President Erdoğan is not intimidated by general references in response to his revisionism. A specific description of sanctions against Turkey is required, as well as a definition of how they are to be applied immediately to the first act of aggression against a Member State of the European Union in violation of international law.

name: Margarida MARQUES
text: – Madam President, Vice-President Šefčovič, there is an "agenda" and a 'no agenda' of the next European Council. The process of ratification by national parliaments, necessary for the establishment of the Recovery Fund, is blocked in the Council. The rule of law mechanism is being an instrument of blackmail in the Council. Europeans expect the European response to the crisis. In July, they thought they were going to have it, but in fact, it's blocked in the Council and increasingly behind schedule. As a member of the negotiating team, I would like to appeal to the Council to take advantage of this European Council to do its work with European leaders on the 'no agenda' to end this block, and citizens, families, businesses, states can benefit from the European response to the crisis. It is not enough to say that this time we have achieved an innovative European response. It is urgent and urgent for it to reach out to citizens and to feel that the EU protects them... (The President withdraws his floor to the speaker)

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the pandemic has shown European vulnerability, endangering the health and lives of millions of citizens. Now we have to show that we have learned our lesson and not just in the health sector. The challenge is to ensure a resilient digital environment that protects citizens' security, their privacy, data, production system and intellectual property, as well as being able to deal with cyber threats. For too many years, The Member States have shown little ambition – as was the case with the NIS Directive, the European Cybersecurity Act or the management and deployment of 5G. Exploiting the opportunities of the digital revolution, while minimising its risks, has become a priority of the new Commission. In this direction, we welcome the decision to allocate at least 20 % of the Recovery Fund's resources to digital transformation. It is certainly a question of keeping our production system competitive, even the more traditional one of small and medium-sized enterprises, but at the same time guaranteeing freedom and technological sovereignty, which are essential prerequisites for our democracy.

name: Emmanouil FRAGKOS
text: Mr President, today is an important day for me. On a day when I have the opportunity to stand up to the President-in-Office of the Council and express to him not only my opinion, but also the opinion of the vast majority of Greeks on the attitude of the European Union towards Greece, Cyprus and Turkey. The view of the Greeks, Mr Michel, who see daily Turkish warplanes violating Greek airspace, Turkish frigates sailing illegally in Greek waters and Turkish research ships defiantly greying Greek areas. And at a time when all this is happening, and we are waiting for sanctions to be imposed on Turkey, we see the European Union equating the perpetrator with the victim and calling for dialogue. At the same time, of course, the Council, taking a provocative stance of two measures and two stations, is imposing immediate sanctions on Belarus.  In conclusion, I would like to tell you that I fully understand the economic and historical relations between Germany and Turkey, but I find it unacceptable that these relations not only affect Union policy, but also jeopardise the security of the Member States. We call for immediate sanctions on Turkey.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Mr President, as we look to the year 2020, we have to admit that this is an atypical year and a very challenging year. And as we look to this year, we have to keep in mind two things: firstly, we delivered this year for the people of Europe, and secondly, people outside of the EU, outside of our 27 Member States, are looking up towards the European Union, towards the EU institutions, and they have high expectations of us. Firstly, on what we delivered, one thing is clear: people expect results from the European Union. We got our act together during the crisis, we provided concrete results and now we are finalising negotiations to provide the biggest financial support to Member States, which are in need of EUR 750 billion. This is important, this is not small, this is concrete, and this will help overcome the crisis and make the lives of people better within the Member States of the European Union. It will modernise the economies, it will make them greener, more digital, more innovative, it will provide for stable and well-paid jobs in the future.  Outside of the European Union, people are looking towards us with expectations and I want to say one thing very clearly: in order to live in stability and safety within the European Union, we need to be surrounded by countries which are safe and stable, and for stability, rules are essential and values are essential. This is why we need to stand up for the defence of European values also in the countries in our immediate neighbourhood and we should use all the tools that we have available to defend EU values in countries which are our immediate neighbours.

name: Javier MORENO SÁNCHEZ
text: – Mr President, two messages to the Council, which, by the way, is still missing.  Time is pressing, the pandemic continues to hit and citizens and businesses need funds to arrive now, so we have to reach an agreement as soon as possible. Remember that Parliament is a co-legislator; negotiate, don't try to impose your agreement. We cannot respond to the COVID-19 crisis with an institutional blockade.  Tomorrow, the Spanish Government will present an ambitious recovery plan to overcome this crisis, modernize society and restore hope to our young people; a plan with absorption capacity and effective and transparent management, in line with our traditional compliance with European standards. Fair digital and ecological transition, social and territorial cohesion and gender equality will be its main axes. Second point: relations with Africa. While we are here debating, many migrants continue to be at risk on the high seas. These States must put the resources to ensure maritime rescue and rescue. Let us show our citizens and our African neighbours that the Migration Pact is really a fresh start.

name: Claudia GAMON
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Infection rates are rising all over Europe. What is surprising to the citizens of the Union is that the governments of the Member States failed to agree on a common strategy during the summer break. The result is a smorgasbord of different rules, where even the most resourceful no longer know each other at all. Do you need a negative test? Do you still have to be isolated? Is it two, four, five, ten, fourteen days? Who put whom on the red list and why? I believe that the Heads of State or Government of the European Union do not realise here that the reality of life for so many people is now clearly European. We live, we work across borders; there are livelihoods in border regions that depend on borders remaining open. I call on the Council to finally get down to work here for the citizens of the Union and to create uniform rules, otherwise it is the fundamental freedoms of the Union that will be the next victims of this pandemic.

name: Geert BOURGEOIS
text: Mr President, we largely agree with the Council's economic conclusions: to commit to open strategic autonomy, which I advocated on 10 March, but no naïve belief in self-sufficiency, no protectionism. Well: to protect without protectionism. Finally, we are also seeing a great commitment to digitisation, colleagues, where we are lagging behind worldwide. It is good, Commissioner, that 20% of the recovery plan is going towards digitisation.  But, had Charles Michel still been here, I would have told him: add the deed to the word and do not detract from the Committee on Research and Development's budget proposal. Finally make a budget for the 21st century. The world is not waiting for us.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Mr President, the corona epidemic is hitting the most vulnerable in the labour market the hardest. Platform workers like the Uber drivers immediately lost their jobs and their income, and the meal delivery drivers are still driving around uninsured. Everyone has become an expert when it comes to teleworking, but it still does work. Our companies and our society are not yet ready for that digital society. What do you do when the work emails and apps keep coming in early in the morning, late at night and all weekend?  The European platform summit has been postponed because of the corona crisis, and that is a shame. But what is really incomprehensible is that there is no plan at European level for fair work in that digital economy. As far as I am concerned, the law on digital services is not enough. Europe needs to be prepared for that digital economy, and that means that platform workers deserve fair contracts, people need to get support when working from home, and that everywhere in Europe the right to be offline is ... (the president interrupts the speaker)

name: Leszek MILLER
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We welcomed the fact that the European Council has reached a final agreement on sanctions for those responsible for the use of violence and repression against protesters in Belarus. However, the process of reaching this agreement and the endless negotiations have shown how inefficient the Union's governance system is, because even on the most obvious issues it requires unanimity among all the members of the Council.  In line with the leaders' agenda presented by the middle of next year, the European Council plans to take a number of strategic actions in the area of foreign policy. These include our relations with China, Africa, Russia and, finally, the United Kingdom. In this context, I am convinced that the Council should make effective efforts as soon as possible to refrain from applying the non-functional principle of unanimity in favour of the application of the Community method in the field of foreign and security policy. To this end, it is not necessary to amend the Treaties – only the political will of the Member States is sufficient. We cannot pursue an ineffective and diluted foreign policy simply because key decisions can be blocked by the vested interests of a country. The Union cannot be a colossus on clay legs. We have legitimate aspirations, and as has turned out, for example, in the case of Belarus, the lack of our ability to act effectively has been exposed by one smaller satrap.

name: Elisabetta GUALMINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the rule of law not only protects the democracy of the European Union but also defends the budget of the European institutions and therefore the way in which they operate, the way they operate. We need much stricter conditionalities than those laid down by the Council, which minimise the concept of the rule of law and even call for a qualified majority on the part of the Member States to envisage a possible blockade. The European Union is not an ATM, nor is it a neutral institution that distributes money outside all rules: Hungary had around EUR 47 billion from the European Union between 2013 and 2020, a third of its annual GDP; Poland had EUR 207 billion. That is not acceptable! What would it be, what would remain of the European Union without democracy? What would remain of the European Union without a transparent and solid budget? What would remain of the European Union without justice if some States have contempt for democracy and silence parliaments? We need strict conditionality!

name: Robert BIEDROŃ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Belarus has been ruled by Europe's last dictator for 26 years. For the last three months, the people of Belarus have been taking to the streets to demand something that we in the European Union take for granted – freedom, democracy and the rule of law. People die in Belarus on lukashenko's orders, people are forced to flee Belarus, in prisons in Belarus women are raped on lukashenko's orders. What is the European Union doing about this? It imposes sanctions on 40 people. Let me remind you: in 2016, on Belarus, we imposed sanctions on 170 people in a much less serious situation. Today, from left to right, there are voices in this Chamber that President Lukashenko himself is not subject to sanctions. If the European Union wants to maintain credibility, these sanctions must be imposed as a matter of urgency on Lukashenko himself.

name: Robert BIEDROŃ
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would also like to thank wholeheartedly the honourable Members of this House, because they made this debate very rich and covered a lot of topics about the last European Council and the next one. I will try to cover as much as I can within the time limit. First, I would like to underline the fact that President Michel covered quite extensively the issues linked with foreign policy, but I feel that it was very much present in a lot of interventions, so let me add a couple of points on behalf of the Commission. First and foremost, I would like to underline the unity which was achieved in this European Council: the unity which, as many of you said, took us quite some time. Therefore, I would also refer all of you to the clear statement of our President that, clearly, if comes to human rights and to sanction regimes, we would prefer in the Commission to use the passerelle clause and to move to the qualified majority vote, because I believe that in this case we would be much more action-based, more operational, and it would allow us to be much faster in adopting sometimes very difficult decisions. I would also like to do one more thing. I would like to send a very clear and positive message to the people of Greece and Cyprus: we have your back. You have our unconditional solidarity and strong support, and we stand united in defence of your sovereignty and of your legitimate sovereign rights. I think that it’s also important to underscore the fact that the EU leaders have made it very clear, in the case of renewed unilateral actions by Turkey, that we are ready to use our restrictive measures. That message was also very clear. But we want to reach a solution through dialogue. Many of you – I think the last was Mr Biedroń – made reference to Belarus. I think here our unity was simply a moral obligation, and therefore I am so glad that today the European Union is united at the side of the people of Belarus and that we would fight and push for the right of all Belarus citizens to elect their President through new elections, which would be free and fair. This is the European Union’s position. Therefore, I would underline once again the gradual approach in the case of sanctions against the concrete persons of Belarus. The leaders of the European Parliament – Mr Weber, Mr Cioloş, Ms García Pérez – have made very important reference to the fact that the EU must remain a global player, that we have to make sure that the European Union is a geopolitical union as well, and that we have to reduce the dependencies on third countries – as was underlined by Mr Lamberts – and that what is very important is the jobs, jobs, jobs in this crisis. I want to tell you that we in the Commission hear you loud and clear, and all our actions are aimed at making sure that the European Union remains a global economic superpower, a green and digital transformation leader and a social model for the rest of the world, and that we are the first major economy to put competitive sustainability at the core of our policies. We are working very hard to achieve what Madame Loiseau described so well as the strategic autonomy of our economy. To achieve that, we are strengthening the pillar of social rights. Very soon we will come to present to you our proposals on the minimum wage and on pay transparency. We are going to use the Just Transition Mechanism in a very efficient way to make sure that nobody is left behind in this very demanding twin green and digital transition. We will introduce the concrete steps in applying the new industrial strategy, where we will use fully the convening power of the Commission and the economic strength of the European single market. I am sure you have noticed, because many of you are working on very concrete projects linked with the forging of our new European alliances to make sure that the EU will be the leader in all key technologies of the 21st century. With Mr Ertug we are working together on the European Battery Alliance and, within two and a half years, we have completely reversed the table where Europe is now the number one direction of foreign investment when it comes to batteries. We are investing three times more in Europe in the battery sectors than in China, and we want to achieve the same result when it comes to hydrogen, quantum computing and critical raw materials. We are also very conscious that, to achieve all that, we need to cut red tape and reduce the administrative burden. We will come very soon to you with very concrete proposals in that direction. Ms Geese referred to the importance of a state aid review and Mr Jurzyca underlined the importance of the single market. We are working very hard to remove as many obstacles as possible on the single market to re-energise and revive it, and we are currently undergoing the most in-depth review of the state aid rules in the history of the Commission. Very soon, in the middle of October, we will start to receive the first recovery plans from our Member States, and we clearly want these plans to be focused on people, on their jobs and on the twin transition. We want 20% of the financial support to be used for digital means, 37% for green goal deals, and we want to use this unique chance for every single Member State to leap forward, to build new economies, not to restore the old ones. And I believe that, with the help of all of you, we will achieve that. I would like to reassure Ms Marques and Mr Mureşan that the Commission will do all in its power to be the best facilitator to achieve the speedy agreement on the next multiannual financial perspective and the Next Generation EU Mechanism. Last, a word to Mr Silva Pereira on Brexit. I really would like to thank this House for the strong support which we feel in every step of the negotiations and in every round of talks. I would like to reassure you that Michel Barnier on his track and I myself on the Withdrawal Agreement implementation will negotiate in good faith until the very last minute possible, despite very difficult circumstances.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The joint debate is closed. I would like to inform Members that interpreters from Malta are only available to a limited extent due to travel restrictions and that, therefore, this morning only passive interpretation from Maltese to other languages is guaranteed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – The ongoing COVID pandemic is a major concern among EU citizens. To date, we do not have clarity as to what the EU plan is in the fight against this pandemic and the consequences it has caused. We do not have a European response to how we will continue to live and by what means will try to manage this crisis. Member States have so far applied different requirements and restrictions in relation to the COVID pandemic, which is very divisive, creating a great deal of uncertainty and instability for both people and businesses in the EU. internal market. As a result of this pandemic, we have already lost over five million jobs in the EU. According to the International Labour Organisation, over 12 million jobs in the EU could be lost this year. These are huge numbers, and the EU's response must be swift, coordinated and effective. It is time to ensure the proper functioning of the internal market and to establish clear measures and rules at EU level so that our people and businesses have more clarity.

name: Domènec RUIZ DEVESA
text: in writing. Discussion topics within the European Council on 1 and 2 October have been a number of topics.  Foreign policy addressed the fight for democracy in Belarus, relations with Turkey, the poisoning of Alexei Navalny, as well as EU-China relations.  Domestic policy discussed ways to strengthen the single market and how to develop a more ambitious industrial policy by making EU industries more globally competitive and driving digital transformation.  The Spanish Socialist Delegation requested the Intermediation Council to obtain fair and free elections in Belarus. In the case of Turkey, it must respect international law by returning to dialogue and cooperation. We defend strategic autonomy that will enable us to rebuild our industrial and digital independence in the face of future crises, ensuring social cohesion, building a single market that meets the objectives of the European Green Pact and ensuring a just digital transition that leaves no one behind.  That is why we need a strengthened Budget from the European Union for the next seven years and the recovery plan to be available as soon as possible.

name: Edina TÓTH
text: Writing. – I welcome the conclusions of the European Council of 1 and 2 October, including digital objectives. Over the past few years, projects that have increasingly demonstrated the capabilities and challenges of rapidly evolving artificial intelligence have been following each other. Today, the biggest problem is hidden in the nature of AI, which is based on intelligent processing of big data. The EU data strategy, published in February, sets ambitious targets for the creation and interconnection of European data spaces. Data are the basis for new technologies, which are of decisive importance in all areas of the economy. The aim is to provide as much data as possible and of the highest quality, which can be used by the public and private sectors. Only in the first half of 2021 will the European Commission present a planned EU legislative act involving a data strategy. I believe that a number of concepts need to be clarified during this period, while at the same time prioritising the protection of sensitive and valuable national datasets and personal data, such as health data that constitutes sensitive data.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. – The European Council of 1 and 2 October was marked by a relevant effort to strengthen the coordination of key policies for the Union's response to the challenges posed by the pandemic and the dynamics of geopolitical change. I welcome the effort made to permanently increase the overall response to the pandemic and, in particular, the need to ensure the smooth functioning of the single market and to adapt industrial policy to the challenges of recovery and transformation.  I also highlight the ambitious approach to an articulated digitisation strategy, which has been decided to affect at least 20% of the resources of the recovery and resilience mechanism. The Council's agenda for 15 and 16 October pursues this line, both in the affirmation of a negotiating position in the framework of BREXIT that defends the principles of good negotiation, and in the planned approach to greater coordination of the response to the challenges of climate change. Good intergovernmental coordination is essential for all necessary institutional pillars to align, approve and implement as soon as possible the new generation funds (REACT EU, PRR and MFF) that are decisive for the EU's health, economic and social consistency in the face of the recovery and modernisation challenges it faces.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Petri Sarvamaa on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development on the subject of "European Forestry Strategy - Future Action" (A9-0154/2020) (2019/2157 (INI)). I would point out to Members that there are no spontaneous speeches and no blue cards accepted in all the debates in this part-session.

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, first, just a couple of words to set the stage. We already have a biodiversity strategy from the Commission. Now, here today we are talking about the EU forest strategy. Having said that, I would now like to explain to this Chamber how a balanced forest strategy should and could be built for us.  Forests and the forest-based sector have a crucial role to play in achieving the Union’s climate, environmental and biodiversity goals, namely within the Green Deal. The enhancement of biodiversity, the fight against climate change and the transitions to a circular bioeconomy and to a fossil-free society will never be possible without multifunctional, healthy, and sustainably managed forests. The Commission will publish its new forest strategy during the first quarter of 2021. The previous strategy was published in 2013, so a new one is now needed for the post-2020 period.  We need an ambitious and self-standing EU forest strategy. It should highlight a balanced approach between the economic, ecological and social sustainability of forests to ensure the continuity of the multifunctional role of forests in the European Union. The new EU forest strategy should act as an effective coordination tool between the various EU forest-related policies, taking into account the whole forest-based value chain. Forests and the forest-based value chain offer crucial climate benefits, such as the promotion of carbon sequestration, the storage of carbon in wood-based products, and the substitution of fossil-based raw materials and energy. In addition, it is crucial to ensure appropriate measures to prevent natural disasters such as bark beetle epidemics, droughts and forest fires.  The own initiative report to be voted on today and tomorrow is a balanced one, and the positions of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI) and the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE) were taken into account in the negotiations. The report addresses the importance of enhancing forest biodiversity; just to mention, the word ‘biodiversity’ is mentioned 39 times in this report. The report points out that healthy and resilient forests are a precondition for the general well-being of our forests, as well as for their economic and social sustainability. It also addresses afforestation and reforestation as suitable tools in enhancing forest cover.  The report calls for the protection of primary forests. Yes indeed, it does, contrary to some of the claims that the members of this Chamber have received. And it calls on the Commission to introduce a definition for old-growth forests. It also emphasises the important role of sustainable forest management and bioeconomy at a time when forests are playing a key role in offering sustainable solutions to the challenges of our time. Lastly, the report notes that the jobs within the sector are dependent on resilient and well-managed forest ecosystems in the long term.

name: Jessica POLFJÄRD
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the COMMITTEE ENVI. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr For me, the forest and forestry industry are for climate benefit, but also for the hopefulness, which is usually so very often lacking in the climate and environmental debate. For it is not only that forests absorb carbon dioxide, but it also plays a key role in reducing emissions, by replacing fossil-based materials and products with bio-based ones.  We must protect and develop this. I am therefore pleased that the report is strongly in favour of the bio-based circular economy. Political ambition matters, but it is through new technologies and innovation that we can reduce our emissions in the future. That is why we need more confidence in the innovation and ingenuity of people and businesses. Because that is the only way we can succeed in reducing our emissions and achieving our climate targets.

name: Janusz WOJCIECHOWSKI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President. Forests occupy about 45% of the European Union’s territory. Forestry is a place of work: the wood-based industry employs 2.5 million people; about 500 000 European foresters work directly in the forest. The forest is a place for rest, recreation and contact with nature for almost 500 million European citizens, because everybody has some contact with forests.  The gross value added from forestry directly is EUR 26.5 billion, and about EUR 142 billion from the wood-based sector. This is a very important sector. Of course, the forest plays a very important role in the protection of biodiversity, climate protection, water management, air protection, etc.  I hope this own initiative report will be adopted by the European Parliament, because it will be very helpful and inspiring for the forest strategy being prepared by the Commission. This strategy will be published in the first quarter of 2021. The main direction of this strategy is defined in the Green Deal Communication, which mentioned that, building on the 23rd biodiversity strategy, the Commission would prepare a new forest strategy covering the whole forest cycle and promoting the many services that forests provide. The biodiversity strategy also mentioned that the EU must increase the quantity, quality and resilience of its forest, notably against fires, droughts, pests and diseases, and other threats likely to increase with climate change.  There is a strong link between forestry and agriculture and the farm to fork strategy. Agroforestry was listed as a potential eco-scheme – a very important part of the first pillar of the common agricultural policy – and the Commission will propose agroforestry as a potential eco-scheme in the recommendation to the Member States for their national strategic plans.  As President von der Leyen stated in her recent State of the Union speech, our current levels of consumption of raw materials, energy, water, food and land use are not sustainable. We need to change how we treat nature, how we produce and consume. Securing the health and resilience of existing and new forests, including under novel climatic conditions in the future, is crucial for their effective support to all the environmental, social and economic functions and services that forests provide to our society. This is why forests are an integral part of the European Green Deal and its EU biodiversity strategy 2030, which reiterates that forests are hugely important for biodiversity, climate and water regulation, the provision of food, medicines and materials, carbon sequestration and storage, soil stabilisation and the purification of air and water. They are also a natural home for recreation and learning about nature, while culture and heritage are preserved. With lively rural areas and wealthy rural populations, they offer opportunities for people and the planet.  Against the wider context that I outlined above, the EU forest strategy will reflect the importance of forests for achieving the different objectives and priorities of the European Green Deal. It will require a holistic approach carried out for, on the one hand, sustainable forest management that improves both their quantity and quality and, on the other hand, the multifunctional role of forests for the economic sector and communities that depend on them.  Key objectives of the new EU forest strategy will be effective re- and afforestation, as well as forest preservation and restoration in Europe. Furthermore, the aim is to help increase absorption of CO2, reduce the incidence and extent of forest fires and other climate-related pressures, and promote the circular bioeconomy in full respect of ecological principles favourable to biodiversity.  The strategy will need the right balance and synergies between the different socioeconomic interests related to forests and the need to increase our forest protection and restoration efforts to achieve our climate and biodiversity goals.  The forest strategy will need to have a strong protection and restoration dimension in strong cooperation with foresters and local communities. In line with the biodiversity strategy, the last remaining primary and old growth forests in the EU need to be protected. An inclusive process has already started, involving Member States and all stakeholders, to achieve that. In addition, some parts of the new protected areas under the regular protection regime will probably also need to include forests.  The upcoming forest strategy will also include a roadmap for planting at least three billion additional trees – maybe more – in the EU by 2030, in full respect of ecological principles. This was a key commitment in the biodiversity strategy to deliver on Green Deal objectives and thus contribute to both climate mitigation and adaptation and revert biodiversity loss. In parallel, the EU forest strategy will have to have a strong economic dimension. It has to lay the foundations for innovation and the promotion of new products, and to replace the intensive fossil-based materials and effectively contribute to a new low carbon society. As an example, President von der Leyen referred in her State of the Union speech to turning the construction sector from a carbon source to a carbon sink by applying organic building materials like wood. Moreover, under the CAP, the EU will also increasingly have to help to ensure that forestry in the EU, together with agriculture, is socially, economically and environmentally sustainable, supporting and strengthening the benefits that forestry brings to European society and providing sustainable economic rewards for farmers, forest managers and the EU as a whole. Overall, let me conclude, the new EU forest strategy will aim to build sustainable forest management and, aligned with relevant EU international commitments, the strategy’s principles and objectives should also help inform EU policy relevant to forests and the forest sector.  It is essential to ensure consistency on EU forest-related policies and the action on internal forests. We will take the European Parliament’s resolution fully into account when developing the upcoming forest strategy, as well as the recently adopted resolution on the Commission’s communication on stepping up action to protect the world’s forests, which we welcome.  The Commission looks forward to working closely together with the European Parliament on the future strategy.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The forest is fantastic, and it's nice that forests are hot on the political agenda. It is so clear that it offers us recreation, it gives us hunting opportunities and it offers great opportunity to preserve biodiversity, to build more climate-smart and to have reasonable carbon sinks that help us in the major climate challenges. In this, we will have a balance going forward that means that none of these factors will dominate the others.  It is also important that we constantly show responsibility and see that the forest looks very, very different. Parts of Europe have deforested themselves for centuries or millennia ago, while in Sweden we now plant two new ones in Sweden. This means that over the last 100 years we have more than doubled our forest mass in Sweden, while preserving more of the forest for biodiversity values and also getting more out of forest materials, which allows us to replace fossil-based materials in both constructions and the chemical industry. Here we have an opportunity for the future, and it is important to make sure that we do not put the hook to ourselves.

name: Herbert DORFMANN
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Forests fulfil many functions in Europe: they produce wood, they absorb CO2, they emit oxygen, they are recreational areas, they are an experience area, and they protect people from the forces of nature and from avalanches. The latter applies in particular to forests in the mountains and in the alpine region, and the European Union's forestry strategy should also take particular care of these forests. There, the already difficult economic situation of the forest and wood is even more complicated: the harvest is expensive and the transport routes often long. Nevertheless, these forests should and must also be managed. Only if they are rejuvenated regularly can they fulfil this protective function. In addition, these forests often produce high-quality wood, and these forests are also important energy suppliers. Innovative cycles, local cycles, have often been created, which contribute to the replacement of imported oil, gas, concrete, plastic or steel with domestic wood. In these Alpine regions, we also have functioning forest services that ensure sustainability. Nor do we need to present ourselves here in Brussels as great teachers and create new rules. Instead, we should use our capabilities – the CAP, the Structural Funds, Horizon – to promote innovative ideas and projects on the ground, thereby also making local timber use interesting.

name: Carmen AVRAM
text: , on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, unlike all other strategies of the ecological pact - Farm to Fork, biodiversity, fair transition and so on - the first forest strategy since the activation of the green revolution costs nothing. Neither the Union nor the Member States. Or, if you will, it costs goodwill, responsibility and understanding the times we live in. That is why, as the shadow rapporteur of the S&D, I wanted, fought and, together with the other shadow rapporteurs and rapporteurs, i.e. reached a balanced, viable and in line with the ambitions of the European Union. In this new strategy for forests there is a combination for the first time of those elements that can lead Europe towards a global model of good practice in the human-nature relationship and in the management of national forests. After seven months of complicated negotiations, the report contains: a harsh message for those who have made a habit of cutting forests illegally, a message that can be summed up in two words: "game over".  We urgently need to implement an efficient and unbeatable timber traceability system at European level. We have the urgency to define, identify and protect with the utmost strictness what is left of Europe's virgin forests.  An absolute first is the linking of the concept of agrosiviculture to the future common agricultural policy, with the recommendation that the Member States make the most of this opportunity in favour of the farmer, the environment and all of us. We have provisions for a truly sustainable exploitation of forests, so that only the last scraps of wood can be used to produce energy. I therefore encourage you to vote for this report.

name: Ulrike MÜLLER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Renew Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has The concept of sustainability has already documented its homeland in forestry in 1713 in writing. Of course, our understanding of this is no longer the same as it was 300 years ago. We need to adapt management to changing challenges. Climate and nature conservation deserve more attention today. The consequences of climate change lead to greater vulnerabilities in forests, for example for pests and forest fires. Through research and practical experience, we also know more about specific factors and the ecosystem performance of the forest: local recreation for humans, the importance of healthy soils, humus formation, plant-available water reservoirs, site-adapted tree species.  A one-sided focus here only on a CO2 sink falls far too short. I refuse to make forests strictly protected areas. Forests are not static natural history museums. The cultural landscape is constantly changing. Only through active management can we meet the challenges.  Our forests supply raw materials, close the resource cycle and provide an economic location for rural areas. The forestry strategy must respond to these developments and bring the various functions of forests to their development. Our report has shown a balance and is a one-way move.

name: Teuvo HAKKARAINEN
text: On behalf of the ID Group. – Mr President, we Finns live in the forest and in the forest. In the woods, I'm home and I breathe freely. There's pollution in these concrete hells, and I see environmental destruction. The economic forest guarantees livelihoods, food, raw materials, energy and recreation, as well as wild nature. Coal is the food of the forest and improves growth. Heat is a prerequisite for growth. Why are positive things being kept quiet? A managed economic forest is a source of pride for its owner. Euros socialists and urban greens: you are welcome guests in the Finnish forest, but remember, you are strangers. Don't dictate your rules. Don't come and tell me what to do. Don't pay for your carbon deficit with us. Direct your demands to the Mediterranean countries where the forests have been destroyed. The market-based green gold industry does not need regulation or subsidies, but freedom to act. Finns don't go to the Dutch to tell us how to raise tulips either. Or the Italians to tell you how to make pizza. In the Sarvamaa report, I cannot accept green utopias, regulations or EU subsidies. However, the whole is balanced and acceptable.

name: Anna DEPARNAY-GRUNENBERG
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the The European Union must take more responsibility for its forests. Our forests can play a significant role in the fight against the climate crisis, as we know, but they are also currently victims of climate change. The EU must therefore take more responsibility for the reconstruction of our forests today as a matter of urgency. We urgently need forest conversion, towards more resilient and species-rich stocks, which can better store water. The forestry of the future must be thought through and through with the European Green Deal and the Biodiversity Strategy, because woods from species-rich forests that form deep, humus-rich soils have the best carbon footprint imaginable in the long term. On the other hand, dry forests and plantations, which are constantly falling victim to drought, storms and bark beetles, have a miserable carbon footprint in the long run. And that's where species protection and forestry come together. In some places, this will require a major change in forestry practice. However, no sector is as allergic to the word "change" as the forestry sector – and rightly so: as trees and forests grow slowly, we must work together with foresters to think through the changes. That is why the EU must also offer the sector and forest owners a perspective – massive support for this change that we are facing. Change must be thought of together with an EU-wide timber construction and bioeconomy strategy, because the new timbers, which are supposed to grow in mixed stocks, must also find buyers. Wood is an excellent CO2 storage system – we have heard it – which is why we should also use this valuable raw material in durable products, through wood construction or high-quality furniture. The industrial process and burning of specially designed forests, on the other hand, is a climate catastrophe. The bottom line is that the own-initiative report that is being voted on today does not go far enough in its responsibility for the forests of the future. That is why I appeal to colleagues: read the alternative resolution of Amendment No 2! I can't think of a Europe without forest for myself and for my children and also for the children of the future .... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Mazaly AGUILAR
text: ECR Group. – Mr President, because I fully support Mr Sarvamaa's report on forestry strategy, and I do so for two main reasons. One, because, although there are aspects that I do not share, I believe that it is a very balanced and constructive text that has to be the basis of the future European forestry strategy. Secondly, if I support this report, it is because, as rapporteur for the ECR Group, I have been able to see first-hand the flexibility of the rapporteur to try to integrate the main demands of all groups into the final text. However, despite the rapporteur's assignments to the Greens — in my view excessive and unjustified — these have not been enough to fill that insatiable appetite to which the Greens and company have accustomed us. They want it all or nothing. I am surprised that the groups that speak most about dialogue, consensus, understanding in this House are then the first to boycott all those reports where they do not get 100% of their claims.

name: Manuel BOMPARD
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, since the establishment of the von der Leyen Commission, the European Union's ecological action has resulted in fine statements which unfortunately are shattered on the reality of the acts. This is the case, again, of this text on the European Union's forestry strategy. So on the one hand, we are saying that we need to protect primary forests, but on the other hand, this text promotes wood as an energy source, when everyone knows that the energy efficiency of wood is extremely poor and that its combustion contributes to greenhouse gas emissions. Thus, on the one hand, we say that the forest is a common good that must be protected, but at the same time it opposes the fact that we can denounce the privatisation of state forest management bodies, which administer 40% of the forest area in Europe. Thus, on the one hand, we say and call on the European Commission to take measures to safeguard biodiversity by promoting, in particular, the diversity of forest species, but at the same time this text defends and encourages commercial management of forests, which relies on commercial monoculture and shaving cuts that are extremely detrimental to sustainable forest management. So, ladies and gentlemen, are we going to, at some point, ask ourselves whether the human species is destined to move from ecological savagery to another? After using gas, oil, coal, will we now burn all our forests or is it finally possible to think of a model of society in which the human species would live in harmony with nature.

name: Dino GIARRUSSO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, forests and forest land occupy 43 % of the Union's surface area and directly employ more than 500 000 citizens and, indirectly, 2.6 million. 60 % are privately owned and their management is the responsibility of the Member States. Since there are no specific provisions for a forestry policy, as the rapporteur's request shows, we need a holistic and independent vision. A new forestry strategy is therefore required, with at least three urgencies. Firstly, to integrate sustainable forest management and the multifunctional role of forests based on sustainability, first of all environmental and then economic and social. Secondly, to include the forestry strategy as an integral and independent part of the new European Green Deal. Thirdly, concrete action to stop both global deforestation and possible new privatisations at the expense of national parks and encouraging not only afforestation but also the sustainable management of forest resources. That is why we believe that the CAP can be of crucial importance in sustainable and multifunctional management and that the financing of forestry measures and the development of the bioeconomy must be increased in rural areas.

name: Marlene MORTLER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Our forests are a place of excursion and recreation, habitat for plants and animals, cultural heritage, timber producer and thus an important and indispensable source of income for our forest farmers. However, our forests are also the most important resource we have in the fight against climate change. The new EU forestry strategy must reflect this multifunctionality. It should take into account all the potential that our forests offer. This means that ecology, social affairs and economics must be in balance – protecting and benefiting. We need a proven sustainable forest economy in Europe. But that does not mean leaving the forest to its fate or chaining itself to every tree. Those who want climate-tolerant forests must allow sick trees to be replaced by new, site-adapted trees. We must not forget that behind every tree are people who have been cultivating, preserving and passing on practical knowledge for generations. They all create enormous diversity with their work in and for the forest. My appeal to the Commission is that the positive functions of sustainable use of forests must be conveyed more intensively, because the carbon sink forest is fundamental and therefore the miracle weapon of our green future in Europe. This must finally become more visible in political action.

name: Paolo DE CASTRO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the situation in our forests is one of the most important achievements of the Union, not least thanks to the common agricultural policy. In contrast to global trends, over the last twenty years we have seen an increase in our forest area equal to the size of Portugal, with substantial social impacts for a bioeconomy sector that accounts for almost 10 % of European employment. A sign of a European strategy which, although it can be improved, has led to important results. We cannot stop, Commissioner. We need to provide our farmers and foresters with risk and disaster management tools which, together with greater innovation and digitalisation of the sector, protect a system that is as fundamental as it is fragile. In this sense, how can we fail to remember the images of the tens of thousands of hectares of forest destroyed in my country by the bad weather of 2018. Our farmers and foresters must become the real protagonists of the challenge to achieve climate neutrality by 2050. That's why the strategy...  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Nicolae ŞTEFĂNUȚĂ
text: – Mr President, forests are not just wood. Forests are not just a resource for our economy. Passing this report as it is would be like looking at our greatest resource in the fight against climate change and only seeing a business. The report speaks often in optimistic terms about forest management in the EU and less about the protection of forests and biodiversity. It speaks too little about this, about the illegal logging in the EU. This is why I ask you to support and ask you to vote for Amendment 2. Let us call on the Commission and the Member States to set targets for forest covers, to call for strict protection of old—growth and primary forests. Let us all speak about the way forests can help the ambitious goals we set in the Climate Law. Forest protection provides us with hope, gives us a chance to have a buffer against the worst dangers of climate change. Let’s not miss the forest for the wood in it. Let’s act now.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Mr President, forest management is not an area that the Treaties have entrusted to the European Union. I therefore believe that it must remain national and protest against the desire of the Sarvamaa report to build a European forestry strategy. My group "Identity and Democracy" has tabled an alternative resolution to mark this opposition. The Union now takes on the detestable habit of violating treaties when it suits it. Our presence in Brussels is proof of this because, according to the treaties, we should sit in Strasbourg. And under the Juncker Commission, the scandalous appointment of Martin Selmayr was another shining example. Before giving rule of law lessons to Poland and Hungary, the Union should start by sweeping at its door. In this case, the Union's interference is all the more absurd because the States manage their forests very well. In France, for example, the forest grows by 40,000 hectares per year. Rather than satisfy its vain will for power, the Union would do better to protect its borders from Chinese traders who come to plunder our wood production, thus putting our sawmills at risk.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you, Mr Lebreton. Mr Lebreton, I call you to order because it is not customary to display messages in the form of banners and T-shirts here in plenary. This is unparliamentary.

name: Marie TOUSSAINT
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, forests are the lung of humanity and of the planet. Much of our future is about our ability to stop deforestation and ongoing degradation, the ecological consequences of which are a disaster.  As you know, almost all of Europe's forests are now threatened, only 15% of them are in a state considered favourable. Fifteen percent. What are we waiting for? Are we waiting for the last tree of Europe's last primary forest to be felled? That would be an aberration.  However, this is exactly what the European strategy we are discussing today is proposing. Behind the blurring of words lies a policy that does not say its name, because it is actually unacceptable. We are finally offered to continue as before, without changing logic. For years, we have watched the Amazon rainforest die and we do not have words harsh enough to condemn Bolsonaro's policy.  But in Guyana, what is Europe doing? We are abandoning the Amazon to legal and illegal gold miners and we plan to open a oil-fired power plant. Across Europe, we are accelerating the disappearance of the forest, instead of correcting our Renewable Energy Directive to prevent it from contributing to the deforestation of areas that we should absolutely protect.  It is time to stop crimes against forests and those who protect them, such as the 170 rangers who have been attacked in Romania in recent years. It is time to reaffirm that the laws of profit are not above nature. It is time to look at forests as natural commons, living entities, partners to protect. I call on you to vote for Amendment No 2.

name: Krzysztof JURGIEL
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The report on the future forestry strategy is holistic and not only highlights the ecological role of forests, but also draws attention to their social aspects. Europe needs an ambitious, strong forestry strategy to ensure a coordinated approach to forests, the forestry sector and many of the services they provide. The report should be supported because, firstly, it is based on the principles of sustainable development, which promotes the ecological, economic and social functions of forests. Secondly, it emphasises human aspects, referring in particular to people who work, live directly or indirectly from forests and the forestry sector. Thirdly, it calls for an ambitious, independent, independent forestry strategy of the European Union for the post-2020 period and stresses the need for better coordination, integration with other European Union legislation relating to forests, forestry and agriculture.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: – Mr President, we cannot support this proposal because it translates into a progressive financialisation of the forest and this financialisation of the forest leads not only to a productivist logic, but to a short-term productivist logic.  This proposal should aim at a strategy to combat climate change, with forests being a key element in reducing carbon dioxide emissions. It should aim at preservation, conservation and biodiversity at a time when only 15% of forests are in a favourable state of conservation in the European Union. It should point to forestry and reforestation. You should point to the resilience against fires and pests and you don't do any of this.  That is why we call for a vote on Amendment No 2, which is the one that allows for a forest strategy that actually responds to the fight against climate change, and which is a strategy of our times and not a strategy of the past. I therefore appeal to all colleagues, do not let this recommendation go through. What we need is, as the name implies, a strategy for the forest in the European Union.

name: Ivan Vilibor SINČIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, no forest strategy in Europe can succeed until the problem of illegal deforestation is resolved. I have spoken and done a lot against the so-called wood mafia that exists in Croatia, Romania and some other countries. It's about organized crime, mass felling of the best trees to make a profit. But apart from this organised crime, there are our fellow citizens, people who have no choice but to embark on illegal deforestation.  It's about people who do it because they have no way to survive the winter, because they have no way to close the home budget. We have 100 million poor people in Europe. That is why we need to introduce a universal basic income for the whole of Europe to combat poverty, to enable these people to live with dignity so that they do not have to go into illegal deforestation to survive. Universal basic income will address this pressure on forests, environmental and nature devastation.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Mr President, the importance of forests cannot be underestimated. We depend on them so we can survive on. The European Union currently does not have a common forestry policy and the Member States are responsible for forestry measures. The European Union's Forest Strategy to date has helped to promote sustainable development and strengthened cooperation between Member States. It is essential, however, that the future post-2020 forestry strategy contains elements that increase the harmonisation of national laws at European Union level. At the same time, the European Union's forestry strategy must influence the global political context and increase measures to stop global deforestation.  The common agricultural policy is the main source of European funding for forests, but at the same time the sector must also be financed from the Structural Funds and beyond. It is essential for the sustainable future of this sector to find the necessary and accessible levers to encourage the restoration and conservation of forests, and local and regional authorities need to step up their cooperation in this regard. A strengthened forestry sector contributes to the economic growth of rural areas. Forests make an essential contribution to food security, helping to maintain the environmental conditions necessary for agricultural production, biodiversity, but also to prevent and combat drought. The competitive forestry sector and agriculture play an important role in job generation, while maintaining the vitality of rural areas.

name: Isabel CARVALHAIS
text: – Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the creation of a common framework in which policies and mechanisms capable of generating synergies are articulated to enable European forests to realise their full potential as healthy, productive and resilient ecosystems, and as structuring areas of rural areas essential to their development, is an undeniable necessity.  Protecting forests is protecting Europe's biodiversity, which is now facing alarming levels of threat. But biodiversity conservation does not have to be incompatible with social and economic development. It requires a very hard effort, an arduous effort of conciliation, but feasible, and that we must achieve, for the good of society. European forests face multiple threats: fires, droughts, climate change, invasive species, urban pressure - all must be properly identified and evaluated in a forest strategy that addresses environmentally and socially sustainable management, promotes biodiversity conservation, but also social inclusion in rural areas.

name: Cristian GHINEA
text: – Mr President, during the Covid crisis, we spent some time in the mountainous area of Romania and we noticed a worrying phenomenon there: people make sure that forest does not grow on their land. Why is that? Simple, because I lose the European subsidy for pastures and meadows.  Traditionally, there are animals growing or hay is made. This is hard physical work, once the population ages, the way of life changes, many would give up in favor of the forest, which grows naturally.  What's going on now? We are basically fighting the forest because these are the rules for receiving the subsidy and it is a great pity because we talk a lot here about the role of the forest, we talk very nicely about forests, but we make rules by which we force the people of the mountain area to fight these forests.  I propose, as a member of the Committee on Agriculture, to rethink this policy, to think of eco-schemes dedicated to forests, both for pillar one for subsidies and for pillar two, so as to encourage people to grow, not to fight the forest.

name: Thomas WAITZ
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Anyone who takes the fight against the climate crisis seriously cannot miss the role of forests. In fact, forests, existing or still reforested, can make a significant contribution to collecting and sequestering CO2. In order to perform this, however, we must stop the clearing economy, because this leads to dehydration, to water loss, to loss of humus, and by the way, it takes the forest 80 to 100 years to recover all this CO2. We must stop destroying the soil with the heaviest harvesters. Soil erosion, soil compaction, humus loss are the consequences of these interventions. We need to turn our monoculture plantations in Europe into mixed forests that are climate-friendly and that can also withstand the challenges of climate change. Only natural forest management can do this, can ensure a water supply, can ensure the highest wood yield, can ensure the best wood quality and, by the way, ensures biodiversity and maximum CO2 storage. Our forest farmers, like me, know how to do this. It is time for industry to take this path as well. Just tell me ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you very much, Mr Waitz. Mr Waitz, the microphone is no longer on.  (Interruption) Yes, but the interpreters cannot hear you, and then posterity is left with no secret of what you have to say about important things. It would be good if everyone were to stick to the list of speakers. Everyone has something important to say; you can express it all in one minute.

name: Beata MAZUREK
text: – The new forestry strategy should provide a key legal framework for coherent, coordinated action at European Union level. It should be a continuation of the previous one, with a clear emphasis on preserving the principle of sovereignty and competence of the Member States in forest management. For Polish, it is very important to strengthen the role of the Standing Committee on Forestry, not only as a discussion network for the exchange of knowledge and expertise, but also as an opinion forum for forest initiatives in the Eu institutions.  Ensuring the sustainability of forests by improving resilience, particularly in terms of protection against fires, droughts, pests, diseases and other risks that may increase as a result of climate change, should be one of the main objectives of the new strategy. Failure to protect forests from dying will result in the loss of the specific characteristics of forest ecosystems in these areas for years to come. This can be the basis for impoverishment and even loss of biodiversity typical of individual forest habitats. Particular attention must be paid to the need to support research and innovation and the deployment of technologies in forests and the forestry sector, as well as to continuously improve skills through academic and vocational education in order to protect the Earth's natural lungs even more effectively.

name: Daniela RONDINELLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, forests are one of nature's greatest expressions, but, in the name of unholy development, we are destroying what we should be keeping for future generations. I believe that the report approved by the AGRI Committee is innovative, because it states that the forestry strategy is one of the pillars of the new Green Deal and that it is essential to provide economic and regulatory instruments to protect and expand existing forests. We must therefore choose to abandon old models. We in the 5Star Movement believe that biomass should be eliminated from European and national energy strategies, as well as hunting, which can no longer be considered a source of income or recipient of European funds. We are aware that more than two million workers are in the forest-related economy, but that does not necessarily mean unbridled and indiscriminate exploitation. Virtuous models are the foundations for building an ecological European framework. So it is a huge challenge and it is at a contrast to what is happening today in the rest of the world. Only Europe is taking this objective seriously, with the active participation of its citizens and its productive and social forces. This is the model to be realized for a real green transition.

name: Simone SCHMIEDTBAUER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The climate crisis is pervasive and we are confronted with it on a daily basis. That's a fact. However, we can only solve the problem by reducing fossil fuels and banishing them from our system in the long term. In forestry, however, we can now react at any time. We are ready to contribute with our know-how and our renewable resources at our disposal. We need active, multifunctional forest management in a sustainable way, taking biodiversity into account. Our forests must be managed in such a way that they can absorb as much CO2 as possible from the atmosphere. It is a completely wrong approach and misconception that we could increase the absorption of CO2 by de-icing and other restrictions. Less forest management in Europe is a concept with which we are driving future generations to the wall. We must prevent this. Europe has enough wood; it is constantly growing and it should be used sensibly. Let us talk about timber construction offensives, biomass plants, wood-gas and wood diesel: all the possibilities that the forest already offers us. Let us also talk about more than three million jobs in Europe! If we strengthen rural areas and the regions, let us counteract emigration. The forest can do all this. Let us move away from populist statements, which certainly do not take us any further at the moment, but only mean gridlock! Hence the support of our report.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: – Mr President, it has obviously not been easy to find a good balance in this report. I think this debate shows it. And from the S&D Group, our perspective is that there certainly are aspects that could have been better included in the process. We need to take good care of our forests. There is no doubt about it. They are one of our green lungs. I’m from a country which has a large and thriving forest myself, and for me a good day is a day when I walk in the forest with my dog or spend time there enjoying the biodiversity. But that being said, I also believe in a sustainable forest management that it’s possible to combine, and I’m convinced that the objectives of forest protection, strengthening biodiversity and wood protection can actually be challenges that together go as a big opportunity for our Member States and also for the climate and climate policy in the EU. So I look forward to seeing the Commission’s proposal taking that into account.

name: Irène TOLLERET
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, the forest is our most precious asset in achieving our climate targets. It is very important to strengthen the European Union's support for the fight against the causes of forest deterioration. I am thinking in particular of the fires, which ravage thousands of hectares of forests every year in Europe and around the world.  I would like to highlight in this Chamber the work done by European farmers in the agro-forest regions: their role in fire prevention is essential. I welcome the European Parliament's recognition of this activity in the reports we will be voting on this week. And I hope that when we adopt the new CAP in two weeks, our institution will show the same recognition to these producers, who are often living in difficult areas. I would also like to stress the need to extend the virtues of European environmental policies to third countries. In this regard, I welcome the broad agreement reached by the European Parliament on the import ban on products from deforested areas and the respect of forests imposed in trade agreements with third countries.

name: Jutta PAULUS
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Unfortunately, everyone does not yet understand it: our forests are primarily habitats, carbon storage, natural air conditioning systems, which are already extremely stressed by climate change, and they must be protected. This protection is poor. Today, the European Environment Agency has published that even more than 80% of the forests protected under Natura 2000 are in good condition, because the protection plans are lacking, because the management plans are not implemented and because violations are not dealt with. Instead of further fuelling the myth of climate-neutral biomass combustion – in the truest sense of the word – as is sometimes the case here, we should instead follow science. It says: protect old forests, protect stringent, verifiable criteria for truly sustainable forest management and tackle illegal deforestation. Ladies and gentlemen, we must take climate protection and the preservation of biodiversity seriously. Please therefore vote in favour of the committee's alternative proposal for a truly sustainable use of forests!

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Mr President, thank you to the rapporteur, Mr Sarvamaa, for the good work he has done.  Forests and forest resources are of great environmental, economic and social importance. In Spain, Galicia has more than half of the logging facilities throughout the country. The forestry sector is strategic for my region —Galicia, as I said. It is necessary to work for sustainable and multifunctional forests and mountains, which are a source of natural and economic wealth. In Galicia we are committed to a management of forest resources based on bioeconomy.  In this regard, I was pleased to see how this report by Mr Sarvamaa is going in this direction and is also committed to strengthening sustainable forest management. In addition, forests are also a way to drive the economic revival needed after the COVID-19 pandemic; for example, the Xunta de Galicia is evaluating the creation of a manufacturing center for textile fibres, from wood, within the framework of the circular economy.  Another very important issue is the prevention of forest fires, a terrible threat that Spain and other southern countries face every summer and which is aggravated by climate change. Fires don't understand borders.
