Within the European Union, as proposed in the report we are now debating, more funding needs to be allocated and greater cooperation and joint capacity for action to combat forest fires. It is important that the European Commission incorporates this element into the forestry strategy it is preparing.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: Mr President, forests and wooded areas currently cover 43% of the EU's surface area. They are true purifiers by eliminating 10% of the total greenhouse gases emitted in Europe.  But in recent years there has been a marked increase in logging and deforestation. It is therefore crucial that we do everything possible to keep the balance between the demand for wood and the need to preserve these ecosystems that are essential for the environment. We need effective, coherent and harmonised management at European level of our forest heritage.  The Commission's proposal will therefore have to focus on the three pillars of economic sustainability, societal sustainability and, of course, environmental sustainability. The challenges are many: intensifying the fight against illegal logging, promoting the circular bio-economy, agroforestry or strengthening resilience to natural disasters. It is our responsibility to recognize the value and importance of forests to society and to develop effective policies to ensure that this value is protected, maintained and strengthened.

name: Karin KARLSBRO
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Forests are home to invaluable biodiversity, and as a carbon sink, forests are crucial to achieving climate goals. In order to preserve the richness of species and to save the climate, we all have an interest in the conservation of forests throughout the EU. I come from a country that is half forest. Forests are one of our main resources that creates growth and benefits and must be managed responsibly and sustainably.  The EU should, of course, advocate responsible forest management that combines financial interests with the protection of biodiversity. But it is important to remember that knowledge of forestry is mainly local. Forests and the conditions for forestry and forest management differ enormously from one Member State to another. Forestry is therefore best decided on locally and must remain national competence.

name: Martin HÄUSLING
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which 285 000 hectares of forest are currently being destroyed in Germany. Consequence of climate change: bark beetles, drought, new fungal diseases. The forest has long since ceased to be a CO2 storage facility. This report, I must honestly say, does not meet the new challenges. The focus is still on use. Yes, nothing against sensible use. But can we in Europe be responsible for burning wood in power stations so that Member States can make their carbon footprints good? We can no longer accept that. That is why we must clearly reject this in the future.  We must place our forests under increased protection. We point the finger at Brazil, but in Europe we are not even in a position to protect the Carpathians, to protect FFH areas. In Germany, a motorway, the A 49, is being built through FFH areas. We can no longer accept that. Therefore, we need to build a new forest, natural forests, away from spruce, pine and eucalyptus plantations. This also includes changing the right to hunt so that trophy hunting does not eat away the forest in some areas.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, although responsibility for forests and forestry is entirely in the hands of the Member States, we know very well that the European Union has a fundamental influence on the quality of forests through its policies. With Europe facing desertification, forest stands being destroyed by drought, pests, fires, and other effects of climate change, we must choose what is more important to us – whether health and long-term effect from species-diverse forests or short-term economic gains from intensive forestry and expanding forest cultivation for biomass purposes.  I believe that if we want forests to remain our lungs, to produce oxygen, to absorb at least the 10% of greenhouse gases that we produce, to retain water and to retain a number of other functions, including the production one, which is much talked about and which I do not underestimate, then today the protection of forests must be put first. I expect the Commission to take a number of new measures, including the revision of the Renewable Energy Directive. I also think it is worth considering whether it is expedient for all disposable articles that were previously made of plastic to now be massively replaced by wood materials, whether it is a better solution to reduce consumption than increasing it in the form of wood products. Personally, I greatly appreciate the work done by my colleague Sarvamaa, but still the emphasis on environmental protection and forest protection... (he withered the speaker's word).

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: – Mr President, I am a supporter , I would like to make it very clear in my speech , of a European forestry strategy with ambition and that it is moving to future regulations at European level so that national forest policy management can now give way to European management. But now this policy is national competence. In addition, we are facing the great fight against climate change and we must take into account our climate commitments made at the Paris Summit and the proposals of the European Green Pact — that is why this Resolution states that forestry strategy should be an important pillar within this Green Pact — both aspects that are contained in the Resolution adopted by the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development , whose rapporteur is Mr Sarvamaa, who I congratulate with the rapporteur group and my colleague Avram. For me it is a balanced proposal that reflects important aspects such as the need to preserve and promote biodiversity or the importance of reforestation. That is why I are asking for a vote in favour of this proposal and against Amendments Nos 1 and 2.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – Mr President! First of all, congratulations to the rapporteur, Mr Sarvamai. It can be seen that it comes from Finland, which can manage forests, has many forests, which is why this report is also comprehensive and also coordinated with the many stakeholders involved in the preparation of this report. Forests play a multifunctional role. Just as sustainable development consists of an environmental, economic, social component, all these components are also included in forest management. Forests also play an important role in the context of the Green Agreement, our new development paradigm, so it is right to highlight both this protective function, such important areas of biodiversity, storage of water resources, fire fighting and avalanches. However, we must talk, in addition to the carbon-related environment, also about the economic use of forests, about what farmers can actually do with forests and what we can do with research beyond the bioeconomy, where forestry plays an important role. I am pleased that Slovenians can be proud of our sustainable development of forest management, as Mr Sarvamaa also recognised in his report. It is farmers who will continue to guarantee the sustainable development of forestry, so it is right that we support it through the common agricultural policy and the rural development programme, while also enabling good management where forests are protected.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the text as voted by the AGRI Committee is a good compromise, which goes in the right direction, that is to say, in the direction of outlining the commitment that we will have to make in the coming years to protect our forest heritage, taking into account, of course, the environmental aspects, which are fundamental, but also the economic and social aspects that are linked to it. We are talking about an important strategy – it has been emphasised by all my colleagues – but it has already led to important results in recent years. It has been said that 43 % of the land is covered by forests that employ more than three million people, which is why it is important to have an ambitious, coordinated and coherent strategy at European level. I believe that this text is heading in the right direction.

name: Balázs HIDVÉGHI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. The EU forestry strategy post-2020 is the best way to achieve a balanced representation of the three pillars of sustainability through sustainable forest management. I am pleased that this report confirms the importance of this. Hungary has almost doubled its forest areas in the past century. Our goal is to reach 27 percent of forested areas by 2030. This is an important part of the Hungarian climate and conservation action plan. I would also like to stress that efforts to halt the decline of biodiversity should be supported. However, this can be done most effectively within the framework of sustainable forest management, and it is therefore regrettable that the publication of the biodiversity strategy preceded the forestry strategy. This was a mistake on the part of the European Commission, in my opinion. This should have happened in parallel and in a coordinated manner.  All the more so because the objectives of the biodiversity strategy have an economically and socially significant impact on agriculture and forestry. However, in the absence of a preliminary assessment, it is clear that these will not have the expected impact and that comprehensive impact assessments should therefore be carried out. Excessive and unjustified pressures on social strata, farmers, forest owners and agriculture and forestry should not be allowed. Particular attention should be paid to this. That is why I consider it extremely important that the principles of sustainable forest management should prevail in both strategies.

name: Delara BURKHARDT
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The forest is not only an important ally in the fight against the climate crisis, but also its sacrifice. Everyone who enters one can experience how badly the forests are doing: drought, storms and parasites are causing them. Only 15% of the forest habitat is in good condition. Not surprisingly, this year's Environment Agency report on the state of nature concludes that the EU has so far failed to meet the target of halting this loss. I fear that the report to be voted on today will not reverse this trend. It reduces our forests to an economic factor and makes the vague concept of so-called sustainable forest management a magic formula for pretty much everything.  With the report by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Social Affairs, which was tabled as an amendment, we are proposing a forest strategy that reconciles the role of forests for the European economy with the Green Deal. In doing so, we are making the climate fighter Forest fit for the future, and that is precisely our task.

name: Asim ADEMOV
text: – Mr President, European forests absorb 10% of the European Union's carbon emissions. Forests and the forestry sector have the potential to make an increasing contribution to combating climate change and to achieving the objectives of the European Green Pact for a climate-neutral economy.  Healthy forests and sustainable ecosystems have natural protective functions to adapt to climate change. That is why we must first take care of the ecological status of forests, fight illegal and bare logging, promote afforestation practices and preserve natural, old and centuries-old forests, which are an indispensable source of biodiversity.  Forests play an important socio-economic role in rural and most depopulated areas in the European Union, creating jobs and livelihoods for the local population (including ecotourism, mushroom harvesting and berries, beekeeping).  In order to achieve higher environmental objectives of the new CAP, it is important to continue supporting the forestry sector and the development of the bioeconomy, to implement agro-forestry practices, as well as incentives for foresters to protect, grow and manage forests in a sustainable manner.

name: Benoît LUTGEN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that we must stop confronting the three key issues of the forest. First of all, the economic stakes that are decisive for three million people, families, in Europe. Secondly, the environmental and climate issue, of course protecting biodiversity, but also ensuring that the entire forest can participate in the fight against global warming through CO2 storage and also prepare our forest in terms of planting so that this forest is not undermined by global warming, as can be seen in some European countries.  And finally, the social issue that is very important, especially the access of the population to the forest and the tourism issue associated with it. There is no point in this, we must find the necessary interactions between these three issues, which are obviously decisive. The report, on the whole, goes in the right direction and respects these balances and above all brings these interactions between these three key issues. There's a weakness, though. That of European sovereignty. Today we export massively from different Member States, to China in particular, part of our raw material. Let us recognize that we do not have the same reciprocity since China prohibits the export of unprocessed timber to other world countries.  Here we must act so that this sovereignty is much stronger so that tomorrow this raw material is transformed at home, in short circuits, to ensure that the whole sector can develop and here we will respond concretely to employment, the environment and the reality of the climate challenge.

name: Michal WIEZIK
text: – Mr President, European forests are not doing well. The majority of them are not in good shape. Europe desperately needs a good forest strategy – a strategy that would facilitate sustainable forest management for forests intended to be extracted, and strict conservation for those which should remain untouched. Neither of these approaches is optional, nor can they be merged. Otherwise, we will see the last untouched valleys in the Făgăraş Mountains being cut down ‘sustainably’. We will see the last capercaillie forest in the Tatra Mountains being savaged ‘sustainably’. We will see another sustainable harvest in the Białowieża primeval forest. All of these ecological tragedies have already happened, because sustainable forestry was promoted where strict protection should have been the only option.    The AGRI report fails to be a good forest strategy proposal. It virtually demands an increase in wood harvesting all over Europe, regardless of its inevitable impact on resilience, complexity, sequestration and biodiversity. This is not a good strategy in times of climate crisis and the sixth mass extinction. Not at all. But there is an option. We have an alternative file, which is complex, based on factual science and goes along the exact path a good forest strategy should follow. It promotes sustainable forest management and strict protection. It calls for balance. Honourable Members, I, as a forest scientist, openly encourage you to vote in favour of Amendment 2. It is the only way forward for European forests.

name: Janusz WOJCIECHOWSKI
text: Member. – Thank you, Mr President. I thank all of you for your comments and for your proposals on the strategy. They are very important, very valuable, and I can declare that both Commissioner Sinkevičius and I , because together we are working on the concept of this strategy, will incorporate the comments that you are presenting, as far as possible. Of course, we will take into account the content of the report that will be adopted. Of course, I will not comment on all the statements of which there were almost 50. I am pleased with the strong involvement of your Members, of interest in this strategy. A few issues may need to be clarified. The first is that the strategy is not yet there. There were voices here, indicating that we were discussing an existing strategy. We have a strategy so far, the new one will of course be a continuation of it, but an improved continuation – these are our ambitions to prepare a better strategy than it was until now. Legal basis. Of course, we remember that forest management is a national competence. The strategy will not be a binding piece of legislation forcing Member States to do anything. We hope that there will be an agreed political declaration of the will of the Member States to ensure, on an equal footing, that European forests are kept in good condition on an equal footing. Many of your statements highlighted the issues of multifunctionality. This is, moreover, crucial in mr Sarvamy's draft report. I am very pleased with this approach, and that will be the Commission's approach. Of course, environmental function is more important for some, others stress economic issues as very important. We need to balance that. We want European forests to be a mainstay of nature, to be green lungs, as has been emphasised in some statements, but to be open, to be accessible to our society, not just to be admired from afar, but to be able to use them. And, of course, the economic role. This cannot be abandoned and must be carried out in a sustainable way. 60% of European forests are privately owned, so we must also respect the rights of the owners, who, as indicated in one statement, are of course proud if their forests are well managed. There must be no contradiction between the strategies that the European Commission has already adopted. The forestry strategy must be in line with both the general Green Deal Communication and biodiversity strategies, to some extent the field-to-table strategy.  For me personally, it is particularly important to make good use of the elements of the common agricultural policy, because such instruments are – afforestation measures in the second pillar. I have mentioned and will repeat: agro-forestry as one of the potential eco-programmes to which we will encourage Member States, farmers, to use it. This will also be one way of increasing the forestry of the European Union. Fortunately, the area of forests in the European Union is increasing, forestry is increasing and this trend needs to be maintained. We need good, growing forests. Of course, we will also remember the forests in the world, we have instruments in common in the European Union's trade policy. We will try to pursue such a policy, so as not only not to favour some kind of robbery of forest management outside Europe, but also to promote the protection of forests and to use, as far as possible, the trade policy of the European Union. We will base our activities on scientific research, of course. Here it is very important to cooperate with science and take all actions based on solid scientific knowledge. It is also important to avoid the trend of fighting plastic, as has been mentioned in some statements, and that forests are not victims of this change of concept. We also need to rationally shape the demand for wood so that, of course, this is not at the expense of over-exploitation of forests. Mr President, to sum up, I am very pleased with this discussion. I think we are on the right track together to develop a good forestry strategy – one that will be accepted by everyone in the European Union and consistently implemented. And thanks to it we will preserve the beauty of our forests, their natural values, but also preserve their important economic potential. Thank you very much, Mr President.

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, just a couple of remarks on the lengthy and very interesting discussion that we’ve just had. First of all, I would say to Ms Toussaint – unfortunately she is not here, but maybe you will give my regards – that I would probably enjoy condemning Mr Bolsonaro on how he treats the Brazilian forests, but this is the European forests strategy, once again, that we are debating today.  Then to Mr Bompard, I want to just make one factual correction – there were plenty of reasons to do that in many speeches, but there’s one that I would specifically like to make – and that’s when he said that this report is promoting wood as a source of energy. The way I understand the word ‘promote’ in the English language, this report is not promoting the use of wood as a source of energy.  That leads me to say the most important thing about this report and about this discussion. Forests are of enormous importance to all of us. So we must not have anything, and we must not accept anything, but a holistic and self—standing forest strategy. That is what we need. I really want to use this opportunity to thank everyone. It was an exceptionally heated process for an own—initiative report, with almost 500 amendments and lengthy and numerous shadows meetings. I think that what the Commissioner just said sums it up best. We need to strike a balance, and I think that this report gives Members a chance to do that.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. The vote on the amendments will take place today. The final vote will take place on Wednesday, 7 October 2020. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. – The EU must support a sustainable forest strategy that is essential for ensuring the economic viability and competitiveness of forest management and the forest sector. The new strategy is also important for providing solutions to promote climate as well as biodiversity, bioenergy and the bio- and green economy. It is important that EU forest management strategies are consistent with the objectives of the Green Agreement, while remaining within the competence of the Member States. The EU's ability to respond to emergencies and prevent disasters must also increase, for example in the event of fires or floods. In addition, the resolution recommends a wider use of wood as a sustainable building material, calls for stepping up the fight against illegal logging and calls for the promotion of sustainable forestry worldwide.

name: Riho TERRAS
text: Writing. – For the European Commission's forestry strategy, Parliament needs to provide a guideline to help shape the next forestry strategy in a balanced way. Europe's forests have a number of very important dimensions and must all be treated in a balanced way. The environmental dimension is very clear to everyone, as forests are a global asset that is extremely important as co2 binders. In many EU Member States, the number of forests has drastically declined and there are different reasons for this – mainly the development of industry and agriculture and population growth. In Europe, however, there are also countries where forests cover more than half of the territory and are in good condition. Estonia, together with other Nordic countries, is a good example. In order to maintain the health of forests, forests need to be managed intelligently. Forest management is the management of renewable resources, i.e. in addition to logging, the importance of forest restoration must be taken into account. In many Member States, forest reworking is a very important source of livelihood and employs many different industries. The Commission's forestry strategy needs to emphasise the importance of forest management, as the half-million workers involved in forest harvesting and the 2.6 million people more broadly involved in the area need to send a clear message about the perspective and potential of the sector. Forests also have a very strong socio-cultural dimension, the protection of which is the responsibility of every nation. Forests have important meaning for Estonia, as thousands of people fled the Soviet occupation into the forest. Resistance to the occupation regime was also organized from the forest. The last forest brother, August Sabbe, fell at the hands of the KGB in 1978, the forest sheltered him for more than 30 years.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. – Promoting sustainable forest management in the EU's forest strategy and rural development measures under the common agricultural policy has had a positive impact on forests and their condition and livelihoods in rural areas, on the biodiversity of EU forests and has increased the benefits for the forest sector. However, sustainable forest management still needs to be strengthened in a balanced manner in order to ensure that forests' ecological status, ecosystem health and resilience are improved and that forests are able to adapt better to a changing climate. This is particularly important for very wooded countries such as Lithuania. The EU Forest Strategy should promote and support the sharing of the most useful practices in the implementation of sustainable forest management, vocational training for forest workers and managers, the results of the forestry sector and better cooperation between Member States in cross-border actions and information sharing in order to ensure the growth of healthy European forests. There is a need to ensure better awareness of the importance of sustainable forest management, as well as to enable the development, implementation and coordination of awareness-raising campaigns on forest multifunctionality and the multiperative benefits of sustainable forest management from an economic, social and environmental point of view. All European citizens should be aware of the richness of this heritage and the need to manage, maintain and use our resources in a sustainable manner.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: I'd like to make an announcement first. I warmly welcome you! Unfortunately, due to travel restrictions, Maltese interpreters are partially unavailable, so today's meeting will only be able to provide passive interpretation in other languages from Maltese. This means that Maltese Members can speak in their own language, but they will not translate the speech in other languages into Maltese, so they will be forced to use another language, English, French or German. Thank you for your understanding.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: The next item is the report by Jytte Guteland on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, debate on the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a framework for achieving climate neutrality and amending Regulation (EU) 2018/1999 (European Climate Regulation) (COM(2) 020)0080 - C9-0077/2020 - 2020/0036(COD)) (A9-0162/2020).

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, this is a historic moment. The European Climate Law is indeed the cornerstone of the European Green Deal, as it enshrines into legislation the Union’s objective to reach net-zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2050 at the latest. The climate neutrality objective brings with it a transition of historic dimension, which Europe will undergo in the coming decades. We are moving away from our history as the coal and steel union and heading towards climate neutrality. The report that we will see voted on this afternoon improves the Commission’s proposal on a number of points and, colleagues, we are responsible for this; we need to listen to citizens, scientists and the movement of young people and do our very best to improve this legislation and make it responsible for our time. The report sets a binding target for the Union and the Member States to achieve climate neutrality by 2050 at the latest. Thereafter, emissions shall be negative. Everyone must contribute to reach the climate neutrality objective. This is something we need to do together. The report proposes a strengthened 2030 climate target of 60% in order to be in line with science and give Europe the best possible chance of reaching its climate neutrality objective and respecting the Paris Agreement. We need to have a higher target for 2030. The Commission has proposed a net target of at least 55% for 2030, meaning approximately between 51% and 53% in real emission reductions, depending on how much greenhouse gas our natural sinks will be able to remove from the atmosphere. This is not good enough. We need a stronger target if we are serious about respecting the Paris Agreement and our own responsibility to reach climate neutrality. This is also why the report includes a new EU climate target for 2040. This is a crucial element to ensure that Europe is on track to achieve climate neutrality by 2050.  To take responsible climate action, we also need to know exactly how much Europe can emit without undermining the Union’s commitment under the Paris Agreement. Therefore, the report also calls for the introduction of a greenhouse gas budget setting out the total remaining quantity of greenhouse gas emissions as CO2 equivalent that could be emitted up to 2050 without putting at risk the 1.5 degree temperature goal. Elements of social fairness and solidarity have been strengthened throughout the regulation. For the S&D Group, this is fundamental. We will only succeed in our climate efforts if everyone is with us, if no one is left behind. It must be socially just and we must make sure that it’s for all the citizens.  I would like to underline the importance of the reference to the 2015 International Labour Organization’s guidelines for a just transition towards environmentally sustainable economies and societies. We also emphasise the importance of social partners, which I’m very proud of. There are also strong provisions on science, not to mention the set-up of an independent climate council at European level: the European Climate Change Council (ECCC), which, with the creation of climate advisory bodies at Member State level, will assess whether we are on track to achieve the climate neutrality objective and identify opportunities to further reduce greenhouse gas emissions and increase the carbon sequestration potential. Furthermore, the provisions for climate adaptation have been strengthened, with increased consideration of vulnerable groups.  I will conclude by saying this is a good proposal. I would like to thank my colleagues, all the shadows, all the people that worked with this legislation, the advisors, and also the interpretation, which has been good, the technical advisers. Thank you so much. No one is left behind. (Applause)

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: draft opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab As historical experience shows, radicalism, which is not limited to the realities, very often leads to consequences contrary to the goal it wants to achieve, and often ends in disaster. We European Parliamentarians, too, should not focus on populist bidding on proposals to reduce greenhouse gases as much as possible in the shortest possible time, but should look for realistic scenarios that are acceptable to everyone – individual Member States and their societies. Scenarios that do not frustrate the achievement of the Union's other objectives, e.g. rebuilding the economy after a pandemic, strengthening its competitiveness, its technological sovereignty. The climate neutrality target agreed to by the European Council last December is to apply at Union level. It has been assumed that zero-emission in each country will be achieved in different time perspectives. This is in line with the principles of a just transition, which must take into account the different primary conditions for the transformation of national economies. The draft regulation also envisages that the European Union as a whole will achieve climate neutrality by 2050. This is a realistic position and it should be parliament's support.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: Executive Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all I have to apologise to Members for being late. It’s because of the College – it finished and I immediately came here. I’m really happy to discuss with you today what is I think a landmark of the European Green Deal, the climate law to turn Europe’s political climate ambitions into binding legislation.  Moving towards a climate-neutral future is the right thing to do for our children and future generations especially now, and everything we’re doing is science—based, so actually those who deny the science are being ideological, not the ones who embrace science! (Applause) If we invest hundreds of billions of euros in rescuing our economy from this pandemic we must not throw money at the old economy. We must guide our societies to a cleaner and healthier future, one that our children can embrace with hope, not fear. We must be very clear and very honest about this. This transition will affect our daily lives: from the cars we drive, from the houses we live in, from the jobs we will have in the future. I’m confident that we can make it if we do two things: if we set ourselves a sound direction and stand together as a continent in mastering the challenge. The Climate Law will set the direction by making our 2050 climate neutrality goal binding. That provides certainty at a time when so much is uncertain.  I want to stress three points. This is a Union—wide commitment to climate neutrality with a just transition for all. The target is also economy—wide: all sectors must contribute, no exceptions granted, and it’s a domestic objective delivered in Europe to inspire the world to follow our lead, and we see across the world other nations following the lead already.  For 2030 we need to increase our ambition if we want a realistic pathway to climate neutrality. Our proposal to increase the 2030 target to at least 55% emissions reductions compared to 1990 was not just conjured from thin air. We did a thorough impact assessment, as I had promised to this House. I have to say I’m really impressed by the work the Commission services have done on this.  I know that this proposal goes too far for some, and for others not far enough, but the target is ambitious. We propose to reduce our emissions over the next decade by as much as we have achieved over the past quarter century. The target is well founded in science. It shows responsibility towards developing countries, but doesn’t take on an undue burden given the ambition needed from other industrial nations. I think it’s the right target. Just as important as the goal is the realisation that we’re in this together. The transition is just – has to be just or there will just be no transition.  We must help households in regions that are at risk of being left behind. We will soon propose a renovation wave to lower energy bills and fight energy poverty. We will continue developing our Just Transition Mechanism to deliver a new future to regions where the path towards climate neutrality is particularly steep. This is our message to the miners in Asturias, the workers on Baltic peatlands and many, many others. We will stand with you to make the journey to climate neutrality with us. Let me address the role of forests and other landscapes that remove CO2 from our atmosphere. The point of climate neutrality in 2050 is that by that year we must balance CO2 emissions with removals – taking out what we put in, if you prefer a cruder expression. The sink in our forests is declining, shrinking. Rather than waiting for 2050 we want to recognise the role of natural carbon sinks now. Including the full sink in our climate target in line with our international obligations will drive us to take better care of our forests and sinks so that they can play this vital role and also give an opportunity to rural communities. This is no accounting trick or cheat code: it’s the reality of how we neutralise the negative impact of human activity on our planet and care for our natural habitat. Honourable Members, you have discussed for many months how to fix the pathway between 2030 and 2050, including an intermediate target for 2040. There is criticism of our proposal to use delegated acts to check whether we’re on track for that pathway. Let me repeat today, and you know this is my opinion: what counts is that we reach our goals. I’m open to discuss which instruments should get us there. Please help me find a solution that we can all support.  Tomorrow you will vote on turning our climate ambitions into binding law. The Commission will be an honest broker for negotiations between Parliament and Council. We will push for an ambitious seven—year budget to finance our climate ambitions, but I want to thank Parliament, and Ms Guteland in particular, already for the work on this historic piece of legislation, the Climate Law. Ambitious climate action is what we need in Europe today and in the world. Let’s set our pathway towards climate neutrality as quickly as possible and start walking along this path together as quickly as possible.

name: Tilly METZ
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. – Madam President, for months, and even years, youngsters have taken to the streets and called for action on climate change. Now, when these same young people have started to vote, we are witnessing green waves, country by country. Our youth knows what is the challenge of our time, but do we as current politicians? Today we have the chance to vote for something historic: the European Climate Law. This law will set the ambition for the EU’s climate actions in the coming decades. Transport and tourism are responsible for nearly a third of Europeans’ greenhouse gas emissions. Transport, and in particular maritime and aviation, is the only sector where emissions are still higher than in 1990, with more than a 25% increase.  I expect that the upcoming Mobility Strategy and the legislative proposals by the Commission will deeply transform the sector. This is crucial to stay below 1.5 degrees warming so that future generations will have a planet to live on. For that, Parliament needs to send a strong signal today and vote for the most ambitious, science—based targets.

name: Caroline ROOSE
text: rapporteur for opinion, REGI committee. Madam President, yesterday President Sassoli paid tribute to the victims of the bad weather and floods that have hit northern Italy and south-eastern France, where I live. Scientists are formal: these bad weathers will multiply if we do not act strongly against climate change. In my region and in Italy last November, there has already been floods. We must vote for a target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by at least 65% by 2030.  I would like those who refuse to listen to the scientists to come and explain to the people of my region that the lives of their loved ones do not count, that the destruction of their homes does not count, that you prefer to sacrifice their lives rather than a few points of growth.  The climate law must be compatible with the goal of the Paris agreement to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees, it is a matter of survival. The climate law is the first stone of the European Green Pact. As rapporteur of the Committee on Regional Development, I would like to stress the role that the territories have to play in the fight against climate change. We must help them by setting ambitious targets and aligning European funds with this objective. By directing investments to solutions, we can create quality jobs that cannot be relocated to our regions. We have a duty to do everything we can to prevent the disastrous effects of climate change. Let's listen to the scientists, listen to the young people on the street, let's live up to our challenges.

name: Asger CHRISTENSEN
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture. Madam President! The Climate Act will make a big impact on the green transition over the next 30 years. It is important for the European Union to take the lead in leading the way with the green transition. The Liberals are in favour of an ambitious target by 2030 of a 65 percent reduction for all Member States. I have been responsible in the Committee on Agriculture and contributed to the Climate Act. Agriculture, the environment and climate are each other's prerequisites, not each other's opposites. That is why we need concrete solutions on the table.  I propose that the European Union should support farmers in absorbing CO2 into the soil. There is huge potential if we establish a separate quota system to suck and store CO2 in the ground. This creates opportunities to finance the green transition. I have tabled an amendment on this which I hope we will be able to vote through tomorrow. We also need common standards in order to be able to measure the farmer's climate footprint by a joint assessment of a climate accounting. The agricultural sector will make a major contribution to the green transition, but it must not harm food security or push production out of the EU. My proposal on food safety is included in the Report of the Committee on the Environment.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Climate change is similar to the Corona crisis, which unfortunately still concerns us all. If you really realise how bad it is, it's too late. That is why we must take precautions. We must act in good time, and we must indeed listen to science. It is quite clear that everyone around the world must do more to avoid dangerous climate change, to prevent our children and grandchildren from living in a world where they can no longer control climate change. I would therefore like to thank everyone who has helped, especially mairead McGuinness, with the PPE-DE, who I hope will be chosen tomorrow in a different task. But I would like to thank the European Commission in particular – Mr Timmermans and Ursula von der Leyen and everyone else. The European Commission has presented a truly ambitious target for 2030 and also for 2050. I do not allow this to be trivialised. No other major economy in the world is even beginning in the direction in which the European Commission wants to go, and the Commissioner – I am pleased to see you healthy again here, Mr Executive Vice-President; Last week in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Energy, I am sorry to say that you were in quarantine, and you explained very well why this objective is Paris-compatible. My speaking time has expired, so please go back to that at the end! What the Commission is proposing is Paris-compatible. As an argument from the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Public Health , I only ever hear against the Commission's proposal as an argument for the 60% against the Commission's proposal: this is tactical. The Council may be pushing us down, and that is why we must now vote for something higher. But firstly, the Council is already qualified at 55%, and secondly, we cannot say to people who are concerned about their jobs, in the steel industry, in the automotive supply industry, etc., 'we did not mean that, that was just tactics'. Let us vote in favour of what we mean, and that is the Commission's proposal: 55%!

name: Nicolás GONZÁLEZ CASARES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, this Law is a historic milestone. We are faced with the legal basis that will guide us to climate neutrality in 2050, the cornerstone of the European Green Pact and our fight against climate change. The Climate Law will require us to revise other regulations, to increase our renewables, energy efficiency and network connections objectives ⸺ we will do so in the ITRE Commission, which we are also progressive⸺, also to improve policies that preserve our biodiversity. It is an opportunity for a committed Europe, state to state, with a new clean economy.  I would like to thank Vice-President Timmermans and certainly my Socialist Group, and the rapporteur, Jytte Guteland, and all the groups who believe it is time to act. We're going to set the pace for our planet to slow down its warming and comply with the Paris Agreement. This Law will be the demonstration of Europe's leadership, in view of the forthcoming international climate summits; others are already starting to go our way. The current crisis should not be a brake on ambition. We must demonstrate this with this Law, and in passing show thousands and thousands of young Europeans who made their voices heard on the streets that we are with them. Its future is Europe.  One last thought. There is no plausible climate ambition without social justice. We will vote for ambition and realism. We have already shown that the economy can improve while reducing emissions. Let's do it together by supporting who costs you the most. There is no Green Pact with no red heart. We must recover by driving a new clean and innovative economy, while just and supportive. I ask the Council, the Commission and this Parliament not to delay this appointment any longer, let us not keep The Earth waiting any longer.

name: Pascal CANFIN
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Madam President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I think it is safe to say that we will all remember this moment when we are older. We voted for the first European Climate Act. We have carved climate neutrality for 2050. And we were the first continent in the world to do that.  Three years ago, three countries started this battle: France, Sweden and Luxembourg. It was a very small minority and in three years they managed to convince everyone and here no one even mentioned the fact that we are going to be the first in the world to do so, it has become so obvious that the debate is now behind us. So we have to measure how far we have come and look forward to it. The second point is that obviously the 2030 target must be consistent with this climate neutrality target and here we, the environment committee within the Renew Group, believe that we can get a majority around 60%. And there are people on the European right who are more progressive than others, and if we really want to have at least 55% as the final point of negotiation with the Member States, we, as parliamentarians, must do politics, do tactics and send the most ambitious message possible with a majority. This most ambitious message possible is 60% which is why we support it and I hope that colleagues from the PPP, the right and the European centre-right will join this majority and win tomorrow in the plenary of Parliament. A final word: adaptation to climate change is fundamental, all European territories are concerned, farmers who are experiencing droughts, people living through floods, rising waters on the coasts, this European law is still too weak on adaptation, that is why we have tabled an amendment, to stop spending European money if we do not test the capacity of the big projects that we finance to adapt , to be resilient to climate change. I hope that the whole of this House will be able to support this amendment tomorrow, which is absolutely fundamental, both for the climate, for the territories and for the proper use of public money.

name: Sylvia LIMMER
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The European Climate Act: according to the Commission, it is at the heart of a complete transformation not only of our economy, but of our entire society– which is now called by its name.  In future, no law may be enacted without prior examination of whether it might not be contrary to the same climate law. Even retrospectively, existing regulations will be examined and, if necessary, amended.  This law is the mother of all laws: poisonous and eerily green-dictatorial. Instead of creating a stable legal framework for a prosperous economy, a complacent, fact-free emergency elite with "ambitious" targets: 40, 55 or 60% greenhouse gas reduction, often a little more. Eat it whatever it wants. And that can be taken literally here.  Last year, the Commission's fine print said that 40% reduction means an additional annual cost of EUR 260 billion over the next ten years. It is now said that an additional EUR 350 billion a year is needed for this green diktat: EUR 610 billion a year.  Meanwhile, the jobs are crumbling, no, the jobs are breaking away in the tens of thousands of german key technology, the automotive industry and its suppliers. I am curious to see whether the Green CDU/CSU MEMBERS of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats will take care of this. As if there were no chemistry or physics, one swears by the improvement of air quality in greenhouse gas reduction and conceals the fact that it stinks enormously under the supposedly CO2-free mantle of renewable energies, not only when it comes to the catastrophic mining conditions – far away – from lithium, cobalt, manganese and the like. The emperor is naked, ladies and gentlemen, and no one looks.

name: Michael BLOSS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, we only have one planet, one house, and it’s on fire – in Portugal, in California, in Siberia we are burning this planet. We must take bold steps, but the conservatives in the House are weighing economic costs against people’s lives. People’s lives, like the life of Vlad Petru. He’s a farmer from Romania. He says there is no longer enough water for his cattle and sheep to drink. He should seek water higher in the mountains, but above 2 000 m there is only the sky.  People’s lives like the life of Sanna Vanar. She is from the Saami culture from Sweden and the culture is based on the cultivation of reindeer, but the reindeer are on the verge of getting extinct due to the climate crisis. Sanna says: ‘if we lose the reindeer, we lose the Saami culture too.’ We are here in the European Parliament; we are here to represent them and we can do something about their future. With our vote today, we can show that we listen to science. We can vote today to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees by reducing our toxic CO2 emissions by 65%. Dear colleagues, we are not voting on numbers here today. We are voting on the future of Vlad Petru, of Sanna Vanar and of many others lives. I will become a father in December. We are also voting today on the future of my children and on the future of our children. We are the first generation to suffer from the climate crisis, but we are also the last generation to stop it. So let’s start listening to science, let’s give hope to the younger generation, and let’s stop this climate crisis. (Applause)

name: Klára DOBREV
text: Congratulations on your child, but I would like to ask the group not to show photos in the Parliament.

name: Anna ZALEWSKA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. –Yes, this is a historic moment, a moment of our parliamentary responsibility. Yes, we promised to protect the environment, water, air, but we promised accountability, the use of facts and consistency. Yes, we think about what in 10 years, in 20, in 30, but we have to think about what next year, what in two and three.  When you read the impact assessment carefully – although it does not answer many cases – you will find that there is a carefree talk about how unemployment will rise, how energy poverty will rise, how the price of water, rubbish and finally the price of energy will rise. We did not promise this to our citizens. We promised our citizens European solidarity and respect for the Treaties. And what do we do? Our prime ministers, presidents, have agreed in the European Council that we will be talking about zero emission at European Union level. Climate law says the exact opposite. We promised that we would be sensible. A dozen or so months ago, we heard from the Environment Agency that we were not able to meet the ambitious 40% target and we are already talking about 55%, knowing what will happen to the price of allowances, because that has happened. During the pandemic, the price of a tonne of carbon dioxide almost doubled. We promised to cut red tape. And what? We have a new tool, a new institution, in addition uncounted. No one knows what they're going to do. We are being seedued by the slogan that these will be scientists who will– again this is incompatible with the Treaties – support the Commission in taking away the rights of the Member States. Finally, let us say this to farmers. I don't know if Franz Timmermans – I asked him recently when we were concerned about his health – or if he had already spoken to his Dutch farmers. Talk to them, count the greenhouse budget with them. Not only do we think that they are the only ones responsible for implementing the biodiversity strategy, the field-to-table strategy, we are still telling them to count, we are telling them to hire accountants and increase bureaucracy. Yes, we are responsible and we will confirm this with our vote.

name: Silvia MODIG
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, we are the group of decision-makers who have the opportunity and the duty to take decisions to tackle climate change. Future decision-makers will no longer have the opportunity to do so, because we are running out of time. This autumn, record temperatures have been measured again in my country, Finland. This week, plants blossomed that have never bloomed at this time of year. Climate change is real and if we do not make sufficient decisions, the economic and human cost will be enormous.  We are facing a decision that will either keep us on the side of the Paris Agreement or not. The Commission's proposal does not do so. Moreover, in 2030, the Commission changed the emission reduction target to a net target, which means that the actual emission reduction is far below the 55% proposed by the Commission. According to various estimates, it is up to 3-10% lower. This solution shows a real level of ambition on the part of the Commission, which is too low. The Commission's proposal is well below the scientific recommendation, no matter how much the Commission tries to speak black and white. Industry and industry have asked for certainty about the regulatory environment in the coming years, so that they can develop their own activities accordingly and that investment be directed correctly. This is extremely important for the preservation of jobs and for the creation of new ones.  The Commission's proposal creates uncertainty. Too low ambition today means that we will have to correct the target forcefully upwards in the years to come. This is much more difficult and costly for everyone than setting a level with sufficient ambition already. Because whether we like it or not, climate change is moving forward regardless of what we think.  In committee, a clear majority supported a 60% reduction in emissions for 2030. Now that the Commission has further weakened its proposal, it is of the utmost importance that this plenary should raise the ambition of the motion. In order to have a chance of surviving climate change, we cannot go below that 60% and keep our word to the millions of Europeans for whom we promised ambitious and adequate emission reduction targets in the elections. The Commission did not keep its word, but this House has the opportunity to rectify this by voting in favour of a good report that is changing.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a 65 % reduction in emissions by 2030 would save the European Union more than EUR 10 trillion in avoided environmental damage. How many floods and landslides, such as those that have occurred in recent days in Piedmont, Liguria, Lombardy and valle d'Aosta, we still have to witness to understand that the climate crisis is ongoing and that action needs to be taken now? The European climate law that we are about to vote on must be ambitious and courageous. And to all those who, even here in this Parliament, continue to deny the evidence and try to sink this law or de-lactate commitments with various tricks, completely ignoring science and citizens, I say that you are out of history. Investing in a zero-carbon economy today can generate millions of jobs: 18 million in the world according to the ILO. So there are no more excuses! But be ware: a serious path to climate neutrality cannot allow the financing of infrastructure projects with a strong environmental impact, such as the TAV. A hole in the mountain to pass a train for which construction work would pour more than ten million tons of CO2 into the atmosphere, and the first kilogram of CO2 saved will not be until 2040, when it will be far too late.

name: Adam JARUBAS
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Today we must take responsibility for our common future, the future of our children, and we must take this decision at a particularly difficult time for Europe at a time of unprecedented economic crisis and pandemic threatening our health and life. We are called to act by young people – those to whom the future will belong – and we owe it to them.  Today, we support the world's most ambitious plan to combat climate change, significantly reducing emissions here and now. We do this by taking care of the economy, about jobs. Before our eyes, in parallel with the fight against climate change, there is a global, not only Pan-European, industrial revolution. In order to keep up with the changes, we already need to build jobs for the future today, but at the same time we must ensure that no one is left alone in the back without support. It is therefore necessary to create effective mechanisms for a just transition. We are voting today on climate law, which speaks of the objectives we want to achieve, but we must not forget that this is only part of the European Green Deal, which must be the flywheel of our economy.

name: Alessandra MORETTI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Vice-President Timmermans, thanks to this regulation, Europe will be the first continent to achieve climate neutrality by 2050 at the latest. The climate law is the first law in the world and is a translation of our political commitment, which puts us irreversibly on the road to a more sustainable future. It is at the heart of the European Green Deal, offers predictability and transparency for industry and investors, guides our green growth strategy and ensures a smoother and fairer transition. We are turning words into actions, to show our fellow citizens that we are serious. The climate law is also a message to our international partners: this is the decisive year to raise the level of global ambition in the pursuit of the objectives contained in the Paris Agreement and to finally shake the consciences of those countries, primarily the United States and China, which have so far shirked their responsibilities. I am very proud that Parliament and the Commission have acted quickly. I actually expected a little more ambition from the Commission. But I hope that Parliament, in today's vote, and the Member States in the subsequent steps, will be guided in their future choices not by selfishness but by science. Today, more than ever, we cannot afford to fail and the pandemic has plastically highlighted how indissoluble the correlation between the environment and health is. The lockdown, if there is one, can no longer delay the implementation of the European Green Deal: the recovery will only be successful if it is green and it is our responsibility to implement a development strategy that provides for a fair and just transition for all. We must vote firmly on this law, remain consistent with our ideals and vote on an ambitious text.

name: María Soraya RODRÍGUEZ RAMOS
text: – Madam President, the year 2020 stopped, but the climate crisis did not, and neither did the European Parliament. Today we transfer to the legal system our commitments under the Paris Agreement. This Climate Law marks a clear and ambitious roadmap, a stable and predictable legal framework for economic operators, certainty, and also recognition of our citizens' right to a healthy and livable planet. This Climate Law, in a deep economic crisis marked by COVID, must help us ensure that all economic growth and job recovery are marked by climate action, and that European recovery funds are invested in clean technologies, innovation and new technologies. Today, ladies and gentlemen, this Climate Law bridges the gap between scientific warnings and political action. Today this Parliament aligns with science. Today we also reconcile with our children.

name: Silvia SARDONE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are all aware of climate change, nature conservation and the urgent need to protect the environment; we are all on the front line, indiscriminately. But the European Union's approach, let me tell you, Europe has a somewhat ideological approach, is a bit succumbed to Greta's slogans and has a potentially damaging approach to the continent. Yes, I said harmful. Because your policies risk draining economies in the face of results that, frankly, are negligible in terms of reducing emissions. Let us be clear: in order to achieve the results you have in mind, you are in fact forced to impose ethical or green taxes, which are a real sledgelaught, which will have a very serious impact on companies and workers with relocations, impoverishments and lower wages. Let me give you an example: in Italy, applying this regulation in the manner and within the time frame that you envisage means bringing new taxes, new bureaucracy, sacrificing entire Italian production chains, in favour of whom? Of what? Chinese scooters, French or German cars equipped with Chinese batteries! In short, you have in mind sustainable development – as defined – but it only applies to European countries, because you are totally silent with Asian countries, such as India and China, with which you continue to enter into trade agreements without saying absolutely anything, and I say nothing, about the environment! So we are in an economic crisis, in Europe stronger than elsewhere. What are you guys doing? Push for measures that risk amplifying this crisis. Think! Is this not the time for new taxes and obligations and, among other things, for whom? Of those who struggle to move forward.  This is not to protect the environment, but it is an environmental ideology made up of European bureaucrats.

name: Marie TOUSSAINT
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the subsequent droughts have had a dramatic impact on the lives of my family and the lives of many European citizens. These are not my words, they are those of Maurice Feschet, a simple farmer from the Drômoise region, who had the courage to file a complaint in 2018 against the European Union's climate inaction. I want to make his voice heard here because it is, for me, the symbol of all those who see their lives very strongly affected by climate change, those who see their lives threatened by natural disasters caused by our development model, those who ultimately count so little. Because what are we talking about when we talk about the climate law? Numbers? No, we're talking about life, people's lives, the lives of our people to protect them. We don't have time to wait anymore. The next ten years are crucial: storms, drought, threatened glaciers, entire territories plunged into energy insecurity require action that is equal to the dangers. To save the climate, it is at least 65%, ladies and gentlemen, that we must aim for 2030. Everybody knows that! Setting goals at a discount, therefore, makes no sense. Let's be responsible, let's be realistic.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: I have to ask you again not to show pictures and placards in the Chamber. The groups have decided that we use the power of language in this Chamber, so please do not do it again. Thank you very much.

name: Grzegorz TOBISZOWSKI
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. Climate concern should be one of the European Union's priorities. And it is. And this is not subject to discussion, and should not be discussed. However, we should bear in mind that this industry is still a major factor in Europe's development and prosperity. That is why the European Union has rightly set itself the objective of increasing industrial production to account for at least 20% in 2000 (now 15-16%). Ensuring continuity, consistency of Union law and predictability for industry is a minimum of achieving this objective. In 2014, the European Union set an emissions reduction target of at least 40% by 2030. It was only a few years ago that it agreed on how to achieve this goal, but on the European Commission's website we have expert reports which say that it will be difficult to achieve 40%. So the question arises: Why don't we analyze first, why is there a problem in achieving goals, and we make new assumptions? How is the industry going to develop in this case, when the inconsistency of what we have so far with what we impose?

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Yes, if we are to make a climate law, then we must do it right. This means that we do not allow gas to enter this law at any point, that we put gas on it. What we have to put in place are renewables, and they are consistent. Gas is not a bridge technology, but an investment in fossil fuels. Honestly, gas is about as climate-friendly as, say, cola light is healthy. Methane emissions, CO2 emissions – that's what gas stands for, and cola light is a risk for diabetes. I therefore urge you to vote against every single amendment that bets on gas and tries to let it in through the back door.  Let us be clear: we need consistent, courageous steps for climate protection. We need real energy efficiency methods in our homes, in all buildings. We need strong infrastructure for renewables and, above all, we also need to combat energy poverty. What we also need to do is stop talking about technology neutrality, so that fossil fuels are no longer favoured. One thing is certain, as we see with this law: the market does not judge everything on its own, and certainly not when it comes to climate neutrality.

name: Antoni COMÍN I OLIVERES
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, there is a European Union that disappoints us, which is the one that, when assessing the rule of law, is silent before the political prisoners of the Spanish State. But there is also the Eu ropean Union giving us hope, and the European law on climate change is the best example of this. It is perhaps the most important law of the entire mandate, one of the most transcendent that this Parliament has ever voted for. We celebrate the fact, among other things, that it incorporates some of our amendments. The Climate Neutral Union in 2050 and we want to achieve this project without endangering either the competitiveness of our companies or the cohesion of our societies. On the contrary, this historic transition must help us build an economy that is not only greener but also more egalitarian and efficient. Let us make the new Green Deal an opportunity to transform European society so that it becomes a fairer society. And we no longer have time: the Paris Agreement may seem very ambitious when we think about the work ahead. But it is a de minimis objective if we think from the point of view of science. We are behind schedule and we must act immediately!

name: Dolors MONTSERRAT
text: – Madam President, the fight against climate change is everyone's task. We support the European Union's efforts and leadership to undertake a transformation towards a more circular, clean, responsible economy that takes care of our health and takes care of our planet.  The European Union must lead the fight against climate change, but without losing sight of the competitiveness of business and job creation. There are many protagonists of this transition: workers, employers, freelancers, farmers, fishermen, transporters, young people, all families. All the measures we take must be taken with all the protagonists, with dialogue, seeking social acceptance and with help.  We've been talking about reinforcing industrial policy for a long time. Today there are two thousand workers on strike in Spain for the closure of the intensive aluminum production plant in Galicia. One of the reasons for the closure has to do with energy costs. European industry cannot continue to bleed to death, especially exposed by unfair competition from third countries. Therefore, we need to accelerate the clean economy, digitisation, but we must also strengthen our industrial bases and strategic autonomy, so that the weight of industry reaches 20% of the total national wealth of the Member States: it is compatible. We must take concrete action already, being consistent in setting new climate targets, and we cannot act as if the COVID-19 pandemic and Brexit do not exist. Right now, especially difficult, let's not leave anyone behind.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: – Madam President, allow me to say thank you to our rapporteur Jytte Guteland for her work, because this is the time to decide whether we are serious about embarking on a sustainable path towards climate neutrality by 2050 or whether what we had in this House was only political rhetoric. How we vote on the climate law today will define us. The climate crisis we are facing will not go away on its own, nor will it be solved by individual action alone. So we must reduce carbon pollution and transform our economy to run on clean renewable energy. This is not about elitists, as we heard today. This is about realists who are seeing with their eyes the impact of climate change all around us. That’s why this political group is being progressive and realistic in pushing forward a 60% CO2 reduction by 2030.  S&D are pushing also for a new climate target for 2040 because we want to provide direction for our Member States, our industries and our citizens. From the very beginning we were at the forefront in asking for a climate law that can put us strongly on the path to ditch fossil fuels and switch to clean energy whilst sustaining a resilient, robust economy.  We need these laws to make sure that we are on track with our targets for 2030, for 2040 and for ensuring carbon neutrality in 2050. Just having vague goals on paper did not work, and they will definitely not work. We know some lawmakers will refuse to act. They would rather risk climate catastrophe and let the rest of us deal with the fallout. But this is not acceptable for us. We want to make sure that we start acting today and make our societies and our continent future proof. Today and tomorrow we have the opportunity to prove that.  (Applause)

name: Frédérique RIES
text: Madam President, last December President von der Leyen referred to Europe's 'man on the moon' moment. Well here we are. This is the first step. I continue in French, but a little in the lunar metaphor all the same. Tonight, when we pass the amendments to the climate law, Europe will take a giant step to give itself the means to become in 2050 the first continent to achieve carbon neutrality. It is historic, it has been said. Negotiations with the Council are expected to be tough and I am already hearing from them here now that they want to weaken our ambitions and cap our CO2 reduction target for 2030 at 55% net. I think, of course, that to have the means to weigh is to aim for 60%. More broadly and quickly now, it is the vote, the package of the Committee on the Environment simply that must be supported tonight, namely a carbon budget for 2023, a European Council for climate change and a minimum of EUR 100 per tonne of carbon when The Member States do not comply with the objectives of the regulation on the allocation of effort.  This week's catastrophic floods in south-eastern France and northern Italy are a stark reminder of this: we have no option but to be ambitious in the face of the climate emergency.

name: Catherine GRISET
text: Madam President, everything in this law, from its legislative background to its content, needs to be reviewed. The 60% emission reduction target by 2030 is not scientifically sound. Its binding nature at the state level does not respect their sovereignty or the principle of subsidiarity, and one wonders what the sanctions regime will be.  As for the European carbon budget, how will it be calculated and who will determine it? Your eagerness to make Europe the first carbon-neutral continent is ideological. Our current trajectory of 40% is already almost impossible to achieve. By increasing it to 60%, you will impose a punitive ecology on businesses and households weakened by the crisis, solely to the benefit of our competitors. We must give ourselves the means of our ambitions: the use of nuclear power, confidence in technological innovation, the fight against unfair foreign competition and a gradual energy transition taking into account national realities. Climate neutrality must come from a collective effort at the state level, guided by legitimate ecological concerns but also by the interest of our peoples.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur, who is there, for her excellent report, which I think is really setting the right ambition level.  In this House last year we all signed up to the climate emergency. In this House, time and time and again, we signed up to climate neutrality in 30 years’ time. Now in the Climate Law we are going to act – and suddenly you see people getting nervous. Maybe they didn’t realise what they were signing up to because it was just a resolution. But that’s not how politics works. If you sign up to these targets you also have to translate it into a binding law, which we are discussing now for 2030.  Talking about science, it is very clear, and the United Nations Gap Report states very clearly, that if you want to maintain a chance on 1.5°, staying below that, the world needs to reduce by 67% – the world. This means an additional challenge for Europe. Maybe a last point on the challenges for industry. I also would like to hope that the EPP is a bit consistent, because we have been fighting international offsets under the Kyoto Protocol together and now I see amendments of the EPP Group bringing back these international offsets and further watering down the targets we are discussing. I think this is really a problem. Please, EPP, stay a bit consistent for once.

name: Robert ROOS
text: Mr President, we always talk about democracy with great words, but in the meantime this European Parliament is about to agree to the European Climate Law. This will deprive the climate goals of national democratic decision-making.  First, there has been no emergency exit in this law for 30 years to take into account economic adversity or new technological insights.  Secondly, NGOs can go to court to align the policy with these goals. This situation, Mr Timmermans, we in the Netherlands know about the Urgenda case and the nitrogen ruling. The judge takes over the role of politics. And that is not how we see democracy.  We MEPs have a mandate from the electorate to represent him in this house in a good way. Policy, and also climate policy, should be the subject of a permanent democratic debate and not be enshrined for 30 years.

name: Manuel BOMPARD
text: Madam President, a year ago, our Parliament declared a state of climate and environmental emergency. Since then, the events before our eyes have demonstrated the consequences of this emergency. It is the droughts that dry up the rivers of our childhood, the forests that burn all over the world, the floods that have recently ravaged the south of France and Italy. Today, we can live up to this situation, we must set in the Climate Act a target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by at least 65% by 2030. This figure is not taken by chance, it is the one that, according to the United Nations, allows us to meet our international commitments and limit the rise in temperature to 1.5oC.  To do this, we must include a reduction that does not include reductions by absorption of natural carbon sinks. We must say this frankly and clearly to Mrs von der Leyen, we do not have time today for the small entourloupes and calculations which aim to mask a lack of ambition and to satisfy some well-placed economic interests. We don't have time to wait, we have to act now, we don't have time to play so let's live up to the situation.

name: Edina TÓTH
text: – Madam President, climate change and environmental damage pose a serious threat to Europe and the world as a whole. That is why it is important to be ambitious and make Europe the world's first climate-neutral continent. The adoption of the EU climate regulation before us can confirm that not only some Member States, but also the EU itself, are really taking action to protect our world created in the fight against climate change. However, it does not matter in what form we do this. Firstly, I would like to point out that, unfortunately, the Commission's latest impact assessment has not shown the effects at Member State level, so detailed modelling will have to be carried out, which, of course, will take time. It is important that Member States follow good examples in order to achieve common goals. Hungary, for example, is at the forefront of achieving the agreed emission reduction targets. However, ladies and gentlemen, there is one point that we cannot give in to. We insist that families should not be made to pay for the costs instead of the climate destroyers. Food and energy prices should be avoided. In order to meet the climate neutrality target, all economic sectors must act. However, we must not allow industrial operators to be incapable of making it impossible. However, it is also important to implement EU climate protection measures at national level and to include targeted steps in a workable single framework.

name: Delara BURKHARDT
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which With the Climate Act, we have the great task of laying the foundation of the Green Deal. Our proposal greatly improves the Commission's proposal – with an EU greenhouse gas budget that clearly shows how much more emissions the EU can emit in the coming years, an independent climate council that provides scientific support and advice. When it comes to the question of how much more ambition we should have on the road to climate neutrality, things get heated here in the House. Even with the at least 55% proposed by Mrs von der Leyen by 2030, it is worth looking at the fine print. For the first time, it talks about a net target that includes the positive climate performance of forests. If we deduct that, we are only at a weak 52%. However, it is important to save today in order to avoid climate tipping points and climate damage tomorrow. According to climate science, this represents a target of around 65%. In terms of circumstances, 60% is already a great political success, which will also strengthen our negotiating position later on. It is also feasible if we stop pitting employment and climate protection against each other and tackle the necessary change. Let me put it this way: 2050 always sounds so far away, but this is the time when my generation is not even retired.
