So it is now important to tackle and get the right instruments in place, because we have no time left to lose.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: I should like to inform Members that due to the partial unavailability of interpreters from Ireland because of the travel limitations, there will be no interpretation from and to Gaelic guaranteed today from 16.15 until 17.15.

name: Claudia GAMON
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The European Climate Act is the first major and important step towards climate neutrality. It is also an acknowledgment of reality, which is bleak, but not hopeless. We must now move from the objectives to really bold implementation steps, so that we will also achieve climate neutrality. We need a smart carbon-balancing mechanism to prevent us from simply shifting emissions to other countries, because ultimately we will have to protect the climate globally. And just because we have a nice statistic in Europe, we will not have saved anything. We must immediately include road transport and buildings in emissions trading, so that it also becomes a powerful instrument, and we must make use of the full potential of technological innovation and also make energy storage a priority, so that we can make the energy transition a reality. I believe that if we adopt a bold emission reduction target, we will be happy to pat ourselves on the back for a day, but tomorrow the work must continue. After all, it is only now beginning, and there is still some persuasion to be done, including in the Council.

name: Laura HUHTASAARI
text: – Mr President, if finns had known in the 1990s that the EU was also going to control Finland's forests when they voted for EU membership, there would be no Finnish meppies here. The EU's climate action must not lead to Finnish forests having to compensate when Germany and Poland burn coal.  But there are good things about this Climate Law, for example, taking into account the climate benefits of renewable materials and changing the winning products, from massive wood construction to microscopic nano-back. Another good thing here is that we are trying to combat industrial carbon leakage. Europe has the cleanest industry in the world and that is why the workplace here is an act of climate change.

name: Pär HOLMGREN
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for In fact, when I stand here today, I am both surprised and rather frustrated. Surprised that there is still, at least among some in here, so great lack of knowledge and insight into the climate issue. But also frustrated that there are so many of you who use political rhetoric that is far, far from what science shows is required. Do you believe – above all, I am now addressing my colleagues in the right-wing group – that you really have the expertise behind you? Or do you deliberately choose to lie when you say that the little that you want to contribute would be enough? Because it's not.  Today, however, we have a chance to do something that is really important. We know what it takes to do that. That is to vote for a proposal that will ensure that we reduce emissions by absolutely at least 65% by 2030. And then all the tools needed to get there, such as a proper carbon budget. It is the least we can do, even the least we have to do. We have a chance to make a difference today. Take that chance. Maybe it's the last time we have such a chance.

name: Hermann TERTSCH
text: – Madam President, when we hear about science, we always think, coming from the left, that it is ideology, and that is what happens ⸺ we are seeing it in Spain continuously⸺: how they protect themselves behind the supposed science, to make barbarities, all possible arbitrariness with ideology. The debate on the European Climate Law already shows the weaknesses of a European Union which is subject to the dictates of a new and reinforced green ideology or religion. This climatic submission to the European Union, in the midst of a pandemic, with immense problems, will not bring stability or legal certainty or a long-term vision based on this scientific evidence. Of course, neither sovereignty is respected, subsidiarity is not respected and common sense is not respected, and, in the end, above all, the interests of Europeans, which are not taking into account when playing with emissions caps, are not respected; you're talking about a reduction by 55, then a 60, then who knows, if in a 70. That is disrespect for the interests of the Peoples of Europe. That's not science, it's pure ideology.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Madam President, setting a 55% net target for 2030 is climate change denial. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) has said that in the gap between 1.5 and 2 degrees, hundreds of millions of lives are at stake. A target of 55% would mean the EU has given up on any chance of limiting global temperature rises to 1.5 degrees.  To avoid climate breakdown, we have to cut world emissions at least in half by 2030, and get to zero by 2050. But this is a global average target. Given their greater responsibility for historic emissions, the better—off nations – like in Europe – must do it a lot faster. Setting a climate neutrality target for 2050 is also a climate change denial. Climate neutrality is not a decarbonising strategy. Why are we continuing to prop up the fossil fuel industry? We need real zero carbon emissions by 2040 and we cannot rely on negative emissions technologies that might never even exist. Scientists say that we will fail if we keep growing the economy at the same rate. GDP may speak for the welfare of capitalism but not for the welfare of humanity.

name: Markus PIEPER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Environment, economy, jobs: The road to climate neutrality offers us a great opportunity to deliver innovation for world markets with European know-how. With a 55% reduction in CO2 emissions by 2030, we are challenging people and businesses. We must take them with us, see climate protection as an opportunity, tackle the whole thing with a positive spirit.  This optimism includes openness to technology. But those who ban internal combustion engines today are building europe's future for the synthetic age. Positive innovation involves looking beyond Europe's borders. But anyone who says today that we must not combine climate investment with development aid is sinning against Africa's future is partly responsible for migration for economic reasons. The positive view of climate protection includes a market economy, not bans and quotas. No. Instead, emission allowances in line with the Paris guidelines; the rest is regulated by the economy and its workers. I know, ladies and gentlemen of S&D, Renew Europe, Verts/ALE and GUE/NGL: thinking positively and freely, this is not your world. They trust themselves more than the people and the businesses. They claim, against better knowledge, that only 60 or 70% of the world does not go down. Don't you want to argue any more? Do you want to intimidate when you paint the end of the world on the wall?  No, ladies and gentlemen, do not intimidate and frighten. Arguing and taking it with you – this is lived democracy, also in climate protection. That is what the PPE-DE stands for.

name: Mohammed CHAHIM
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Timmermans, with this climate law we are going to distribute the costs of the energy transition fairly, lead by example and make our climate targets binding. For me, it is very important that the biggest polluters make the biggest contribution, because we must not blame the costs of the energy transition on our people. This is still the case to this day.  Energy producers responsible for more than 80% of greenhouse gases in the Netherlands pay less tax on their emissions than ordinary households. And an OECD study shows that in the Netherlands we pay an average of EUR 60 per tonne of CO2 and our industry is only EUR 15 per tonne, which is four times less. The cost of CO2 emissions is simply not distributed fairly. This can and must be done differently, and with this climate law we are taking the first step.  Mr President, there is a lot of discussion about interim climate targets. It's about 55, 60 or 65. There seems to be a 60% compromise in Parliament. I'm not entirely satisfied with that either. There's no reason not to listen to science. But I'm positive. With the investment programme of this Commission, with the European Green Deal of our Frans Timmermans, and with the innovative power of the business community, I am convinced that a higher goal is achievable and that by setting up, among other things, a hydrogen economy and a circular economy, we will be overtaken by practice.  Let's vote for the climate bill today. Let us send a clear message to our youth, our people and our business community.

name: Karin KARLSBRO
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for We have no time to lose. Europe needs a climate law that makes our ambitious climate targets legally binding today, preferably yesterday. The Liberals want a 65% reduction in emissions by 2030. But we also want to focus on how we get there; climate goals mean nothing without economically effective sustainable solutions.  That is why we say yes to a common carbon tax, yes to scrapping subsidies for fossil fuels, yes to investing heavily in research and new technologies, and we say yes to nuclear power and carbon storage as part of the solution. The United States has turned its back on the Paris Agreement. The EU is now doing exactly the opposite. The EU takes on the leader's jersey and gears up. That is why the Liberals say 'yes' to a strong Europe and 'yes' to an ambitious European climate policy.

name: Roman HAIDER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her When it comes to the demands for ever stricter climate targets, the EU institutions, political groups and NGOs outperform each other almost every week. Only one group is not thought of – namely, the citizens of Europe. To those citizens who live in the countryside and not in the big cities, and to those citizens who need their cars to get to work. In my own country, Austria, a study has calculated that the implementation of your objectives leads to a very real additional burden of EUR 1 541 for each citizen. For mobility alone, EUR 1 541, just to get to work. For EU bureaucrats with princely salaries, this is not a lot of money; for ordinary citizens, this is a great deal of money, all in the midst of the worst economic crisis in decades. People are facing unemployment, they do not know how to feed their families, and the European Union's recipes are to dismantle industry, jobs and burden citizens. Mr Timmermans, you are not leading the EU to the abyss, you are leading it into the abyss.

name: Grace O'SULLIVAN
text: – Madam President, the Climate Law is the main reason why my somewhat reluctant move into politics was actually the right move. Our vote here this evening is a culmination of calls for action from citizens across the globe who recognise the emergency we are in. We have to slash greenhouse gas emissions within a timeframe that gives us some hope of avoiding a total wipe—out of life on our planet. We must set a truly ambitious target that will create the change we need by 2030. The implementation of the Paris Agreement is essential to achieving the Sustainable Development Goals by 2030. No Paris, no SDGs.  We must have official, international, legally—binding commitments that see every single decision we make as individuals and as nations benchmarked against the goal of climate neutrality. Our survival depends upon this. (Applause)

name: Izabela-Helena KLOC
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab We need to talk about how serious politicians are, not like the participants in the youth climate strike. Let us talk specifically about the cost of climate policy and its victims. I will tell you what the price of the Green Deal is from the perspective of the people – the people of my region. The cost of creating new jobs for employees of the Polish Mining Group alone is PLN 200 billion. And we are talking about only one company, one of the largest in Europe. 140 billion will be missing to carry out the modernisation of Silesia. We will not get these funds from Brussels.  Several countries are making money from enforced technologies, and regions such as Silesia are expected to plunge into poverty and social crisis. There are countries whose climate transformation will cost nothing, other countries will cope with minimal effort. Poland, whose industry is most dependent on coal, will be economically and socially devastated, and the European Commission and some MEPs, instead of understanding us, are threatening to cut sanctions and threaten to cut funds. This is your justice!

name: Agnès EVREN
text: Madam President, this climate law provides two lessons. The first is the political will to take action to make the European Union the first continent in the world to achieve the goal of carbon neutrality by 2050. The second is that to achieve this, two visions clash. On the one hand, there are those who have an ambitious but realistic vision, as we do in the EPP with Peter Liese. The impact study we requested showed that a target of at least 55% was the most realistic route and provided visibility to our businesses and industries that will have to engage in this transition. So we support the 55% of course. On the other hand, there are those who are in the political display, it is the position of my colleagues Renew, Socialists, Greens or far left, it is that of a shallot race which consists of asking 5% more than its right-wing neighbour to appear as green, as ambitious as possible. The preservation of our jobs, the adaptation measures that our companies and industries will have to take, the risk of offshoring and therefore carbon leakage, all this comes after. Ladies and gentlemen, you will have understood that between these two visions, my choice is clear. I refuse to be in ideology, in political display or in incantations. The ecological transition engages us all, it must be credible to be achievable, it is the only condition for its success.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Madam President! Colleagues! The planet is overheated. Europe has a shared responsibility for this situation, which is why we must also take responsibility for resolving it. We need to act now before it is too late. That is also why we must have an ambitious European climate law. If we do not get it, then we will pass the bill on to future generations, and it will simply not work. That is why I am pleased to be able to vote in favour of the Report of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, because it sets an ambitious target for reduction by 2030. And we demand a new target. We want a target for 2040. We demand that both the EUROPEAN Union and the Member States take responsibility and have binding objectives.  I believe that this climate law and the way we do things in the European Parliament can help to ensure that we can both save the environment and safeguard future generations. I think it is absolutely crucial that the European Union, as one of the richest regions in the world, should take the lead and show the rest of the world that we must deal with this climate crisis. We can do it. If we do that, if we get this report through, then we can actually achieve that we change the Coal and Steel Union to become a climate union. What a great objective it is not for future generations to be able to say yes to. So thank you for that and vote for the Report of the Committee on the Environment. It is the one that is the most ambitious.

name: Ulrike MÜLLER
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for his work Over the last 30 years, we have been able to reduce our CO2 emissions by just over 20%. If we want to become climate neutral by 2050, it means that we will have to create 80% over the next 30 years. This will be a huge effort that poses huge challenges for our industry. In the sectors with the largest emissions, investments that will work until 2050 are already being decided. Planning security is fundamental here. I therefore very much welcome the anchoring of the long-term objective of a path to that end. However, we must plan this path with great care. For our innovative companies, a European showcase of "climate-friendly innovations" can be a great opportunity. But if we want too fast and too much, we will choke off the engine that has to get us to our destination. Hence a clear 'yes' to long-term objectives. However, the target path must be based on what is feasible.

name: Gianantonio DA RE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, with european climate law, the Commission is imposing on Member States the objective of zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2050. This constraint provides for tight monitoring by the Commission, as a pretext for genuine control of national policies. The objectives to be achieved are clear, but nothing is said about the social and economic costs that this will entail: think of the inevitable loss of competitiveness of our companies vis-off in relation to countries such as China, India and the United States, which do not agree with the climate objective; Our European industries, especially steel industries, are subject to energy costs that are impossible compared to their global competitors. The energy transition requires graduality, sharing and substantial economic aid, which our businesses do not have at the moment. The fight against climate change must take place by safeguarding our businesses and, above all, let us remember to save them from failure.

name: Jutta PAULUS
text: Madam President, you can see the stripes representing global warming on my mask and I must say to you, please fight every crisis. Fight the corona crisis, but fight the climate crisis with as much enthusiasm. I will continue in German. Madam President! I want to focus on methane emissions because they are so often overlooked. The Commission also expects the greenhouse gas intensity of methane to be outdated. Calculated over a 20-year period, it is more than 80 times as effective as CO2. That is why we need rapid and effective measures to reduce these emissions. We are waiting for the Commission's methane strategy. From what we know, the Commission only wants to count a little better than before, but it does not want to reduce emissions effectively. We cannot afford that in this climate crisis. In the energy sector, it would be very simple: we need regulation, plugging leaking pipelines, replacing valves, closing boreholes, replacing outdated equipment. But we must also go to agriculture, and this clearly shows that we have to get out of mass animal husbandry, otherwise we will not be able to control methane emissions.

name: Johan VAN OVERTVELDT
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, my delegation supports the goal of climate neutrality at EU level by 2050. Europe can play a leading role in the sustainable transition. Short- and long-term objectives are needed, not least to provide investors with more certainty.  Showing ambition is a good thing, but I am concerned about the bid that is clearly under way and which sometimes overlooks social and economic consequences, such as in connection with the increase in the emission reduction rate. Moreover, this Parliament expects each Member State to be – or should be – climate neutral by 2050, when we do not yet have an impact assessment at each Member State's level. Flanders, for example – and I would of course point out the great diversity among the Member States – is a small and densely populated region with extensive energy-intensive clusters on which literally hundreds of thousands of jobs depend.  I hear colleagues argue for an energy system based on renewable energy, but without nuclear energy, climate neutrality is an illusion. We are advocating and will continue to advocate for a viable and affordable climate policy that also puts prosperity and competitiveness first.

name: Alexander BERNHUBER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Climate protection is a major priority for me as a young person in particular, and the EU climate law is an important step. But if we take climate protection seriously, we must think across all continents and take all continents into account, because this is a global responsibility. For me, however, it makes little sense if we want to call for climate protection here on the one hand, but on the other hand we want to conclude trade agreements such as Mercosur. We are looking away at how thousands of hectares of rainforest are being burned down and dozens of ships with cheap meat coming to Europe – that is absurd. We must finally begin to rethink free trade, where climate protection plays a key role and where there is no risk of cheap imports for farmers or entrepreneurs. We do not need to be proud of the fact that we in the EU are entrusting a green mess on which we say that we are the most climate-friendly continent, but that we are moving any production to other continents, whether it is food or steel. This is neither credible nor contributes to climate protection. With regard to the climate law, I would like to say that the CO2 reduction targets set out in it must be realistic. A fictitious number poker, as we are doing here in this House, is neither to be respected nor does it bring anything to the economy or the citizen. Better, we set ourselves realistic, practical goals that we can achieve and exceed than overstated goals that we fail to achieve.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union has made clear commitments in several circumstances to combat climate change, and today we have the world's first climate law, which puts these commitments in black and white, in particular the trajectory that we must take in the coming years to achieve the goal of climate neutrality in 2050. This is an obligatory path, which must necessarily start with a more ambitious review of co2 emission reduction targets in 2030. That is why we are calling for a reduction of at least 65 %. We are facing a health emergency and we cannot afford to find ourselves, earlier than science already tells us today, in a real climate emergency with equally devastating effects. Moving now, with determination and ambition, is the only way to ensure sustainable growth for future generations. After all, this is the right time to act: the unprecedented crisis caused by the coronavirus has accelerated what was already felt as the need to radically revise our development model. Today we have on the table the largest economic aid package in the history of the European Union and we must use these resources intelligently and forward-lookingly, to launch a new economic, social and environmental paradigm. That is why we need clear legislation, such as the climate law that we are adopting today, with precise timetables and objectives, which will tell us what direction Europe intends to take and on which it does not intend to go backwards. I stress, you do not intend to go back!

name: Barry ANDREWS
text: – Madam President, I’m very happy to support the EU Climate Law today. I’m delighted that the European Union is providing global leadership in achieving the targets of the Paris Agreement and providing legal certainty. Despite the difficulties this might cause in my country, in Ireland, I will be supporting the 60% target for emissions reductions. I do so for a number of reasons, but one I wish to call out. By 2050, the global population will have reached 9 billion; that’s up from 7 billion today. And those 2 billion new citizens will not live in the EU or in developed countries; they will live in developing countries. They will live in parts of developing countries that are vulnerable to environmental shocks: on hillsides, in river deltas. So, what we need to do is to acknowledge that these new citizens will live with the greatest vulnerabilities associated with climate change, having contributed the least, and that is the essence of climate justice based on human rights. So, in this Parliament, in 2020, we have an opportunity to do something that we don’t always do, which is to set aside all electoral considerations and do the right thing, and make a down payment for those coming generations against whose credit today’s emissions are being paid.

name: Jordan BARDELLA
text: Madam President, while the ambition of carbon neutrality in 2050 on European territory is a laudable objective, the European Union once again faces the wall of its contradictions. How can we advocate at the same time the tightening of carbon taxes in Europe on the one hand and on the other, the great move of the world by the multiplication of free trade agreements. It is not for taxpayers to pay to compensate for the deleterious effects of your economic policy. It is this policy itself that must be changed by the reappropriation of the local, the short circuit and economic patriotism. In favour of other more expensive and less efficient renewable energies, you want to reduce ideologically the share of nuclear energy in the energy mix: it is a political and ecological mistake. Nuclear energy is the cheapest, most decarbonised energy we have today, essential for the massive development of hydrogen pipelines, rightly promoted by the European Union. I call on you not to blame people, we are the best students in the world, the cleanest and the most environmentally friendly. The ecological transition must not be punitive or sacrificial, but rather a means of providing new opportunities for our industry and, with good reason, improving the quality of life of Europeans by re-engineering them in their environment.

name: Thomas WAITZ
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The COVID-19 crisis is exercising a collective dramatic crisis experience. This gives us a taste of what is to come. We will not solve the climate crisis by vaccination, by masks or by medicines. The only way to stop the climate crisis is to massively reduce CO2. I appeal to Members of this House to support an ambitious climate policy. It is about the objectives we set ourselves. We will have to follow suit with the measures anyway. Support our proposal for 65% savings, or at least the compromise on 60%, which we could possibly agree to! For the next generations, for our nature, which is under severe pressure – already due to warming – but also for our economy. We are already complaining about EUR 14 billion a year in damage caused by climate change. At +2 degrees, we are heading towards an estimated EUR 120 billion.  I also appeal to the industry, which is lobbying for less than 50% savings here in the House. Please accept reason! This is short-term. If you want to sustain long-term economic activity, we need to tackle climate change effectively.

name: Jessica POLFJÄRD
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for It does not have to be that we reduce climate debates, or climate action, to climate populism or pessimism. We can vote in favour of an increase in ambition that delivers both reduced emissions and increased economic growth. But this requires creating the right conditions for companies to change, investing in new technologies and innovation, and also ensuring the availability of clean energy. Unrealistic targets will never reduce emissions. On the contrary, it risks eroding confidence in the goals we jointly set and climate action in general. We also run the risk of driving businesses and jobs out of Europe, and we must be able to cope with the transition while maintaining competitiveness. To do this, everyone, both countries and people, needs to feel involved and share the understanding of the transition. Only then can Europe change and not shut down.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: – Madam President, today what we are doing is moving from rhetorical objectives to real legal and binding climate commitments. That's what the Climate Law means.  Moreover, in this case, Parliament is doing so by demanding that we have a 60% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2030, with the horizon set to climate neutrality by 2050. This Law is the cornerstone of the European Green Pact, probably the most relevant project for Europe in the next decade, where there will then be regulations and a huge transformation of our energy sources, our industry, our transport and mobility and our housing. A transformation that also has to be fair and social. But today we also send a message to the world: that we want, as Europeans, leadership in what will be the race on the journey to the Moon of the 21st century. This time we're not going to travel to any planet, we're going to have to save our planet. China has announced a willingness to have climate neutrality in 2060, we expect the United States to return to this race after November. We're not alone. And then all humanity, because it is humanity that is at stake and today we take a step in that defense.

name: Ondřej KNOTEK
text: – Madam President, we definitely need a climate law, but it must bring all EU regions together. The current proposal is unfortunately dividing the EU again into east and west. One of the key issues is the energy transition. Member States with industrial regions can reach ambitious climate goals but not only through switching to renewables. Besides renewables, here will also play low carbon technologies, like nuclear, and transition technologies, like fossil gas projects.  Therefore, I strongly encourage in the upcoming climate law negotiations, and within the negotiations on the various sustainability tools and state aid, to build the conditions for all technologies to reduce emissions. Such technological openness will be one of the key success factors in the climate transition and will maintain public support in the most challenged regions.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – Madam President! In recent decades there has been exponential population growth, resulting in consumption of energy, food, raw materials. That is why we have problems with the environment today, because the omissions go beyond the capabilities of our continent. For decades, Europe has been the leading country on the road towards greening our continent, and that is why climate legislation is part of this path, on which I hope that as many countries as possible outside the European Union will follow us, those that produce 90% of greenhouse gases. We can adopt very ambitious legislation. Today, the Commission is proposing to increase from 40% to 55% of the reduction in emissions, and we have proposals in Parliament 60, 65, 70. However, dear colleagues, we will not solve the environment by adopting demanding and ambitious legislation, but in the economy, among the population, in the real world, among farmers. We therefore need to take decisions here that will allow the development of new technologies that will reduce greenhouse gas emissions. We must prevent the reduction and loss of jobs resulting from moves too quickly. We must prevent energy poverty for those people who have the lowest incomes. The transition must be fair for all countries. And in the future, brave decisions will be needed, even when we are placed in space, I do not know, wind farms or also decide on a nuclear power plant. And those who are most ambitious today, I hope that such conclusions, which will require brave decisions, will also be supported in real life.

name: Sándor RÓNAI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European We can't just stand by and watch our environment go down in front of our eyes. With each snoted day, we just get closer to the climate catastrophe. Therefore, we cannot give in to the goals we believe in and with which we can achieve tangible results in the coming years and decades. But what does it take to see real change by 2030 or 2050? For example, we must insist that 65% less greenhouse gases enter the air in 10 years' time. Nor can we allow governments, including the Hungarian Government, to start dealing with a genuine green policy until after 2030. There's no time for that. If we allow this, we will not achieve total climate neutrality by 2050. But in 20 years' time, I would like to be able to look people in the eye and proudly say that we have not only tried, but also made real progress against climate change. Like I've said many times, we don't have another planet, so you have to be brave and green. Let's make a bold and green climate law.

name: Valter FLEGO
text: Dear Chairman, our planet is not good. He's sick. Young people, and all responsible people are in fear, aware that the future is uncertain. That's why we need to pass this remedial exam. We need to do it right, because today we are creating a climate neutral Europe, the leader of a healthier, better world, but on this path let's not stray and get involved in commas, percentages and statistics. Let man be at the center of us, because we have a lot of changes in behavior, in investments, but also in costs. And that's why, as much as it costs the budget of the European Union and the Member States, we have to pay for it because we don't have alternatives. And the fight against climate change needs and must go hand in hand with the budget. For this reason, we too often hear that each crisis is an opportunity for a new beginning. Let's show it now by deeds and vote for this Climate Act.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Vice-President Timmermans, today we are all taking a historic step together based on strong scientific data and leading humanity to restore the balance of the planet, while at the same time redesigning our economy and changing the habits of all of us. Citizens in Karditsa, Fthiotida, Macedonia, Crete know better than anyone how great the need is to tackle climate change, enhance sustainable development, sustainable food, sustainable transport, change in buildings, new innovative treatments in medicines. It is, at the same time, time to take this step realistically so that the 2030 target is based on an updated impact study and takes into account the effects of pandemics and corovirus.  Any high target risks undermining our credibility and at the same time creating expectations for citizens, which we cannot meet. This step must include green digital and resilient investment and jobs to deal with the recession. The citizens of Western Macedonia and Megalopolis, Commissioner, are looking here, in the European Union, and expect us to guide them and finance the projects so that no one is left behind. This step must be implemented directly by all Member States with strong monitoring. It is our duty today to give European citizens and the global community a modern, realistic, development legislative framework for climate.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I think that almost everyone in this House agreed that we want to provide ourselves and our children and grandchildren with fresh air, clean water and a safe environment. In general, as I listen to our discussion today, I get the impression that we are all a little bit right. There is no doubt that we need ambitious climate policy targets and a great deal of effort by all Europeans to achieve them.  Let us remember, however, that ambitious does not mean reckless or unreasonable. On the way to achieving these objectives, we must not deprive hundreds of thousands of Europeans of their jobs. Nor can we pass on the costs of this transformation to ordinary citizens who will have to pay them, for example in the form of higher electricity bills. Yes, let us set the bar high, but at the same time let us also give European companies and citizens the tools and means to jump the bar. The transformation must be carried out prudently.

name: Pernille WEISS
text: Madam President! I suppose we all dream of a simpler world, an easier life and a guarantee that everything will end well. That's how we humans are. But that is just not the way the world is, and especially not the challenges of the climate. That is why it is therefore our primary task as politicians to have the courage to set both course and pace so that we reach the ultimate goal by 2050, without sending jobs and CO2 out of the EU and making everyday life more expensive than ordinary people can afford to pay.  The EU's climate law is therefore more than a single figure that has filled far too much in the debate, namely the 2030 reduction target. Whether it should be 55, 60 or 65 does not really matter if the tools and especially the support are not present in reality, and not just on social media. That is why, frankly, I am embarrassed that we have not focused more on the tools, such as the proposal for industry-specific and cross-border strategic climate partnerships for companies and researchers, which here can find role models and sparring to make the latest technologies flourish more and faster. I hope, ladies and gentlemen, that whatever 2030 objective you are voting for tonight, you will vote in favour of these strategic green partnerships.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: Executive Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I see that many people who’ve made comments have left, but still, I’ll try and answer more in general to some of the comments that were made. First of all, to those people mostly sitting here, who are always referring to the citizens to not be ambitious. Well, if there’s one thing that’s consistent over the last year – even in the middle of the pandemic – a large majority of our citizens want us to act to face the climate crisis. It is the citizens who are asking this of us: even in the middle of the pandemic, when they’re very much worried about their health, when they are very much worried about their jobs, they still see the climate crisis as something they want us to act upon. Secondly, in the same context, don’t come at me with ‘sovereignty – we need to do it at the national level’. Our citizens understand this is a problem we can only tackle on a global level, and that Europe needs to take the leadership as Europe. Individual Member States can no longer do that. Another remark in reaction to some of the criticisms: the costs. It’s expensive. Well, let me be very clear. If you look at our impact assessment, and to put it in layman’s terms: this is going to be bloody hard to do! It is hard to do, and we will ask sacrifice of everyone – industry, our citizens, the transport system, etc. It’s a tough job, but it can be done, and the sooner we start, the lower the cost. The sooner we start, the earlier the benefits. That’s why we had our target of -55% for 2030. So we shouldn’t hide the fact that this is going to be, as I said, bloody difficult to do – but just imagine for one second the cost of non-action. How are you going to go to a small town, such as Limone Piemonte, where they’ve just suffered the most horrible weather conditions and people have died and the village is a shambles, and tell them: no, it’s too costly, we won’t do this. What’s the cost of that? What’s the cost of another monthly gota fria in Valencia if we don’t do something about that? What’s the cost if people are saying: here, we should keep all these coal mines open, but there’s no market for the coal – what’s the cost of keeping people in jobs that have no future? The cost is huge. We need to help people find new jobs, retrain them – but show solidarity. That’s why Just Transition is essential. Without Just Transition there will just be no transition and we will never get to our -55% goal. Now of course, on the other side of the Chamber, you want a higher target. I maintain that -55 is difficult but feasible. I also maintain it is in line with our international obligations. I say this with force, because I do not like the argument that we should be doing more because other industrialised nations are doing less. We should be leading but also taking others along the way. I am quite sure that Xi Jinping saying that China will be carbon-neutral by 2060 is a consequence of what we’re doing, and we need to convince others. The fact that South Africa has now said: ‘we want to be climate-neutral by 2050’ – that’s huge for a country like South Africa. Let’s use that and create more international cooperation, and then -55, I think, is very important. A final point on using carbon sink. Look at the state of our forests. Look at what’s happening with biodiversity in Europe. If we continue like this, there will be no pollinators anymore. How are you going to explain that to the farmers when they say: ‘let’s keep the present agricultural policy’? There will be no agriculture if there are no pollinators. There will be no agriculture if there’s no water for the land. There will be no agriculture if a storm sweeps away the topsoil every time. And we need to look after our forests. Carbon sink is diminishing in Europe. We need to increase it. We need to look after the situation of our grasslands, our peatlands, our forests, and in that context, I believe it is wise to include carbon sink in our targets and to make sure we increase the health of our natural environment.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to thank Executive Vice—President Timmermans for introducing this new chapter for the EU to become climate neutral. It is indeed a big change, it’s a historic moment and it is a new chapter that we are going to write together in the upcoming decades. I would like to paint a picture, inspired by a young climate activist who doesn’t need to be presented. I would like to paint a picture of a house that’s on fire. This planet is on fire and the young people, the young movement, noticed it and heard the alarm faster than many others. The scientists saw that the installation and the heating system is not functioning anymore. The conservatives say: ‘oh, but please keep it as it is because it was my daddy who actually installed it’. But that’s not a serious way to act when we have a problem with a system that is actually catching fire and already needs to have water put on it to make sure that we don’t have the catastrophe in some of the rooms that we already actually have. In the debate today we got many important messages from the Members. I would say that we have a big majority who see the necessity of doing more and who see that it’s not a sustainable way to keep giving subsidies to a system that is old. Therefore, we need to get rid of those fossil fuel subsidies by 2025 at the latest. Many also pointed out the necessity of doing it together. Yes, we need to do it together. It’s not OK if some Member States are not there helping out. Then the reparation will take further time, and we don’t have the time. Some others pointed out the importance of giving us more time. No, sorry, we don’t have that. A long reparation will actually endanger us more – all of us, all on this planet. Last but not least, it has been a privilege to work in this House together with the shadows. I would also, Commissioner, like to mention a shadow who is now going to be your colleague in the Commission, Ms McGuinness. I would like to say that she did a tremendously good job and that she will be a good colleague of yours, so I also mention that.  (Applause)

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: The debate is closed.  The vote on the amendments will take place shortly and the final vote in the afternoon of Wednesday, 7 October 2020. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Magdalena ADAMOWICZ
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – European climate law is a piece of legislation that paves the way for the European Union to achieve full climate neutrality by 2050 at the latest. This is not an easy process. Many are concerned about the competitiveness of our businesses, the maintenance of jobs, as well as the possible increase in the prices of products and services. For Polish is a particularly big challenge due to the very high share of coal in electricity and heat production. However, a radical reduction in greenhouse gas emissions is absolutely necessary to stop the climate catastrophe. It is no longer a question of whether, but when and how to achieve this goal.  There is no doubt that we must fight for climate on many fronts today, and that climate neutrality will not only be achieved through European climate law. The European Commission has already announced m.in. revision and extension of the EU greenhouse gas emissions trading scheme, the tightening of carbon dioxide emission standards for road vehicles, further support for the development of electromobility, the improvement of energy efficiency and renewable energy policies. These measures are necessary to decarbonise the European economy. However, adequate financial support is equally important, for example through EU cohesion policy and the Just Transition Fund. Only then will climate protection be reconciled with the socio-economic challenges we face today.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Writing. – It is in our interest to ensure energy independence in the European Union. We should not depend on the import of fossil fuels or the import of energy from third countries from the burning of fossil fuels. The less we burn fossil fuels in Europe, the healthier our people are and the longer our life expectancy. Achieving climate goals is also important for Europe from a security point of view. A greener Europe is less dependent on third countries in its energy policy. Energy issues are closely linked to our sovereignty.

name: Marc BOTENGA
text: Written. – The scientific consensus is clear: we need a 65% reduction in emissions by 2030. And yet the Commission came up with a much less ambitious target. Fortunately, the European Parliament is doing better, but again there is no majority in favour of a climate law that would simply reflect the scientific consensus. That's weird, isn't it? How is that possible? It has to do with economic interests.  We know the reason why the far right is doing everything possible to avoid ambitious climate targets. They want to protect the large shareholders of petroleum multinationals. That's why they like to spit on the young people who come out on the streets for a livable planet. But the traditional parties are also procrastinating, hesitating, when there is just no time. Why is it? Because they realise that really ambitious targets would also mean that we are going to ask for contributions from large multinationals, and not pay the ordinary worker with all kinds of eco-taxes? That we should then break with market logic and take energy policy back into public hands, instead of leaving it to the Engies, Electrabels or Shells of this world? That we then need a completely different production model, because capitalism does not offer a future for our planet?

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. – Climate change is affecting humanity, and extreme weather events are becoming more frequent. The European Green Pact reaffirms the ambition of the European institutions to make Europe the first climate-neutral continent by 2050. Agriculture depends to a large extent on weather conditions, being one of the most vulnerable sectors.  Romania, the EU's second-largest wheat exporter, has been affected by the worst drought in 100 years, with a direct effect on the European economy, which denotes the importance of compliance with climate measures at European level as well as global compliance. The European Parliament voted to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 60% by 2030, representing an additional financial effort that is extremely difficult for Member States to achieve.  We certainly all want a climate-neutral continent, but without causing a significant increase in unemployment at European Union level. Climate targets must not jeopardise millions of jobs without the certainty that workers in directly affected industries will have a future in the European labour market. Europe must take swift and firm action to protect jobs.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: Writing. – Today we have an extremely important task ahead of us. This is because the EU will undertake to meet carbon neutrality by 2050 and set a medium-term emission reduction target by 2030.  The vote and then the entry into force of the European Climate Act is a historic and groundbreaking act. Solidarity and justice are very important in achieving both objectives. The starting points for achieving climate neutrality vary from one member to a different one, so countries will have support mechanisms and funding at their disposal, such as the Fair Transition Fund.  Slovenia can also draw from this fund, so I call on the Government to set more ambitious targets. Indeed, Slovenia has committed to reducing CO2 emissions by 30% by 2030, and this is not enough. It is important that we do not fall behind in the transition to carbon neutrality. In a socially just way, we must tax CO2 emissions so that the damage done to the environment and people will actually be paid for by polluters, without exceptions for large industries and corporations.  Although I welcome the Commission's higher proposal after a 55% reduction in emissions, the Socialists and Democrats in the EP are advocating an even more ambitious 60% reduction. We cannot turn back time, so we must take bolder measures and fully comply with the commitments made in the Paris Agreement and the Sustainable Development Goals. Because there's no Planet B!

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. – The severity of the climate situation is beyond dispute. Therefore, raising awareness or, if you will, discussing another administrative step is not enough today. We must act responsibly. In the midst of the coronavirus epidemic, the European Parliament should focus on the impact of the proposed objectives on the economy, SMEs and jobs and not on abstract debates on various regulations. Nevertheless, there is still hope of achieving the climate goals. To do this, three conditions must be met. The first is the entry into force of the European Council Agreement on the Multiannual Financial Framework in July and the "Next Generation EU" Recovery Fund. It is unacceptable that Parliament, playing a petty political game, is delaying the launch of programmes and financial instruments essential for climate protection. The second criterion is to take into account the specificities of the Member States. There is concern that the European Commission and Parliament would like to see the climate regulation adopted in the absence of impact assessments at Member State level. Member States are starting their climate protection efforts from different situations, and respect for this is key. Finally, we need fair and equitable climate protection. Measures which do not lead to a sharp increase in consumer prices and do not jeopardise the security of supply of Member States. No climate regulation should result in an increase in overhead costs. In this context, it is also worth taking into account good practices in the Member States. Such a good example Hungary, which has steadily reduced greenhouse gas emissions and household energy prices at the same time over the last decade.

name: Krzysztof JURGIEL
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – European climate law is one of the flagship elements of the European Green Deal and as such should be of the highest legislative standard. I have some reservations about the ENVI report. Firstly, an impact assessment of this proposal is not sufficient– it should apply to both the EU as a whole and the Member States, and include concrete data on the impact of the increased target on individual sectors. Secondly, the determination of the trajectory by only one institution, namely the European Commission, without extensive consultation with the stakeholders and governments of the Member States, raises serious doubts. Thirdly, as a member of the AGRI Committee in the European Parliament, I do not support the introduction into climate law of a greenhouse budget that will burden all sectors, including the agricultural sector.  Farmers will be subject not only to the new environmental requirements of the Field-to-Table Strategy and biodiversity strategy, but also to greenhouse gas emission requirements. We must not forget that agriculture is an emitter of carbon dioxide, but also an important absorber. This role must be emphasised at every turn if we do not want excessive requirements to force farmers to stop producing. For the above reasons, I voted against the report on European climate law.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – The climate law is the landmark legislation of the current mandate of the EU institutions. Not only because it will stimulate record-high government spending aiming to reach net-zero emissions by 2050, but also our ambition will determine the economic and social landscape in Europe in the coming decades. If we are wise and smart, we could make Europe a better place for our children and grandchildren. We should be aware of not ruining this chance by disengaging whole regions and Member States. I cannot support a text calling for the binding objective of climate neutrality on Member State level. Our countries differ widely in terms of the starting points. There are also path-dependent factors formed over decades and centuries such as industrial base and capacities, as well as factors completely irrelevant to the political government such as geographic situation and natural resources. Furthermore, we should not undermine the weight of our institution if we set prescriptive targets without having scientific proof for their adequacy. The stakes are too high – the future of our economies, of our European way of life. The profound implications that the climate law will have means that it requires rigorous impact assessment at all levels.

name: Dan-Ştefan MOTREANU
text: in writing. – I consider it extremely important to make the transition to climate neutrality, building on the comprehensive impact study carried out by the European Commission in recent months, in a responsible, progressive and safe way, also protecting the European Union economy, generating jobs and not destroying them, without imposing additional taxes on citizens. Romania, the country I represent, supports the European Commission's proposal to increase the 2030 emissions reduction target from 40% to 55%. It is an ambitious growth, and closer to the economic reality of the moment, at a time when the 55% target already entails costs of around EUR 350 billion for the next 10 years at EU level.  Of course, we all want a climate-neutral Europe as soon as possible, but I stress that the economic effort to achieve a target of more than 55% is extremely worrying even for the most developed states of the Union, assuming new, extraordinary costs, which are neither identified nor foreseen.  In addition, we are in the midst of a pandemic that is causing and will continue to cause significant long-term economic losses, and at the end of the year Britain, one of Europe's main economic forces, will officially leave the European Union.

name: Rovana PLUMB
text: in writing. – The European Parliament has, alongside several countries, local authorities and scientists, declared that our planet is facing a climate and environment emergency. To avoid accelerated and irreversible climate change and a massive decline in biodiversity, global greenhouse gas emissions need to be rapidly reduced. In response to this challenge, the European Commission has presented a Green Deal, aiming to make Europe the first climate neutral continent by 2050, achieving economic development with respect for the natural boundaries of the planet while ensuring a just transition with no person and no place left behind. The Climate Law represents a cornerstone of the Green Deal. We have the policies, we have the commitment, and we have the funds to support it. But fairness is key. Our ambition should help, not hurt, the most vulnerable in society. This transition will be just, or there will be no transition. We expect this fairness will drive to eradicate energy poverty, creating jobs and ensuring solidarity among all Member States. We have to act in time so we can still manage the transition. That is why it is so important that we start now, no time to waste.

name: Andrey SLABAKOV
text: in writing. – Dear colleagues, we are gathered here today, it seems, in religious worship at the altar of the Green Deal. Well, I refuse to worship this apparently misguided idea or the unreasonable way you're going to implement it. We are hostage to a left-wing green policy that keeps asking and doesn't care about the effect on states and people.  First, the Council agreed to a target of 43% by 2030. The Commission has decided to raise it to 55%, and now Parliament will vote, I am sure, on a target of 60%. Once again, I am telling you that with this climate law, you put nature before the people. You cannot insist on an immediate green transition and the closure of entire industries, when the lives of tens of millions of Europeans and their families depend on these sectors. Every time you raise your goals and congratulate yourself on how progressive you are, you doom people to unemployment and hunger. Hungry people don't produce carbon dioxide emissions, I'm sure. Meanwhile, you voted for the Mobile Package, which destroyed an entire sector in Central and Eastern Europe and caused thousands of lorries to travel empty on the roads. And they don't produce carbon dioxide, I'm sure. Shame! Thank you.

name: Susana SOLÍS PÉREZ
text: in writing. – One of the EU's priority objectives is the fight against climate change. That is why the European Climate Law is of fundamental importance to our future. This law is set as the cornerstone of the European Green Pact and will enshrine in European legislation the objective of achieving climate neutrality in the EU by 2050.  We must support this historic proposal that will make Europe a world leader and a benchmark for achieving climate neutrality. All this must also serve to strengthen the competitiveness of European industry and achieve an economic and digital transition.  This Law should provide a framework that drives new opportunities and places the EU at the forefront of innovation and clean technologies. To do this, we need to create the right economic incentives and promote investment in innovation.  It is our obligation to ensure a fair transition with the right support for the regions, sectors and citizens most affected.  Among all of us, we must make this law a reality and make it a European success story for our citizens.

text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Downpours, droughts, tornadoes, extreme heat, rising sea and ocean levels, species extinction, famine, forced migrations, epidemics. These are just some of the effects of the climate crisis. Decades of merciless exploitation of the planet's resources have brought us to the edge of the abyss. Many losses will no longer be reversed, but we can and are obliged to take steps to protect the Earth and its inhabitants and residents from disaster.  According to a UNEP report published in 2019, achieving the target of limiting global warming to 1.5°C, which was identified in the Paris Agreement as a desirable state, will require the EU to reduce emissions by at least 65% by 2030. name: Alexandr VONDRA
text: Writing. – The main problem with this report is that it does not respect reality. And we could talk about other dangerous ideas that it contains, at random, about lawsuits against states that, in the eyes of concerned activists, will not do enough, but in the light of this fact it seems secondary. We are constantly told to listen to scientists, but when the EEA European Environment Agency says that the 40% target by 2030 will also be problematic, the proponents respond with a Stachan figure of 60%. Even the impact assessment, which, incidentally, we received only after the vote in the ENVI Committee, still envisages a maximum of 55% by 2030. The commitment to climate neutrality by 2050 applies not only to the EU, but also to the Member States, not taking into account their different baseline situation with the COVID-19 pandemic, which has damaged and will further damage their economies, nor the conclusions of the European Council. In short, some colleagues have once again demonstrated that they are mainly interested in building air locks and that no facts or rational analysis will prevent them from doing so. But believe me, the incentive to deliver the unassable will quickly disappear in some Member States, and without their will, only this ambitious plan will remain as a testament to the times.
